webTitle: Can new year resolutions change your life?

fields.headline: Can new year resolutions change your life?
fields.trailText:
Dear Oliver,
The making of resolutions appeals to a primeval part of the human psyche: our need for rituals and symbolism. The act of acknowledging that your health, your finances, or your relationships could be improved by changing something plants a strong message in your subconscious. You identify your needs, whether it's to shed a few pounds or ditch self-limiting behaviour; you garner your thoughts, prioritise, and set goals: all catalysts for change.
fields.body:
Dear Oliver,
The making of resolutions appeals to a primeval part of the human psyche: our need for rituals and symbolism. The act of acknowledging that your health, your finances, or your relationships could be improved by changing something plants a strong message in your subconscious. You identify your needs, whether it's to shed a few pounds or ditch self-limiting behaviour; you garner your thoughts, prioritise, and set goals: all catalysts for change.

The ritual of writing things down is a simple yet powerful way of regaining a sense of control after the unchecked excesses of the season. Forward planning is an affirmation of optimism for the future. Just because you behaved in a certain way last year - smoked too much, drank too much, were grumpy in the mornings - does not mean you have to be the same this year. A successful company does not go forward without a good business development strategy. Resolutions are our personal development strategy, a commitment to ourselves.

Today is a date unlike any other - a symbolic marker of new beginnings, a fresh start. It's an opportunity for pause in our lives, when we focus on what we want from the year ahead. It occurs at a time when we're overfed and overspent, so we naturally incline towards shaping up, becoming leaner, fitter, focused, solvent. So what's stopping you? Make this the year you realise your dreams!

Yours sincerely,
Elaine Griffiths

Dear Elaine,
Of course we have to monitor our behaviour and make plans to change it, and of course the start of a new year is a good time to create a punctuation mark - even a new chapter heading - for the next stage in our personal story.

But that is not all you are saying. You are offering fool's gold in suggesting that we can realise our dreams. While you may become personally wealthier, through the success of your magazine, if enough people buy into your damaging illusions, the reality is far harsher than that.

All of us are powerless to protect ourselves from dog-eat-dog globalised corporatism. It is also extremely hard for us as individuals to grasp the huge impact of our childhood experiences on our adult personalities, something it can take decades, rather than a single year, to sort out. On top of that - although I am sceptical that their effect is great on most people's personality or wellbeing - genes do have a big effect on some people. What if you are a woman who, having consumed the advertising images which pay your wages, dreams of being a 5ft 8in model with fabulous legs but is actually 5ft 2in, with a thick and dumpy lower half?

Like so much modern psychology and nearly all think-positive, anyone-can-be-president American psychobilge, you are in the business of encouraging us to believe there are quick fixes for problems that take many years to create and at least as many to solve.

Yours sceptically,
Oliver James

Dear Oliver,
Points taken. But what else should we do? Give up trying? None of us is immune to the arbitrary daily threats to our happiness and wellbeing - whether it's falling victim to aggressive globalised corporatism, the legacy of a less-than-perfect childhood, or a genetic tendency to a thick and dumpy lower half. Most of us accept that there are things we cannot change, but understand that there are things we can: negative habits, attitudes, ways of thinking.

Some of us may need help with this - often an expensive process that, presumably, pays your wages. Our early experiences undoubtedly shape our characters, but the notion that we spend the first part our lives accruing damage which we then have to spend decades of the second unravelling denies the capacity of the individual to take some responsibility for the way things are in the here and now.

Sure, there are no quick fixes, but there is a lot to be said for not blaming others (our past, our parents, the media) for the way we are now. Accepting that our parents and others did the best they could with the knowledge they had available at the time, forgiving them their human faults and frailties, and trying to understand their own stories is enormously liberating.

Far from being psychobilge, it seems to me common sense to accept that we cannot change the past, but also to recognise that we can influence our future through our thoughts, actions, decisions and choices, and that we have within us the capacity to take responsibility for writing our personal story. Resolutions can be a tool for doing this.

Whatever way you look at it, Oliver, if we ourselves don't realise our dreams, no one else is going to do it for us.

Yours,
Elaine

Dear Elaine,
I'm not advocating blaming others, nor do I mean to suggest that there is nothing that can be done to help ourselves. But as Roy Baumeister's research has recently shown, the trouble with insecure people telling themselves (or being told by parents or counsellors) that they are great and that they can achieve whatever they dream of achieving is that it can actually make them even more insecure.

Unjustified self-esteem needs constant propping up, and when the real world intervenes in the form of a rejection it can cause depression or even violence: Baumeister's study showed that hostility and aggression were sometimes triggered when falsely inflated self-esteem was popped by reality.

On the one hand, an American-style culture of complaint - blaming the parents, government etcetera - will get us nowhere; but on the other, it will not do for parents and governments to deny their ultimate responsibility for how we turn out.

As individuals, each of us must eke out as much volition as we can from our lives, but the huge difficuties must not be minimised. The danger of being relentlessly and exaggeratedly over-optimistic about what can be achieved is that it actually has the opposite effect.

Yours,
Oliver

Dear Oliver,
What a dreary, lacklustre life it would be if we didn't dare to dream. How would anything ever get done if we didn't dare to try because of fear of failure? Setting ourselves goals and targets in the workplace is seen as perfectly acceptable, as is coaching, encouraging and inspiring others to succeed. Why should things be any different when it comes to making personal resolutions?

Furthermore, you must be aware of the plethora of research findings showing the power our thoughts and emotions - positive and negative - have on our physiology and behaviour, most notably in Candace Pert's seminal Molecules of Emotion.

Thought-based techniques such as creative visualisation, neuro-linguistic programming, hypnotherapy and cognitive behavioural therapy are all gaining scientific credence for their effectiveness in helping to change negative habits.

At their most basic, many of these techniques involve the individual thinking about and often writing down their goals, hopes and aspirations - pretty much what most of us do on January 1 each year. Many of them involve shifting the focus on to the positive - reminding yourself of the benefits of losing a few pounds, for example, rather than how many pounds you need to lose - and playing up one's strengths. Should we refrain from positive self-talk for fear of falsely inflating our self-esteem?

Of course a balance has to be struck between optimism and realism, but if we don't at least start off with an expectation of success, we'll fall at the first fence. Even if this year's resolution is simply to accept ourselves as we are, warts and all. Now there's a thought...

Happy new year, Oliver.

Yours,
Elaine

Dear Elaine,
One of the few really interesting findings of cognitive science is that healthy people live in a bubble of positive illusions. At least 121 studies have shown that in general they view themselves in unrealistically positive ways, believing themselves to have far more control over the external events which dominate their lives than is truly the case and being far more optimistic about the future than probability predicts.

By contrast, depressed people suffer from what is known as "depressive realism". Although some of their beliefs are incorrectly negative ("I'm fat, I'm stupid, I'm ugly", when they're not), they actually have a better grasp of the real likelihood of life going pear-shaped than the undepressed.

In this sense, treatments for depression (like cognitive therapy or pills) are often partly about encouraging depressives to see through the rose-coloured specs of the undepressed. That is fine. But where I totally part company with you is if you exploit our need to accentuate the positive and eliminate the negative by allying therapy and self-help with the goals of modern corporatism.

We do need dreams - but too many of our dreams have been hijacked by commerce and the work ethic. We find ourselves constantly wanting to be something we are not and to own possessions that we "lack". No amount of positive-thinking sticking plaster will cure the consequent sense of disappointment which afflicts so many of us on discovering that these dreams are not really ours at all.

Yet how far are we really disagreeing? For all my curmudgeoning, a sense of seasonal harmony is sweeping over me. Things can only get better, eh?

Happy new year and best wishes,
Oliver

webTitle: Steaming in

fields.headline: Steaming in
fields.standfirst: Mother of all hangovers? How about a hair of the dog in Reykjavik? Start saving, says  Andy Pietrasik
fields.trailText: Mother of all hangovers? How about a hair of the dog in Reykjavik? Start saving, says Andy Pietrasik
fields.body:
Good morning and welcome to the 21st century. You probably feel 1,000 years old today, even those of you who decided to stay in last night, watch the festivities on television and crack open one too many bottles of bubbly. The furthest thing from your mind is likely to be the party capital of northern Europe anyhow. But, rest assured, you'll soon get over any millennial hangover. And remember, the best thing about resolutions is breaking them.

Besides, it could be worse. A lot worse. You could have woken up to a credit-card receipt with as many zeroes on it as the year. Which would have been the case had you chosen to see in the new year in Reykjavik. So, console yourself with the fact that you've saved all that money and now you can afford to go out there and indulge yourself.

Everything you've read or heard about Reykjavik before is true - it's remote, it's cool, it's expensive and it's wild - only more so.

How remote? It's the world's northernmost capital and one of the smallest, with a population a third the size of Bristol's (170,000) stuck out on an island that's almost as big as England, but which, with its volcanic lava fields, geysers and glaciers, is about as uninhabitable as the moon. Outside Reykjavik, it's home to only 107,000 or so more people.

How cool? Iceland may share its name with a frozen-food chain, but the climate's not that cold, and the attitude is a lot more upmarket. When Robbie Williams was here last year, he took a stroll down the main shopping street, Laugavegur, accompanied by four burly bodyguards. The locals simply laughed and pretended not to notice him. There's no room for an ego that outsized in a town this small.

Besides, most people under the age of 30 seem to play in a pop band and it's hard to be impressed by Robbie Williams when everyone around you looks as if they've just stepped out of the central school of casting for glacial chic. The term "model society" applies to features other than Iceland's health service, housing stock and low rate of unemployment.

How expensive? A beer will set you back £6 in a bar, a bottle of wine £30 in a restaurant and even the McDonald's takes credit cards.

How wild? To quote Blur's Damon Albarn, who owns a flat here, "They come out at midnight, drink all night, dance like bastards and then run through the streets shagging each other senseless. It's brilliant!"

Reykjavik's hedonistic reputation has preceded it for more than a decade now in articles and features headed "Diamond geysers", "Crazy Norses" and "Over the volcanoes". It's hard, then, not to be initially disappointed when you arrive in a town that, by day, looks distinctly grey, low-rise and deserted. You feel as though the captain must have mis-set the co-ordinates and landed you in Reykjavik, Manitoba, way up in the wastes of northern Canada. What a load of codswallop, you're tempted to think as you take in the fishing fleet on a dockside as grim as Grimsby and contemplate a Friday night dodging the fists of the tanked-up crews.

But the seductive charm of Reykjavik is that it reveals its qualities by degrees. Degrees of alcohol, largely, it's true, but still it's impossible not to warm to the place after even a short visit. Architecturally, it may not be the most pre possessing city in the world - an exception is the Pearl restaurant on the hill, its glass-domed dining room revolving on columns supported by silver water tanks. Then there's the modernist City Hall, which juts out into the lake. And all those old red, blue and green townhouses with tin roofs. Oh, and, over the bay, the low-lying, flat-topped Mount Esja.

But, generally, it's what's inside the buildings that counts, and you only get to see this when the locals are good and ready to put on a floor show. That usually means after 11pm on a Friday and Saturday night. There's no point starting the weekend any earlier, because the bars stay open till about 5am on these two days and, with alcohol so prohibitively expensive, most people are content to charge themselves up at each other's homes before going out on the " runtur ".

Sounds a bit like rutting, I know, but it's what Icelanders do on a big night out. And it is a bit more sophisticated than it sounds, especially since beer was legalised in 1989, and the locals no longer have to rely on industrial quantities of vodka and the native firewater Brennivin (black death) to act as social lubricants. Basically, the runtur means going from bar to bar and sampling from each until you can no longer be bothered to move on and queue outside another place that promises an even better mix of music and an even more beautiful set of people within. Simply put, it's a pub crawl; except for pubs, read designer bars; and don't expect anybody to crawl when they are wearing Prada, Armani, Diesel and Duffer.

The good thing is that most bars are concentrated in a few downtown streets, so you're never more than a stroll away from the next runturing post.

A typical Friday night, then, might kick off in the Kaffibarinn, a cosy, little drinking hole that Damon Albarn is reputed to have a stake in. Most locals claim he was given 1%, but that's enough to pack the place with black polo necks by 11.30pm and have you asking for a can-opener to extricate yourself by midnight.

Down the road, at the Rex, the tone is less Camden Britpop, more King's Road chrome. It was designed by Sir Terence Conran, after all, and is a minimalist setting fit for the Helmut Lang-labelled to mwah-mwah the Nicole Farhis, for gin and tonics to chink with cocktails called, um, orgasm (peppermint liqueur and Baileys), and for Björk to be seen wafting down the stairs to the members-only Mafia Room. Even its toilets figure in a best-of-Reykjavik feature in a local boutique's magazine.

One o'clock in the morning and all is well: still no sign of chundering Vikings causing carnage in the town. Next stop, Kaffi Thomsen, "a hip nightclub for the younger generation that boasts a café atmosphere upstairs [and] a dancefloor in a basement that's styled in a gothic mode", according to another magazine. In terms of interiors, it doesn't get more basic: wooden floors, window tables and cave-like drawings of horses on the walls. But the DJ by the door is Herb Legowitz of local band Gus Gus, and the music is house, drum'n'bass and a dash of classic disco. People are drinking all right, people are dancing like bastards even, but no one is running down the streets shagging or, indeed, beating each other senseless. Despite the binge-drinking, Iceland has one of the lowest crime rates in the world and vandalism, to people or property, appears minimal.

It feels a bit lightweight to be leaving at 4am, but there's another round to come on Saturday night. And besides, there's one more treat in store before the dawn. Down by the docks is a fastfood stand that has a queue of 30 or more people weaving and snaking its way up to the serving hatch.

The name picked out in neon is Baejarins Beztu Pylsur, which at this pickled hour could translate as ram's testicles in whey, for all I know and care. Except that a friendly type has already informed me it means City's Best Hotdogs. He also tells me that this particular outlet is so popular the owner can afford to live in Florida off the proceeds (£1 a dog, and people still insist on paying with credit cards). Icelanders love their hotdogs -the secret's in the sauce, apparently, a confection peculiar to the island, called Remoladi, which tops off the usual staples of fried onions, raw onions, steaming dog, ketchup and mustard. Too much information at 4am, but a simpler and cheaper pleasure could not be more appreciated after a night on the runtur .

You may find they lie a little heavy on the stomach when you emerge late morning for your next Reykjavik sortie, mind. But a dip in one of the seven naturally-heated outdoor pools within the city limits only goes to confirm why Icelanders look so good despite the ravages of the weekend runtur. That, and the fact that there's very little chlorine in the gene pool. A constitutional swim in warm geothermal spring waters and a relaxing soak in the hot pots is part of the daily routine here.

Okay, so tectonic activity coupled with glaciers can have its drawbacks - three years ago the Loki volcano erupted beneath Europe's largest glacier and threatened widespread flooding along the southern coast. But there's no getting away from the fact that, all in all, Icelanders lead pretty clean and healthy lifestyles: hot water pumped straight from the ground to heat their houses and their baths; natural spring water to drink from the taps; and hydroelectric power to keep the computers up to speed with their credit-card spending. All very green.

Then there's the diet: fish stocks precious enough to wage and win three cod wars with Britain and free-range lambs to make the Welsh turn green with envy. Apart from that, though, they don't mind what they eat: puffins, rotting shark and cod's chins (whoever knew they had chins?).

When it comes to food, Icelanders argue that you get more for your money in terms of quantity and quality in Reykjavik than you do in London. And it's hard to contradict them when you sit down to a meal of hot smoked breast of guillemot with beetroot, cheese and pears, followed by pan-fried plaice with banana and blue cheese sauce (it works, believe me) for £25 in a restaurant as cosy as the Vid Tjornina. Chuck in dessert, wine and coffee, however, and the plastic soon comes in for another pasting.

In between all the scoffing and quaffing, let's not forget that Reykjavik is one of the nine European cities of culture this year. Apparently, Iceland publishes more books per capita than any other country in the world and has the highest literacy rate. And they had a Nobel Laureate in novelist Halldór Laxness. You could do worse than take in some of the Icelandic sagas displayed on vellum at the Arni Magnusson Institute - more tales of runtur , revenge and rampage to tide you over till the next session.

Then there's the bleak but powerful landscapes of artists such as Finnur Jonsson in the National Gallery, which give a pretty good indication of how apocalyptic the landscape must be just beyond the city limits. And finally there's the pièce de resistance , quite literally, in the form of the Icelandic Institute of Phallology. That's right, a penis museum.

The director, Sigurdur Hjartarson, started out with a bull's penis that he used as a whip when he was a boy in the country. He has now expanded his collection to include 90 specimens. Since you ask, the smallest belonged to a field mouse and the largest to a blue whale. There's no human trophy on display as yet, though there is a written pledge on the wall beneath a picture of an 84-year-old farmer called Pall Arason.

Right. So. Anybody up for a stiff drink?

Reykjavik on the cheap

1 Follow the line of incoming locals after Customs and raid the booze shelves in Keflavik airport's duty-free shop. Will save you a small mortgage on the runtur .
2 Lunch lightly on lobster soup at Laekjarbrekka restaurant (Bankastraeti 2), which specialises in Icelandic cuisine. Built in 1834, this is one of the oldest houses in Reykjavik. Prices have gone up a bit since, though, and soup will set you back about £10.
3 Swim at one of the city's seven naturally-heated outdoor pools. At £1.70, they're a cheap hangover cure and a convenient alternative to the Blue Lagoon. Sundlaug vesturbaejar (Hofsvallagata) is the oldest and has the most local characters.
4 Hotdog supper. At a £1 a go, you can have several. Many outlets, but City's Best (Posthusstraeti) is the local favourite.
5 Get a Reykjavik tourist card for unlimited free bus travel and admission to public swimming pools and museums. Cards can be bought at the City Hall Information Centre, Bankastraeti 2, and from some hotels and guesthouses,£5 for one day, £7 for two.

City of culture highlights

Reykjavik is promoting itself under the theme of culture and nature, and events fall under the categories of water, air, fire and earth . . . to mirror the landscape.

Water
Futurice, August 11-13. Reykjavik makes it on to the international fashion map with a show to promote talent from Iceland, Helsinki and Bergen, with support from international designers such as Jeremy Scott.

Air
Voices of Europe: Björk sings with 10 choristers from each of the nine other cities of culture in Hallgrimskirkja Church, August 26 and 27.

Fire
Reykjavik culture night, August 19. Entering its fifth year, the festive night features outdoor concerts, performances, fireworks and fairs, late-night opening for restaurants, bars, galleries and shops. Until dawn.

Earth
International Festival of Literature, September 10-16. Seminars, talks and readings with prominent Icelandic and international writers (previous guests include Kurt Vonnegut, Seamus Heaney and Martin Amis).

Day trips

1 Blue Lagoon. Pool of mineral-rich, geothermally-heated seawater set amid a lunar landscape 35 minutes' drive from the city. Facilities recently refurbished to the tune of $7m, but only £7 to get in. A steal and a must.

2 Golden circle tour (8 hours, £42). Takes in some of the best-known natural features - the Gullfoss waterfall, Geysir geothermal field, where the hot spring Strokkur obligingly spouts every five minutes, and Thingvellir national park - where the world's oldest parliament was established (930AD) and where the continental plates of Europe and America are slowly pulling apart.

3 Icelandic pony trekking, Hafnarfjordur, 15 minutes from the city centre. Three-hour tours cost £26, including transfers, and trot out daily from 10am and 2pm.

Best bars and cafés

1 Solon Islandus (Bankastraeti 7). Entrance to the classical or jazz performances upstairs costs £10. Downstairs, it's a genteel setting for a bohemian crowd to sip coffee, wine or snack on puffin salad at £8-£9.
2 Vegamot (Vegamotastigur 4). Bistro and bar with mellow sounds and Thai chicken by day and evening, funk and salsa by night.
3 Prikid (Laugavegur) Recently refurbished but retains a traditional feel. Marvin Gaye soothes you into Saturday over a cafetiere (£3.50).
4 Kaffibarinn (Bergstadastraeti 1). Musician, writer and actor crowd (plus wannabes) form a tightly-packed clique in this clubby pub.
5 Radhuskaffi (City Hall, Tjarnargotu 11). Perfect place to contemplate the scenery and the state of your finances. Seated at water level, look out across the lake to the mountains.

The practicals

Icelandair (0171-874 1000, www.icelandair.co.uk) flies every day, 11 times a week from Heathrow and Glasgow. Two nights in the Leifur Eriksson hotel costs £267pp, including flights, transfers and breakfast, January- March. A two-night break staying at the art-deco Hotel Borg, including breakfast, costs £317pp.

And remember, the best thing about resolutions is breaking them. Besides, it could be worse. A lot worse. You could have woken up to a credit-card receipt with as many zeroes on it as the year. Which would have been the case had you chosen to see in the new year in Reykjavik. So, console yourself with the fact that you've saved all that money and now you can afford to go out there and indulge yourself. Everything you've read or heard about Reykjavik before is true - it's remote, it's cool, it's expensive and it's wild - only more so. How remote? It's the world's northernmost capital and one of the smallest, with a population a third the size of Bristol's (170,000) stuck out on an island that's almost as big as England, but which, with its volcanic lava fields, geysers and glaciers, is about as uninhabitable as the moon. Outside Reykjavik, it's home to only 107,000 or so more people. How cool? Iceland may share its name with a frozen-food chain, but the climate's not that cold, and the attitude is a lot more upmarket. When Robbie Williams was here last year, he took a stroll down the main shopping street, Laugavegur, accompanied by four burly bodyguards. The locals simply laughed and pretended not to notice him. There's no room for an ego that outsized in a town this small. Besides, most people under the age of 30 seem to play in a pop band and it's hard to be impressed by Robbie Williams when everyone around you looks as if they've just stepped out of the central school of casting for glacial chic. The term "model society" applies to features other than Iceland's health service, housing stock and low rate of unemployment. How expensive? A beer will set you back £6 in a bar, a bottle of wine £30 in a restaurant and even the McDonald's takes credit cards. How wild? To quote Blur's Damon Albarn, who owns a flat here, "They come out at midnight, drink all night, dance like bastards and then run through the streets shagging each other senseless. It's brilliant!" Reykjavik's hedonistic reputation has preceded it for more than a decade now in articles and features headed "Diamond geysers", "Crazy Norses" and "Over the volcanoes". It's hard, then, not to be initially disappointed when you arrive in a town that, by day, looks distinctly grey, low-rise and deserted. You feel as though the captain must have mis-set the co-ordinates and landed you in Reykjavik, Manitoba, way up in the wastes of northern Canada. What a load of codswallop, you're tempted to think as you take in the fishing fleet on a dockside as grim as Grimsby and contemplate a Friday night dodging the fists of the tanked-up crews. But the seductive charm of Reykjavik is that it reveals its qualities by degrees. Degrees of alcohol, largely, it's true, but still it's impossible not to warm to the place after even a short visit. Architecturally, it may not be the most pre possessing city in the world - an exception is the Pearl restaurant on the hill, its glass-domed dining room revolving on columns supported by silver water tanks. Then there's the modernist City Hall, which juts out into the lake. And all those old red, blue and green townhouses with tin roofs. Oh, and, over the bay, the low-lying, flat-topped Mount Esja. But, generally, it's what's inside the buildings that counts, and you only get to see this when the locals are good and ready to put on a floor show. That usually means after 11pm on a Friday and Saturday night. There's no point starting the weekend any earlier, because the bars stay open till about 5am on these two days and, with alcohol so prohibitively expensive, most people are content to charge themselves up at each other's homes before going out on the " runtur ". Sounds a bit like rutting, I know, but it's what Icelanders do on a big night out. And it is a bit more sophisticated than it sounds, especially since beer was legalised in 1989, and the locals no longer have to rely on industrial quantities of vodka and the native firewater Brennivin (black death) to act as social lubricants. Basically, the runtur means going from bar to bar and sampling from each until you can no longer be bothered to move on and queue outside another place that promises an even better mix of music and an even more beautiful set of people within. Simply put, it's a pub crawl; except for pubs, read designer bars; and don't expect anybody to crawl when they are wearing Prada, Armani, Diesel and Duffer. The good thing is that most bars are concentrated in a few downtown streets, so you're never more than a stroll away from the next runturing post. A typical Friday night, then, might kick off in the Kaffibarinn, a cosy, little drinking hole that Damon Albarn is reputed to have a stake in. Most locals claim he was given 1%, but that's enough to pack the place with black polo necks by 11.30pm and have you asking for a can-opener to extricate yourself by midnight. Down the road, at the Rex, the tone is less Camden Britpop, more King's Road chrome. It was designed by Sir Terence Conran, after all, and is a minimalist setting fit for the Helmut Lang-labelled to mwah-mwah the Nicole Farhis, for gin and tonics to chink with cocktails called, um, orgasm (peppermint liqueur and Baileys), and for Björk to be seen wafting down the stairs to the members-only Mafia Room. Even its toilets figure in a best-of-Reykjavik feature in a local boutique's magazine. One o'clock in the morning and all is well: still no sign of chundering Vikings causing carnage in the town. Next stop, Kaffi Thomsen, "a hip nightclub for the younger generation that boasts a café atmosphere upstairs [and] a dancefloor in a basement that's styled in a gothic mode", according to another magazine. In terms of interiors, it doesn't get more basic: wooden floors, window tables and cave-like drawings of horses on the walls. But the DJ by the door is Herb Legowitz of local band Gus Gus, and the music is house, drum'n'bass and a dash of classic disco. People are drinking all right, people are dancing like bastards even, but no one is running down the streets shagging or, indeed, beating each other senseless. Despite the binge-drinking, Iceland has one of the lowest crime rates in the world and vandalism, to people or property, appears minimal. It feels a bit lightweight to be leaving at 4am, but there's another round to come on Saturday night. And besides, there's one more treat in store before the dawn. Down by the docks is a fastfood stand that has a queue of 30 or more people weaving and snaking its way up to the serving hatch. The name picked out in neon is Baejarins Beztu Pylsur, which at this pickled hour could translate as ram's testicles in whey, for all I know and care. Except that a friendly type has already informed me it means City's Best Hotdogs. He also tells me that this particular outlet is so popular the owner can afford to live in Florida off the proceeds (£1 a dog, and people still insist on paying with credit cards). Icelanders love their hotdogs -the secret's in the sauce, apparently, a confection peculiar to the island, called Remoladi, which tops off the usual staples of fried onions, raw onions, steaming dog, ketchup and mustard. Too much information at 4am, but a simpler and cheaper pleasure could not be more appreciated after a night on the runtur . You may find they lie a little heavy on the stomach when you emerge late morning for your next Reykjavik sortie, mind. But a dip in one of the seven naturally-heated outdoor pools within the city limits only goes to confirm why Icelanders look so good despite the ravages of the weekend runtur. That, and the fact that there's very little chlorine in the gene pool. A constitutional swim in warm geothermal spring waters and a relaxing soak in the hot pots is part of the daily routine here. Okay, so tectonic activity coupled with glaciers can have its drawbacks - three years ago the Loki volcano erupted beneath Europe's largest glacier and threatened widespread flooding along the southern coast. But there's no getting away from the fact that, all in all, Icelanders lead pretty clean and healthy lifestyles: hot water pumped straight from the ground to heat their houses and their baths; natural spring water to drink from the taps; and hydroelectric power to keep the computers up to speed with their credit-card spending. All very green. Then there's the diet: fish stocks precious enough to wage and win three cod wars with Britain and free-range lambs to make the Welsh turn green with envy. Apart from that, though, they don't mind what they eat: puffins, rotting shark and cod's chins (whoever knew they had chins?). When it comes to food, Icelanders argue that you get more for your money in terms of quantity and quality in Reykjavik than you do in London. And it's hard to contradict them when you sit down to a meal of hot smoked breast of guillemot with beetroot, cheese and pears, followed by pan-fried plaice with banana and blue cheese sauce (it works, believe me) for £25 in a restaurant as cosy as the Vid Tjornina. Chuck in dessert, wine and coffee, however, and the plastic soon comes in for another pasting. In between all the scoffing and quaffing, let's not forget that Reykjavik is one of the nine European cities of culture this year. Apparently, Iceland publishes more books per capita than any other country in the world and has the highest literacy rate. And they had a Nobel Laureate in novelist Halldór Laxness. You could do worse than take in some of the Icelandic sagas displayed on vellum at the Arni Magnusson Institute - more tales of runtur , revenge and rampage to tide you over till the next session. Then there's the bleak but powerful landscapes of artists such as Finnur Jonsson in the National Gallery, which give a pretty good indication of how apocalyptic the landscape must be just beyond the city limits. And finally there's the pièce de resistance , quite literally, in the form of the Icelandic Institute of Phallology. That's right, a penis museum. The director, Sigurdur Hjartarson, started out with a bull's penis that he used as a whip when he was a boy in the country. He has now expanded his collection to include 90 specimens. Since you ask, the smallest belonged to a field mouse and the largest to a blue whale. There's no human trophy on display as yet, though there is a written pledge on the wall beneath a picture of an 84-year-old farmer called Pall Arason. Right. So. Anybody up for a stiff drink? Reykjavik on the cheap 1 Follow the line of incoming locals after Customs and raid the booze shelves in Keflavik airport's duty-free shop. Will save you a small mortgage on the runtur . 2 Lunch lightly on lobster soup at Laekjarbrekka restaurant (Bankastraeti 2), which specialises in Icelandic cuisine. Built in 1834, this is one of the oldest houses in Reykjavik. Prices have gone up a bit since, though, and soup will set you back about £10. 3 Swim at one of the city's seven naturally-heated outdoor pools. At £1.70, they're a cheap hangover cure and a convenient alternative to the Blue Lagoon. Sundlaug vesturbaejar (Hofsvallagata) is the oldest and has the most local characters. 4 Hotdog supper. At a £1 a go, you can have several. Many outlets, but City's Best (Posthusstraeti) is the local favourite. 5 Get a Reykjavik tourist card for unlimited free bus travel and admission to public swimming pools and museums. Cards can be bought at the City Hall Information Centre, Bankastraeti 2, and from some hotels and guesthouses,£5 for one day, £7 for two. City of culture highlights Reykjavik is promoting itself under the theme of culture and nature, and events fall under the categories of water, air, fire and earth . . . to mirror the landscape. Water Futurice, August 11-13. Reykjavik makes it on to the international fashion map with a show to promote talent from Iceland, Helsinki and Bergen, with support from international designers such as Jeremy Scott. Air Voices of Europe: Björk sings with 10 choristers from each of the nine other cities of culture in Hallgrimskirkja Church, August 26 and 27. Fire Reykjavik culture night, August 19. Entering its fifth year, the festive night features outdoor concerts, performances, fireworks and fairs, late-night opening for restaurants, bars, galleries and shops. Until dawn. Earth International Festival of Literature, September 10-16. Seminars, talks and readings with prominent Icelandic and international writers (previous guests include Kurt Vonnegut, Seamus Heaney and Martin Amis). Day trips 1 Blue Lagoon. Pool of mineral-rich, geothermally-heated seawater set amid a lunar landscape 35 minutes' drive from the city. Facilities recently refurbished to the tune of $7m, but only £7 to get in. A steal and a must. 2 Golden circle tour (8 hours, £42). Takes in some of the best-known natural features - the Gullfoss waterfall, Geysir geothermal field, where the hot spring Strokkur obligingly spouts every five minutes, and Thingvellir national park - where the world's oldest parliament was established (930AD) and where the continental plates of Europe and America are slowly pulling apart. 3 Icelandic pony trekking, Hafnarfjordur, 15 minutes from the city centre. Three-hour tours cost £26, including transfers, and trot out daily from 10am and 2pm. Best bars and cafés 1 Solon Islandus (Bankastraeti 7). Entrance to the classical or jazz performances upstairs costs £10. Downstairs, it's a genteel setting for a bohemian crowd to sip coffee, wine or snack on puffin salad at £8-£9. 2 Vegamot (Vegamotastigur 4). Bistro and bar with mellow sounds and Thai chicken by day and evening, funk and salsa by night. 3 Prikid (Laugavegur) Recently refurbished but retains a traditional feel. Marvin Gaye soothes you into Saturday over a cafetiere (£3.50). 4 Kaffibarinn (Bergstadastraeti 1). Musician, writer and actor crowd (plus wannabes) form a tightly-packed clique in this clubby pub. 5 Radhuskaffi (City Hall, Tjarnargotu 11). Perfect place to contemplate the scenery and the state of your finances. Seated at water level, look out across the lake to the mountains. The practicals Icelandair (0171-874 1000, www.icelandair.co.uk) flies every day, 11 times a week from Heathrow and Glasgow. Two nights in the Leifur Eriksson hotel costs £267pp, including flights, transfers and breakfast, January- March. A two-night break staying at the art-deco Hotel Borg, including breakfast, costs £317pp.

webTitle: All is quiet on New Year's Day

fields.headline: All is quiet on New Year's Day
fields.standfirst: A roundup of the first day of the new millennium
fields.trailText: The celebrations
fields.body:
The celebrations

Britain's millennium celebrations were today declared an overwhelming success after 12 hours of momentous spectacle to greet the new century.

Prime minister Tony Blair led the praise, saying he wanted to bottle the "optimism and confidence" shown by the country as it saw in the new year with a nationwide festival of fire, light and music.

Police forces reported no major disturbances as 2.5m revellers crowded into London to watch a £1m fireworks spectacular on the stroke of midnight and millions more partied from Plymouth to Edinburgh.

Health secretary Alan Milburn praised NHS staff as "simply brilliant" after emergency services coped with a huge rise in 999 calls.

The dome

About 12,500 people went to the Millennium Dome today as London's most talked-about new landmark opened its doors to the paying public for the first time.

The crowd seemed to like what they saw, with comments ranging from "huge" and "awesome" to "very enjoyable" and "good value for money".

Queues formed at the Body zone, which is emerging as the dome's main attraction. The zone is dominated by a giant sculpture of a male figure and a female figure in a gentle reclining embrace.

All 20,000 tickets available for the dome for the next two days - Sunday and Bank Holiday Monday - have been sold.

The lottery

The National Lottery's special Big Draw 2000 created a record 18 millionaires for the New Year, Camelot confirmed today.

More than £80.5m was raised by the £5 ticket sales for the one-off game which gave players two chances to win.

In game one, where players chose six years from 1900 to 1999, two lucky ticket holders scooped £3,563,220 each. The winning years were 1901, 1918, 1950, 1958 and 1986, with 1903 the bonus year, and there were prizes for everyone matching two or more years. Game two created 16 £1m winners each of whom matched the two drawn years with those on their tickets - 1575 and 2832 -

The bug

Strong long-term planning led to a millennium bug free new year, the government said today - but warned that there could still be problems ahead.

More than £420m of government investment in recent years to prevent a millennium meltdown was "money well spent" because only a few Y2K -related incidents emerged, said Paddy Tipping, minister with responsibility for the millennium bug. However, he warned that Tuesday 4 January, when businesses return to work, could be a "critical day", and problems could also emerge on 29 February.

One of the few reported millennium bug incidents occurred at Portsmouth harbour, where a tide gauge system failed due to a computer error. The problem was quickly fixed and it did not cause any damage.

Worldwide, only a handful of Y2K-related computer glitches have been recorded.

The swim

More than 150 hardy revellers took a dip in Edinburgh's freezing Firth of Forth today. They were taking part in the 13th annual Loony Dook at South Queensferry in the shadow of the Forth Road and Rail Bridges.

A total of 162 men, women and children ran into the chilly water many of them wearing fancy dress and Jimmy hats and carrying Scotland flags. Organisers hope to raise up to £4,000 for local charities.

Ruth Usher, the organiser of the event and this year also a participant for the first time, said: "The water was absolutely freezing but it was good fun. We ran in from the beach and stayed in for about five minutes although it felt like ages."

The babies

A baby born in Dublin at one second after midnight is thought to be the first millennium baby in the British Isles.

Antoinette McGarr gave birth to her daughter, Caroline Anne, at Dublin's Coombe hospital as the city's church bells had just begun to ring in the new year.

Ms McGarr, who said she had turned down advice to call the new baby Millie in honour of the event, today received a cheque for IR£1,000 from the hospital. Britain's first millennium twins were born to Zenna and Gary Doherty, from Angus, northeast Scotland. A girl was born at five minutes past midnight, followed at 29 minutes past midnight by a boy.

The weddings

Two brides and two grooms battled to become England's first millennium couple this morning. David Hollingdrake, 47, and Alison Bully, 31, tied the knot at 8am, the earliest they were allowed to marry by law, at Liverpool town hall. At the same time at Scarborough register office Gordon Jackson and Adele Vickers were exchanging declarations of love in a ceremony timed meticulously so that the legal exchange of words coincided with the pips on BBC Radio 4.

The Prince of Wales

Prince Charles delivered the first Thought for the Day of the millennium on BBC Radio 4's Today programme. In a message which dwelt on religious and spiritual themes, the prince said: " The millennium provides us with an opportunity to abandon the poles of blind optimism on the one hand and total despair on the other, and to re-discover a much older emotion - hope."

Life is a strange paradox, the Prince said, and the art of living consists of achieving balance and harmony. Arguing that human rationality has limits, he concluded: "Perhaps, in the midst of all the celebrations and the hype, deep down inside many of us may feel intuitively - to paraphrase a wonderful passage from Dante - that the strongest desire of everything, and the one first implanted by nature, is to return to its source. And since God is the source of our souls and has made it alike unto himself... therefore this soul desires above all things to return to Him."

Read the full text of Prince Charles's Thought for the Day

webTitle: Prince Charles's Thought for the Day

fields.headline: Prince Charles's Thought for the Day
fields.standfirst: This is the full text of the Prince of Wales' Thought for the Day broadcast on Radio 4 today
fields.trailText:
I suspect many of us will have been wondering how to approach The Millennium; wondering what it actually means in the midst of our
daily lives.
fields.body:
I suspect many of us will have been wondering how to approach The Millennium; wondering what it actually means in the midst of our daily lives.

I daresay many of us will have decided what it does not mean. Will it - for instance, be an "experience" - the dawning of an exciting moment when we step boldly across a threshold marked "21st Century" and emerge into the golden, promised land of a perennial future where there shall be no more "wailing and gnashing of teeth", where water flows uphill and the whole of humanity is genetically re-engineered?

Or will it, perhaps, provide a Sacred moment of reflection as we celebrate the 2000th anniversary of that unique occurrence when "the word became flesh and dwelt among us"?

Will it remind us that each New Year represents, as did Christ's mysterious birth, a microcosm of the vital process of renewal that dominates our existence?

For although our everyday lives seem to be dominated by linear time, one day following the next and year following year in an unbroken line, each New Year reminds us of the importance in our existence of natural cycles, of events which continually recur. But, of course, there is all the difference in the world between renewing what is old and replacing old with new.

The Millennium provides us with an opportunity to abandon the poles of blind optimism on the one hand and total despair on the other, and to re-discover a much older emotion - hope.

Hope belongs to a world which recognizes the idea of limits; going with the grain of nature and cherishing, and learning, from the best of what we have inherited from the past.

In this sense, the dawn of a new millennium should not be the excuse for a bonfire of the past, but a chance to re-discover the profound wisdom of those who have made the difficult journey through this life before us; those who, like Our Lord Jesus Christ, taught that this life is but one passing phase of our existence and that the reality lies within each one of us. Or, as Rilke put it - "Death is the side of life turned away from us."

In an era when we are tempted to believe that science knows nearly all the answers it is instructive to recall that Einstein understood the close connection between wonder and the sacred.

To him the sense of wonder was the most important sense to open ourselves to the truth, the immensity of the mystery and the Divinity of ourselves and our world.

He wrote that "a person who is religiously enlightened appears to me to be one who has, to the best of his abilities, liberated himself from the fetters of his selfish desires and is preoccupied with thoughts, feelings and aspirations to which he clings because of their supra-personal value."

As we enter a new Millennium, with all its hopes and fears, I pray that we may come to realise that life is a strange paradox and that the art of living it lies in striking a balance; and that it is a sacred thing to compose harmony out of opposites.

Two and a half thousand years ago Plato was at pains to explain through the words of Timaeus that the great gift of human rationality should not be disparaged. Far from it, he said - it should be exercised to its utmost, but it must not make the mistake of believing it has no limits.

In an age of secularism, I hope with all my heart that in the new Millennium we will begin to rediscover a sense of the sacred in all that surrounds us - whether in the way we grow our crops or raise our livestock on the land that God has given us; whether in the way we create places for people to live in the countryside we have inherited; whether in the way we treat disease in our fellow human-beings; or whether in the way we educate or motivate our young people.

But to do that we must first of all understand that life is a more profound experience than we are told it is. After all, the likelihood of life beginning by chance is about as great as a hurricane blowing through a scrap yard and assembling a Rolls Royce.

Perhaps, in the midst of all the celebrations and the hype, deep down inside many of us may feel intuitively - to paraphrase a wonderful passage from Dante - that the strongest desire of everything, and the one first implanted by Nature, is to return to its source.

And since God is the source of our souls and has made it alike unto himself... therefore this soul desires above all things to return to Him.

In an age of secularism, I hope with all my heart that in the new Millennium we will begin to rediscover a sense of the sacred in all that surrounds us - whether in the way we grow our crops or raise our livestock on the land that God has given us; whether in the way we create places for people to live in the countryside we have inherited; whether in the way we treat disease in our fellow human-beings; or whether in the way we educate or motivate our young people. But to do that we must first of all understand that life is a more profound experience than we are told it is. After all, the likelihood of life beginning by chance is about as great as a hurricane blowing through a scrap yard and assembling a Rolls Royce. Perhaps, in the midst of all the celebrations and the hype, deep down inside many of us may feel intuitively - to paraphrase a wonderful passage from Dante - that the strongest desire of everything, and the one first implanted by Nature, is to return to its source. And since God is the source of our souls and has made it alike unto himself... therefore this soul desires above all things to return to Him.

webTitle: Kohl's party sets aside £2.5m to repay donations

fields.headline: Kohl's party sets aside £2.5m to repay donations
fields.trailText: Germany's Christian Democrats yesterday acknowledged for the first time that the irregular financial activities of their former leader, Helmut Kohl, could cost the party millions of pounds.
fields.body:
Germany's Christian Democrats yesterday acknowledged for the first time that the irregular financial activities of their former leader, Helmut Kohl, could cost the party millions of pounds.

A revised annual report of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU) for 1998 includes a provision in respect of "funds of as yet unknown origin" totalling DM7.3m (£2.5m). The party's financial expert, Matthias Wissmann, said the sum set aside was the "maximum amount conceivable".

Mr Kohl was this week placed under investigation in connection with secret contributions to the party during his term in office of about £680,000. The accounts released yesterday suggest that his successors at the head of the CDU know, or fear, that much larger sums are involved.

Mr Kohl, chancellor for 16 years, admitted in November that he ran secret bank accounts for undisclosed contributions to the CDU. The accounts came to light after an arms dealer claimed to have given party officials a suitcase of cash at a secret rendezvous in a Swiss car park in 1991.

The CDU leaders to whom Mr Kohl handed over following his election defeat last year have repeatedly said that they knew nothing about the origin of the money.

Both the party chairman, Wolfgang Schäuble, and its secretary-general, Angela Merkel, said they learned of the secret accounts through the media. However, the last account to be closed was shut after Mr Kohl quit as its chairman - a fact that has led some critics to question whether the new leadership was as much in the dark as it claimed.

Compounding the confusion, Mr Kohl has refused to say who gave him the money. He told a television interviewer that he had given his word of honour not to reveal the names of the donors. The degree of linkage, if any, between the Kohl era and his successors will be a key issue over the next few months as the CDU braces to fight two crucial state elections. Before the scandal, the Christian Democrats had hoped to inflict stinging losses on the ruling Social Democrats (SPD) in Schleswig-Holstein in February and in North Rhine-Westphalia in May. While the polls still show the CDU ahead, its lead has shrunk as more revelations have emerged.

Prosecutors in Bonn said this week they would investigate Mr Kohl for a suspected breach of trust in handling the CDU's finances. An all-party parliamentary committee is meanwhile poised to examine the claim that donations - secret and otherwise - influenced government decisions.

webTitle: A night to remember

fields.headline: A night to remember
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown reflects on a shambolic but very moving new year's eve
fields.trailText: How was it for you? Wild party, can't remember the details, terribly sorry   about the cigar incident, that sort of thing?
fields.body:
How was it for you? Wild party, can't remember the details, terribly sorry about the cigar incident, that sort of thing?

Join the gang. It's all a bit of a blur. Just like the coverage on BBC1, which was gloriously shambolic. Poor old Parky mumbling with embarrassment, Peter Snow in a definitive tizz over time-zones, various excited young women getting their cues utterly wrong. And now over to Paris - whoops, there's dear old Prague. Here's Jeremy Bowen in Bethlehem looking puzzled, and a Dimbleby shouting dementedly to his producer over an open microphone. Live, lingering footage of the Edinburgh beacon failing to catch light. Lots of talk about the River of Fire, travelling along the Thames at the speed of sound. Pity they didn't switch to the outside broadcast unit on time. Oh dear, it's Prague again.

It did have its moments, though. Paris - when we got to it - all but stole the show with that splendid eruption of fireworks from the Eiffel Tower. Nelson Mandela, pacing down the corridor of cells where he spent 26 years of his life, was eyestingingly dignified.

And there were reminders too, in the apologetic little news updates which broke into the endless pap of pop music and bulletins from the maternity wards, that the world and its human cargo continued to spin. We learned that the bearded halfwits on the Indian Airlines airbus in Kandahar had won their sordid little battle and that their hostages, thanks be to their various gods, were safe. We heard that enterprising thieves had half-inched a £2m Cezanne painting from the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, one and a half hours into the new millennium. Later, in the swollen-tongued dawn, we found out that waves of Russian war planes were pulverising Grozny again, reducing the Chechen capital from rubble to ash, and ripping out the guts of its cowering inhabitants.

Sick, sorry old world. And yet, and yet...

Let us give way, on this day of days, to shameless self-advertisement. This column, it happens, is hand-crafted in Chipping Norton, a small and determinedly undistinguished little market town in British West Oxfordshire. It is not a place known for extravagant behaviour or undue display of sentiment.

The bells of the parish church rang out, as advertised, and rockets soared fitfully into the night. But the town had closed down in the last mid-afternoon of the century, and apart from some heroic ticket-only goings-on in the few open pubs, it seemed that Chipping Norton had pulled its collective bedcovers over its head.

Then, as midnight approached, shadows began to move on the streets. Old people, children and in-betweens were quietly making their way to the town hall in the centre of the market place. There, assorted minor dignitaries made little civic speeches which nobody in the swelling crowd could make out. The church had fallen silent, and when the tinny municipal clock chimed the enchanted hour it had little competition save for hundreds of cheering voices. Fireworks hoarded for the moment exploded, the scarlet-decked mayor lit a portable beacon, and a middle-aged man clutching a champagne bottle stood to attention and roared out Old Lang Syne, quite alone.

It was pure, unadulterated magic; as disorganised as anything the BBC could offer, and two thousand times more spontaneous. Happy new year, everyone!

webTitle: Pope poised for his big push

fields.headline: Pope poised for his big push
fields.standfirst: Rome: Vatican fights to stamp authority on celebrations
fields.trailText: The Pope last night vowed to slice through the secular euphoria of the millennium celebrations by mobilising 1bn Catholics into a spiritual task force to lead the world in a year of repentance.
fields.body:
The Pope last night vowed to slice through the secular euphoria of the millennium celebrations by mobilising 1bn Catholics into a spiritual task force to lead the world in a year of repentance.

The stroke of midnight signalled one of the toughest fights of John Paul II's papacy: to stamp Christianity's ownership on the celebrations.

For two decades he has prepared for this moment, striving to infuse significance and wonder into the 2,000 anniversary of Christ's birth.

More than 50,000 pilgrims packed St Peter's square at midnight to hear the ailing Pope give his address from the central loggia of the newly scrubbed basilica.

More than 20m pilgrims are expected to converge on Rome during the next 12 months for the Vatican's biggest ever holy year, or jubilee.

Almost continual commemorations, celebrations and contemplations, with a mass rally every fortnight, are intended to make Rome, the focus of worldwide soul-searching.

The 79-year-old Pope has overcome numerous illnesses to defy those who had belittled the year 2000 as being little more than a mathematical curiosity.

He has declared this a time for redressing personal wrongs, especially the misdeeds of the Catholic church. He has in recent months reached out to Anglicans, Muslims, Hindus, Jews and Orthodox Christians.

Some Vatican insiders say that it is John Paul's belief that God has chosen him to lead the holy year that has kept him going. All obstacles have been batted away, sometimes controversially.

Pop concerts at the Piazza del Popolo, the Quirinale palace and St Peter's square entertained Romans, but no one was in doubt that when the champagne ran out and the music ended, then, like it or not, the coming year would belong to the pilgrims.

The spending of £1.4bn of taxpayers' money to improve roads, tunnels, bridges and rail links has spawned 700 building sites, traffic chaos, scared away more lucrative tourists and sliced up an ancient imperial villa to make way for a Vatican parking garage. Many Romans like it not.

More seriously, his efforts to lure other religions into joining the jamboree have faltered. Visits to India and Georgia in November angered Hindus and left the Orthodox church unmoved.

In the western world attendances at mass and vocations continue to slide.

Whether these forces will loosen Christianity's grip on the celebrations time will tell, but yesterday the Pope seemed invigorated as he led the century's final Te Deum during Vespers at St Peter's basilica.

The church held its first jubilee in 1300, when Pope Boniface VIII urged pilgrims to earn indulgences in Rome because wars had made it difficult to reach the holy land.

Because each Pope wanted a chance to preside over a holy year, they have been scheduled every 25 years since 1475.

Each one has been assailed by doubters who warned that war, plague, poverty or indifference would deter pilgrims and doom the jubilee.

Each time the Vatican gave the same reply: trust in providence. And providence obliged - sometimes.

webTitle: Putin bandwagon looks unstoppable now

fields.headline: Putin bandwagon looks unstoppable now
fields.standfirst: Enigmatic ex-KGB man is promising a strong state
fields.trailText: In his resignation statement yesterday, Boris Yeltsin said it was time for Russia's old guard, born and bred under communist rule, to make way for a new generation of leaders. There is no doubt that he meant the 46-year-old former spy and black belt judo aficianado who is currently breaking political box office records in Russia.
fields.body:
In his resignation statement yesterday, Boris Yeltsin said it was time for Russia's old guard, born and bred under communist rule, to make way for a new generation of leaders. There is no doubt that he meant the 46-year-old former spy and black belt judo aficianado who is currently breaking political box office records in Russia.

Vladimir Putin, the prime minister who launched a vicious war in the north Caucasus within days of taking office last August and has been reaping the political dividends ever since, already looks unassailable as Mr Yeltsin's successor.

If successful, Mr Putin, too, will go down in history as the first beneficiary of a democratic handover of the presidency in Russia. If he is elected the new Russian president on March 26, it will, staggeringly, be the first time he has ever held an elected office.

The father of two daughters and a law graduate of his native Leningrad, now St Petersburg, he spent almost 20 years in the KGB. He served mainly in Leipzig and Dresden in what was then east Germany, and has a reputation for being bright, quick, determined, and modest.

After being plucked from obscurity by the Yeltsin staff who run Russia, Mr Putin has risen by virtue of being a fresh face in a society where most people are sick of the opportunists and cronies ruling Mr Yeltsin's Russia.

"Putin is not associated with the past seven years," said an aide to the prime minister.

The contrast between the ageing, frail, part-time president in the Kremlin and the young, dynamic, hardworking prime minister in the White House that is the Moscow seat of the Russian government has worked wonders for Mr Putin and the sharp-suited marketing men who have masterminded his political ascent.

"Putin is the right guy in the right place at the right time," says Andrei Biryukov, a political consultant. "The Putin phenomenon is that he and his team have created and implemented the myth of a strong and responsible leader in Russia. It's very attractive. It's what we Russians have been pining for."

But despite the masterly salesmanship, the prime minister remains an enigma.

"Putin," the former Soviet president, Mikhail Gorbachev, said yesterday, "is not as strong as he seems because his opinions are unknown. Putin is holding on thanks to his mystery - his mysterious appearance, his mysterious glance, his mysterious phrases. But sometimes it happens that a man opens his mouth and he has nothing to say."

That sums up the prime minister's enigmatic qualities, but looks premature as an assessment of his leadership ability. While Mr Putin appears shy, he is growing into his role and also sending signals to his international peers.

For their part, Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, Gerhard Schröder and others are responding, eager to get to know Mr Putin better. A visit to Russia by Mr Blair is being organised and Mr Clinton has been invited. Putin aides also say the prime minister is being inundated with invitations from abroad.

A western diplomat who recently saw the prime minister reported an attentive, self-confident figure, quick to command his brief. It may be that Russia is about to enter a different era led by a new type of politician - managerial, competent, non-ideological. In short, a Russian version of the current western predilection for leaders like Mr Clinton, Mr Blair, and Mr Schröder.

That Mr Putin will stop at little to cement his power is evident from his ruthless prosecution of the Chechen war where Russian forces yesterday stormed villages in the south and continued to shell Grozny, the Chechen capital.

But yesterday for the first time, Mr Putin announced that he was about to turn his attention to the economy, the area in which any Russian president will ultimately be judged. "Putin definitely wants to continue the market reforms. There will be no deprivatisation or renationalisation," says the prime ministerial aide. "He's very rational and pragmatic."

Mr Putin is known to be close to Anatoly Chubais, the free marketeer who helped devise the mass privatisation and sell-offs of the 90s.

Mr Putin is also allied with the party of young economic liberals - Union of Rightwing Forces - which performed better than expected in the parliamentary elections two weeks ago and which could make a disproportionately large contribution to a new government appointed by a President Putin.

But he also appears to embody a fledgling statist ideology, a new Russian "patriotism" aimed at rebuilding a strong Russian state after the chaos and decline of the 90s.

In his most detailed policy statement to date earlier this week, Mr Putin argued for the restoration of strong statehood based not on western liberal notions but on Russian history and tradition, the tra dition of the strongman leader, whether Soviet communist or tsarist. He has already declared that there is no need to change the constitution Mr Yeltsin engineered in 1993 and which gives the president sweeping powers.

In his lengthy statement this week, Mr Putin called for a "new Russian idea" based on "patriotism, social solidarity, a strong state, and great power status".

"Our state, its institutions and structures have always played an extremely important role in the life of the country and the people. To the Russian a strong state is not an anomaly, something to fight against. On the contrary, it is the source and guarantor of order, the initiator and the main power behind all changes."

Apart from Mr Putin, the most popular of the five prime ministers Mr Yeltsin went through in the past two years has been Yevgeny Primakov, a former communist, foreign minister, and spymaster who, at the age of 70, will be hard-pressed to mount a formidable challenge to the younger man in March.

But in his new "strong state" doctrine, Mr Putin has borrowed heavily from Mr Primakov on the centre-left who favours greater regulation and state control, particularly in economic policy where the Chubais-led reforms engendered criminalisation, profiteering and corruption, in the process souring the democratic experiment for many ordinary Russians.

Mr Putin quit a career in the KGB in 1990 to return to St Petersburg where he worked in the administration of the city's liberal mayor, Anatoly Sobchak, and met several of the young group of politicians and fixers who have played such a prominent role in the new Russian politics of the 90s.

By 1996, his political star was rising when Mr Chubais, then Kremlin chief of staff, brought him to Moscow and into the Yeltsin administration.

By 1998, Mr Putin had moved on to head the FSB, the main successor to the KGB, before being made prime minister in August this year.

If the Chechen war was the first exercise aimed at having Mr Putin prove his political mettle, the prime minister's triumph came two weeks ago this weekend in the elections for the new duma, or lower house of parliament.

Again, it was an election in which Mr Putin was not standing. But the phantom party that the Kremlin insiders created in September as a parliamentary and campaign vehicle for a Putin presidency bid took almost a quarter of the vote after the prime minister endorsed it.

Then this week Mr Putin went to the founding congress of the party, Unity, in a Moscow cinema and was feted as a hero.

The question exercising the minds of pundits in Moscow last night was not so much whether Mr Putin would win the presidential election, but whether he would win outright in the first round against a predicted four opponents.

There is much that can go wrong between now and March 26, but the Russian presidency is Vladimir Putin's to lose.

webTitle: Big Macs, small horizons

fields.headline: Big Macs, small horizons
fields.standfirst: America isn't beautiful - and that's thanks largely to an avaricious clown who is the spirit of the new millennium
fields.trailText: America isn't beautiful - and that's thanks largely to an avaricious clown who is the spirit of the new millennium
fields.body:
My mother was a hypnotist for McDonald's. In 1970 one of the chain's biggest franchisees, moving millions of burgers in Hollywood, feared for their managers, who worked 15-hour shifts scattered over nights and days for little more than £2 an hour.

Some of these 'crew leaders' took on that look of insomniac spookiness that one imagines could end with one of them 'going postal', the colloquialism for what happens when the Californian penchant for self-expression meets the American fascination with automatic weapons. So my mother taught them self-hypnosis. 'Twenty minutes' trance is worth four hours' sleep!' Maybe that's why I don't eat burgers any more. I wonder about those grinning, unblinking faces, asking: 'Do you want fries with that?'

Ronald McDonald's first UK outlet opened in Woolwich, South East London, on 2 October 1974 - a quarter-century milestone that passed without commemoration recently.

But we shouldn't enter the new millennium without acknowledging that McDonald's significance consists of far more than caterers to the Dome.

To residents of Montparnasse and Hampstead, McDonald's heralds the Bozo-headed déclassé Americanisation of Europe. But to me, it represents something far more sinister: the Americanisation of America. This is my last Inside America column for a while, so I have to get this off my chest: America is ugly.

A conspiracy of British travel writers has sold the image of America the Beautiful: Georgia O'Keefe sunsets over New Mexico's plateau, the wide-open vistas of the Grand Canyon. But to get there, you must drive through a numbing, repetitive vortex of Pizza Hut, Wal-Mart, K-Mart, The Gap, Kentucky Fried Chicken, Starbucks and McDonald's. All the separate tastes - New Orleans jambalaya, Harlem ham hocks, New England crab boil - the uniqueness of region and town have been hunted and herded into a few tourist preserves. The oppressive ubiquity of contrived American monoculture has ingested and eliminated any threat of character. The words of McDonald's late chief executive Ray Kroc - 'We cannot trust some people who are nonconformists' - have become our national anthem.

Almost. One hundred miles dead east of New York City, a hamlet of farmers called Southold held out. Southold was the last place in New York State where you could look from a rolling road across an open cornfield uninterrupted by Golden Arches. The town board refused McDonald's request to build. 'Just not part of our rural character,' it said. A group of visiting English land-use experts had planted the un-American idea of 'stewardship' trumping property rights. In Britain, these battles are common stuff - last month 40 mothers and children in Harrow, north London, marched against conversion of the Hungry Horse pub into yet another Avaricious Clown, but in the States 'Tiny town resists' was national news.

Southold's rebellion lasted six years. Then McDonald's threatened law suits, and Southold - my town - bowed down. Today, Southold schools take students on 'educational' outings to McDonald's.

This McDonald's story is my contribution to the Big Bubble debate. A whole gaggle of pressroom Chicken Lickens has issued apocalyptic warnings about the huge speculative rise in share prices that must soon burst and spew financial fire, brimstone and bankruptcies.

But stay calm. The sky is not falling. The Bubble Theorem is the creation of good-hearted souls of the Left, made ill by the orgy of monstrous increases in wealth for a few and begging bowls for the many. The world's 300 richest men are worth more than the world's poorest 3 billion. They believe the stock market cannot rise indefinitely on the promises of dot.coms that sell nothing, yet lay claim to a large share of the planet's wealth. The Guardian's Larry Elliot sermonises about the 'day of reckoning'.

But this belief that a price must be paid is religion, not economics - Calvinism in Marxist clothing. What the Left fails to accept is that the class war, as Messrs Blair and Clinton tell us, is over - not because we have reached a happy social entente, but because the working class has been defeated soundly, convincingly, absolutely.

Dr Edward Wolff, director of the Income Studies Project at the Jerome Levy Institute in New York, will soon report that between 1983 and 1997, 85.5 per cent of the vaunted increase in America's wealth was captured by the richest 1 per cent of the population. In that time, the country's income rocketed - yet 80 per cent of American families received 0 per cent of that increase. The market's up, but who is the market? The gilded 1 per cent owns $2.9 trillion of US stocks and bonds out of a total $3.5 billion, says Wolff.

By no coincidence at all, the rise in the riches of the rich matches quite well the wealth lost by production workers through their falling share of the productivity captured by wages. US workers produced more per hour (up 17 per cent since 1983) while keeping less of it (down 3.1 per cent). The market is not rising on a bubble of fictions but on the rock-hard foundation of the spoils of the class war.

What's going on? Forget Robert Reich's sweet notion that computers can make work more meaningful. The purpose of every industrial revolution, from the steam-powered loom to the assembly line, is to make skills obsolete, and people interchangeable and cheap. And now, computerisation is speeding the industrialisation of service work.

That brings us back to McDonald's. While Kroc gets the kudos for building the company, it was the genius of the brothers McDonald - Richard and Maurice - in 1948 to divide the production of restaurant food into discrete, skill-less tasks and methodically, ruthlessly apply to the corner greasy spoon the time and motion paradigm that rules factory assembly lines. No more cooks. Any clown can make a hamburger for McDonald's. Their machines are designed so that unskilled workers can reach full speed on any job in minutes. Your Prime Minister believes computers will spawn a Knowledge Economy. Oh, yeah. At McD's, you can spend all day punching machine-portioned glops of ketchup on to burger buns.

The Observer has learnt that McDonald's has retained the notorious union-busting law firm, Jackson Lewis of New York (which is now seeking work in the UK). But why should McDonald's bother? Fast food operators' employee turnover averages 300 per cent a year - and, whatever it says, the industry must love it. Workers out of the door in four months don't demand pensions, promotions, training or unions.

In 1996, the McLibel court in London found that the company depressed the pay of young workers in the catering trade in Britain. But that is temporary. It won't be long before workers of all ages in all industries will need no more experience than any 17-year-old slacker - and be paid like one.

It is estimated that one in eight American adults has worked at a McDonald's. It acts as a kind of moral instruction for the working class, like jail time in the ghetto. It is one reason behind America's low unemployment rate. As my old professor, Milton Friedman, taught me, unemployment falls when workers give up hope of higher pay.

How fitting that the Battle of Seattle began when crazies threw a rubbish bin through the window of a McDonald's. The question is, will it break the trance?

webTitle: Why short hems raised PM's hackles

fields.headline: Why short hems raised PM's hackles
fields.standfirst:
Fury at grant for mini-skirt 'research'
Public records office documents of 1969
fields.trailText: The swinging sixties were forever associated with the mini-skirt - but it was not just the sight of bare female legs which caused male temperatures to rise.
fields.body:
The swinging sixties were forever associated with the mini-skirt - but it was not just the sight of bare female legs which caused male temperatures to rise.

The prime minister, Harold Wilson, saw red when he discovered the government was funding research into why men preferred women in short dresses.

It all started with an article in the Guardian which reported that a Dr K Gibbins of Newcastle university had obtained a £1,432 social science research council grant to study fashion statements, specifically "why do girls raise hemlines?".

Files released to the public record office show Wilson an grily demanded a review of such research funding.

Dr Gibbins had told reporters that he was planning to send questionnaires to 15-year-old schoolgirls because they were "at a crucial age for fashion acceptance".

When a furious Wilson demanded an explanation, an education department official hurriedly wrote to Downing Street insisting that press reports that the project was about the appeal of women in mini-skirts were "well wide of the mark" and that it had a serious academic purpose.

But his reply did nothing to placate the prime minister. "If this is so valuable to these vast industries why do they not pay for it?" he demanded in a handwritten note scrawled across the letter. "How did this get to the press? His PR suggests he is a very odd and extrovert character."

Egged on by his Downing Street staff, Wilson ordered a review of the entire SSRC funding list.
