webTitle: The way we are and the way we were

fields.headline: The way we are and the way we were
fields.standfirst: A look at statistics shows how much our lives have changed in the past 100 years
fields.trailText: A look at statistics shows how much our lives have changed in the past 100 years
fields.body:
A century of dark or light? Revisionists have lately been emphasising the 20th century's volume of death and destruction but even here, among the body counts, progress has to be recognised. We now know so much more about other societies, the past, especially - the British Institute of Public Opinion (later Gallup) was established in 1937 - ourselves. Never, to coin a phrase, has so much been known about so many.

What we don't know, we can find out by phone (3,000 in the UK in 1900, 32.6m now) and thanks to expanded publishers' lists (even today's depleted English public libraries have 30 times the 4.4m volumes stocked in 1906).

The capacity for transmitting and acquiring knowledge has exploded through television and telecommunication invented since 1900. And education. In 1902 only 9% of English and Welsh 14-year-olds received full-time schooling; the 20,000 UK students who attended university have become 1.2m; approaching half of all 18-year-olds continue in some form of advanced study.

Of course most indices across the century point upwards. More people live in these islands, as on every other land mass around the globe. So we live more densely - though not in Scotland. We travel around more, driving 26.2m cars against 15,900 in 1905. The urban area of England and Wales has doubled though the proportion of total population living in cities has not changed much.

We own more. Material possessions abound because the economy has grown - though real GDP per head did not begin its spectacular upwards trajectory till the late 40s. For all the vicissitudes of depression and unemployment, numbers of jobs have grown to provide work for a workforce which grew from 16.3m (1901, Great Britain) to 28m. Meanwhile average output per employee has tripled.

Among the fruits of that growth, nearly seven in 10 households now own their own homes compared with one in 10 in 1914. Entire categories of goods and services, holidays to domestic appliances, have been created. Average hours worked have fallen but in Britain far less spectacularly than on the Continent.

Some of the new leisure is spent on collective life. We are more democratic: 1900's electorate of 6.7m excluded women and most of the working class; today 40m citizens aged over 18 have the right to vote.

As a society, we are healthier, longer lived and more sober - in 1900 a fifth of consumers' spending went on alcohol, now it is about a fourteenth. We are more managerial or managed, depending on viewpoint, with some 7m workers now classed as professional executives. Whether the UK is more European may be politically controversial but it is an economic fact that trade with mainland Europe at 53% of total trade is well above 1900's 37%.

Who "we" are has changed. At the last census, 500,000 people were labelled as Black Caribbean and 840,000 Indian. In 1901 8,680 were registered as having been born in the West Indies and 55,362 in India and Ceylon. The largest group then living in England and Wales but not born there were Irish.

The numerical preponderance of women has fallen - in 1900 there were more women than men in all age groups - but women are now a formidable economic presence outside the home. In 1911, 35% of women were employed; now 71%. Those changes are paralleled by declining family size and later child-bearing.

The growth of women earners reflects labour market changes, notably the rise of services and associated part-time employment and the decline of manufacturing. Farming now supplies 1.1% of all jobs against 8.1% in 1911, when a similar proportion was employed in mining and quarrying. Today's manufacturing labour force (17.5%) is just over half 1911's. Manufacturing's decline has cut collective bargaining. In 1900 the Trades Union Congress had 1.25 members and 184 affiliated unions. It waxed then waned and now has 6.75m in 76 unions.

Some things do not change much over time - the rate at which the appeal court overturns lower courts, for instance, and the proportion of UK total trade that is carried on with the US (about 12%).

Nor has everything grown. At 376,000, the Labour Party's 1900 membership is about the same as its (individual) membership today - though it did grow to over a million individual members in 1950. Whitehall has shrunk. 1900's civil service numbered 779,520 against today's 490,000, although government does occupy a much higher proportion of economic and social space. In 1900 the standard rate of income tax was 8 old pence in the pound - 2%. To spend the extra tax revenue, the size of the cabinet has grown by three from the 19 members it had in 1900 and the number of MPs on the government's "payroll vote", key indicator of executive dominance in the legislature, has tripled.

Now and then

 Communication In 1900 there were 3,000 telephones in the UK, today there are 32.6m

Education In 1902 only 9% of English and Welsh 14-year-olds received full-time schooling. Today half of all 18-year-olds are in further education

 Transport There are now 26.2m cars in the UK, compared with 15,900 in 1905

 Democracy 1900's electorate of 6.7m excluded women and most of the working class; today 40m citizens aged over 18 have the right to vote

Health In 1900 a fifth of consumers' spending went on alcohol, now it is about a fourteenth

 Europe Trade with Europe at 53% of total trade is well above 1900's 37%

Ethnicity At the last census, 500,000 people were labelled as Black Caribbean and 840,000 Indian. In 1901, 8,680 were born in the West Indies and 55,362 in India and Ceylon

 Industry Today's manufacturing labour force (17.5%) is just over half that in 1911

 Tax In 1900 the standard rate of income tax was 8 old pence in the pound (2%). Today it is 23%

Marriage and divorce

 on average over half the population of Great Britain aged 16 and over is married
 there are four times as many widows as widowers
 on average there are 310,000 marriages a year in the UK
 on average there are 161,100 divorces a year in the UK
 it is estimated that there are 1.6 million cohabiting couples in England and Wales

Health and fitness

 on average there are 10 deaths a day in the UK caused by accidents in the home
 on average there are 9 deaths on the road a day in the UK
 on average 2,760 child pedestrians a year are killed or injured alongside Britain's roads during the two months after the clocks go back in October
 there are an estimated 13 million smokers in Britain
 on average 328 people die each day in Britain from smoking related illnesses
 on average 450 children (under 16s) take up smoking each day in the UK
 an estimated 40,000 deaths a year are alcohol related
 there are approximately 16,000 cases of Aids in the UK
 there are approximately 33,800 cases of HIV in the UK
 solvent misuse accounts for approximately one in 50 of all deaths among teenagers between the ages of 15 and 19
 there are approximately 6,500 cases of TB a year in the UK, compared with nearly 50,000 in 1950
 on average 14,000 women die from breast cancer each year; one in 10 women will develop it
 approximately 20% of women and 17% of men aged 16 and over in England are obese
 around 1.2 million people in the UK go to a hospital casualty department each year as a result of an accidental fall
 approximately 43,000 people experience falls from ladders each year in the UK
 on average there are 717,000 live births a year in the UK
 almost 38% of all births occur outside marriage in the UK
 on average there are about 628,000 deaths a year in the UK
 on average there are 177,332 legal abortions per year in England and Wales; that is 13.8 abortions for every 1,000 women aged 14 to 49
 the conception rate for girls under the age of 16 is 8.9 per 1,000 women
 approximately 57,500 oral contraceptive pills are distributed to women through family planning associations daily worldwide
 approximately 258,000 condoms are distributed through family planning associations daily
 malaria kills one child every 30 seconds
 on average 1,644 women die worldwide every day as a consequence of pregnancy and childbirth
 on average 10,958 people die each day in the world from smoking-related illnesses
 33.4 million people worldwide are infected with Aids/HIV

The environment

 the UK contributes about 2% to world man-made carbon dioxide emissions each year, approximately 6,000-8,000 tonnes
 on average 5 million steel cans are recycled every day of the year
 from today leaded fuel will not be on general sale in the EU. Approx 6.5m cars still use it
 on average in Britain, 2.2 million tonnes of newsprint are recycled every year
 12.3427 trillion kWh of electricity are used worldwide every year
 the average global surface temperature has risen 1F since the turn of the century, while sea levels have risen between four and 10 inches
 the hottest 12 years ever recorded have all been since 1980
 there are an estimated 1,743 threatened or endangered species on the planet, where endangered means in danger of extinction, and threatened means likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future

Transport

 there are an estimated 646,759,108 motor vehicles on the road in the world, a third of which are in the US
 there are a total of 31,069,785 vehicles on the road in the UK
 there are 26,268,802 cars on the road in the UK
 there are 549,363 lorries on the road in the UK
 there are 86,711 buses and coaches on the road in the UK
 there are 37,591 taxis on the road in the UK

Consumption and waste

 185 million cups of tea are consumed each day in the UK
 there are 4 million vegetarians in Britain (7%)
 the volume of waste produced over a year in the UK is 27 million tonnes
 every day approximately 80 million food and drink cans end up in landfill: that is one and a half cans for each person
 over 9 million disposable nappies are used in Britain every day, accounting for 4% of household waste
 on average 5 million steel cans are recycled every day of the year
 alcohol is consumed by over 90% of the adult population of the UK
 there are an estimated 1.3 billion smokers in the world
 in developing countries 900 million men smoke, compared with 100 million women
 an estimated 5,609 billion cigarettes are smoked in the world per year, compared with 1,686 billion in 1950

Technology

 there are 32.636 million telephone exchange lines in the UK
 63% of British households own a CD player
 a fifth of households in the UK own at least one mobile phone
 one in four British households own a home computer
 there are approximately 2.183 billion radio receivers worldwide, with 514 million in Europe
 there are 1.361 billion television receivers worldwide with 322 million in Europe
 there are an estimated 43 million internet hosts worldwide, with 200 million internet users
 there are about 190 million mobile phone users worldwide

Religion

UK church membership:
 Christian - approx 7 million
 Hindu - approx 155,000
 Jewish - approx 94,000
 Muslim - approx 580,000
 Sikh - approx 350,000
 Others - approx 116,000

As a society, we are healthier, longer lived and more sober - in 1900 a fifth of consumers' spending went on alcohol, now it is about a fourteenth. We are more managerial or managed, depending on viewpoint, with some 7m workers now classed as professional executives. Whether the UK is more European may be politically controversial but it is an economic fact that trade with mainland Europe at 53% of total trade is well above 1900's 37%. Who "we" are has changed. At the last census, 500,000 people were labelled as Black Caribbean and 840,000 Indian. In 1901 8,680 were registered as having been born in the West Indies and 55,362 in India and Ceylon. The largest group then living in England and Wales but not born there were Irish. The numerical preponderance of women has fallen - in 1900 there were more women than men in all age groups - but women are now a formidable economic presence outside the home. In 1911, 35% of women were employed; now 71%. Those changes are paralleled by declining family size and later child-bearing. The growth of women earners reflects labour market changes, notably the rise of services and associated part-time employment and the decline of manufacturing. Farming now supplies 1.1% of all jobs against 8.1% in 1911, when a similar proportion was employed in mining and quarrying. Today's manufacturing labour force (17.5%) is just over half 1911's. Manufacturing's decline has cut collective bargaining. In 1900 the Trades Union Congress had 1.25 members and 184 affiliated unions. It waxed then waned and now has 6.75m in 76 unions. Whitehall has shrunk. 1900's civil service numbered 779,520 against today's 490,000, although government does occupy a much higher proportion of economic and social space. In 1900 the standard rate of income tax was 8 old pence in the pound - 2%. To spend the extra tax revenue, the size of the cabinet has grown by three from the 19 members it had in 1900 and the number of MPs on the government's "payroll vote", key indicator of executive dominance in the legislature, has tripled. webTitle: Sydney harbour first to light up

fields.headline: Sydney harbour first to light up
fields.trailText: In Australia, the first country to encounter the millennium, Sydney harbour bridge was lit up in lights with the word Eternity - as scrawled in chalk on the city's streets for nearly 40 years by a reformed petty criminal who died in 1967.
fields.body:
In Australia, the first country to encounter the millennium, Sydney harbour bridge was lit up in lights with the word Eternity - as scrawled in chalk on the city's streets for nearly 40 years by a reformed petty criminal who died in 1967.

It's five not two, says China

President Jiang Zemin welcomed the new year in Beijing by saying China had seen five millennia come and go. He lit a flame at a monument to "five thousand years of history" the Chinese nation had existed.

Year of Dragon for Japan

In Japan, millions headed to Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines to wish for good fortune in the Year of the Dragon.

Tragic start in Philippines

Filipinos welcomed the millennium with gunfire and fireworks. Two people were killed by stray bullets and a five-year-old died after being struck in the face by a firecracker. Another 200 were injured in and around Manila.

Submarine's dateline date

The USS Topeka saw in the millennium submerged in the Pacific and straddling the international dateline, meaning that at midnight half the crew was in 2000 while the other half was in 1999. "It's better than Times Square," said Lt Michael Bratton.

French PM calls off his party

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, cancelled his new year's eve party in sympathy with some 2m of hiscountrymen without electricity or phone after storms killed 83 this week.

webTitle: A snapshot of the world today

fields.headline: A snapshot of the world today
fields.trailText: World population 6 billion
fields.body:
World population 6 billion

3000 million are under the age of 25

960 million illiterate adults worldwide (two thirds are female)

766.6 million live in Africa

190 million have mobile phones

66 million are over the age of 80

33.4 million are infected with Aids/HIV

UK Population 59.2 million

16 million are over the age of 65

13 millionsmoke

11 million are under the age of 25

5.1 million live in Scotland

4 million are vegetarians

4.9 million are divorced and have not remarried

Marriage and divorce

 on average over half the population of Great Britain aged 16 and over is married

 there are four times as many widows as widowers

 on average there are 310,000 marriages a year in the UK

 on average there are 161,100 divorces a year in the UK

 it is estimated that there are 1.6 million cohabiting couples in England and Wales

Health and fitness

 on average there are 10 deaths a day in the UK caused by accidents in the home

 on average there are 9 deaths on the road a day in the UK

 on average 2,760 child pedestrians a year are killed or injured alongside Britain's roads during the two months after the clocks go back in October

 there are an estimated 13 million smokers in Britain

 on average 328 people die each day in Britain from smoking related illnesses

 on average 450 children (under 16s) take up smoking each day in the UK

 an estimated 40,000 deaths a year are alcohol related

 there are approximately 16,000 cases of Aids in the UK

 there are approximately 33,800 cases of HIV in the UK

 solvent misuse accounts for approximately one in 50 of all deaths among teenagers between the ages of 15 and 19

 there are approximately 6,500 cases of TB a year in the UK, compared with nearly 50,000 in 1950

 on average 14,000 women die from breast cancer each year; one in 10 women will develop it

 approximately 20% of women and 17% of men aged 16 and over in England are obese

 around 1.2 million people in the UK go to a hospital casualty department each year as a result of an accidental fall

 approximately 43,000 people experience falls from ladders each year in the UK

 on average there are 717,000 live births a year in the UK

 almost 38% of all births occur outside marriage in the UK

 on average there are about 628,000 deaths a year in the UK

 on average there are 177,332 legal abortions per year in England and Wales; that is 13.8 abortions for every 1,000 women aged 14 to 49

 the conception rate for girls under the age of 16 is 8.9 per 1,000 women

 approximately 57,500 oral contraceptive pills are distributed to women through family planning associations daily worldwide

 approximately 258,000 condoms are distributed through family planning associations daily

 malaria kills one child every 30 seconds

 on average 1,644 women die worldwide every day as a consequence of pregnancy and childbirth

 on average 10,958 people die each day in the world from smoking-related illnesses

 33.4 million people worldwide are infected with Aids/HIV

The environment

 the UK contributes about 2% to world man-made carbon dioxide emissions each year, approximately 6,000-8,000 tonnes

 on average 5 million steel cans are recycled every day of the year

 from today leaded fuel will not be on general sale in the EU. Approx 6.5m cars still use it

 on average in Britain, 2.2 million tonnes of newsprint are recycled every year

 12.3427 trillion kWh of electricity are used worldwide every year

 the average global surface temperature has risen 1F since the turn of the century, while sea levels have risen between four and 10 inches

 the hottest 12 years ever recorded have all been since 1980

 there are an estimated 1,743 threatened or endangered species on the planet, where endangered means in danger of extinction, and threatened means likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future

Transport

 there are an estimated 646,759,108 motor vehicles on the road in the world, a third of which are in the US

 there are a total of 31,069,785 vehicles on the road in the UK

 there are 26,268,802 cars on the road in the UK

 there are 549,363 lorries on the road in the UK

 there are 86,711 buses and coaches on the road in the UK

 there are 37,591 taxis on the road in the UK

Consumption and waste

 185 million cups of tea are consumed each day in the UK

 there are 4 million vegetarians in Britain (7%)

 the volume of waste produced over a year in the UK is 27 million tonnes

 every day approximately 80 million food and drink cans end up in landfill: that is one and a half cans for each person

 over 9 million disposable nappies are used in Britain every day, accounting for 4% of household waste

 on average 5 million steel cans are recycled every day of the year

 alcohol is consumed by over 90% of the adult population of the UK

 there are an estimated 1.3 billion smokers in the world

 in developing countries 900 million men smoke, compared with 100 million women

 an estimated 5,609 billion cigarettes are smoked in the world per year, compared with 1,686 billion in 1950

Technology

 there are 32.636 million telephone exchange lines in the UK

 63% of British households own a CD player

 a fifth of households in the UK own at least one mobile phone

 one in four British households own a home computer

 there are approximately 2.183 billion radio receivers worldwide, with 514 million in Europe

 there are 1.361 billion television receivers worldwide with 322 million in Europe

 there are an estimated 43 million internet hosts worldwide, with 200 million internet users

 there are about 190 million mobile phone users worldwide

Religion

UK church membership:

 Christian - approx 7 million

 Hindu - approx 155,000

 Jewish - approx 94,000

 Muslim - approx 580,000

 Sikh - approx 350,000

 Others - approx 116,000

Sources: Wastewatch, WWF, United Nations, RoSPA, Office for National Statistics, International Planned Parenthood Association, The Vegetarian Society, ASH, World Health Organisation, Oftel

webTitle: Birth, life and death - the world's joys and sorrows begin anew

fields.headline: Birth, life and death - the world's joys and sorrows begin anew
fields.standfirst: Millennium briefs
fields.trailText: It's five not two, says China
fields.body:
It's five not two, says China

President Jiang Zemin welcomed the New Year in Beijing by saying China had seen five millennia come and go. He lit a flame at a monument to "five thousand years of history" the Chinese nation had existed.

Year of Dragon for Japan

In Japan, millions headed to Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines to wish for good fortune in the Year of the Dragon.

Tragic start in Philippines

Filipinos welcomed the millennium with gunfire and fireworks. Two celebrants were killed by stray bullets and a five-year-old died after being struck in the face by an exploding firecracker. Another 200 were injured in Manila.

Pyramids turned green for opera

Green floodlights bathed the pyramids of Giza as an electronic opera by Jean-Michel Jarre, Twelve Dreams of the Sun, began Egypt's millennium show.

Submarine's date with destiny

The submarine USS Topeka saw in the millennium submerged in the Pacific and straddling both the international date line and the equator, meaning that at midnight one half of the crew was in 2000 while the other was still in 1999, and one half was in summer and one in winter. "It's better than Times Square," said Lt Michael Bratton.

And one who missed it all

It's nearly impossible to miss millennium celebrations. But not if you are on your own deep below ground in a dark cave in southern France.

Explorer Michel Siffre has been underground for more than a month with no means of telling time, leading him to think that yesterday was December 27, his support team reported.

webTitle: Where sands of desert and time conspire, all they can do is hope

fields.headline: Where sands of desert and time conspire, all they can do is hope
fields.standfirst: Timbuktu The hype has reached even this most remote of cities
fields.trailText: We found Sidi Mohammed just a few hours before midnight. He, his sons, grandsons and 75-camel caravan were 15 days from the saltmines in the middle of the Sahara desert, and hours from Timbuktu.
fields.body:
We found Sidi Mohammed just a few hours before midnight. He, his sons, grandsons and 75-camel caravan were 15 days from the saltmines in the middle of the Sahara desert, and hours from Timbuktu.

We were the first people they had seen in days and a welcome diversion from the monotony of sand and rock.

But for the camels being reloaded with slabs of salt for the last leg of the 650-mile journey, our arrival in a Japanese 4-wheel drive was the last straw. A great roar filled one of the emptiest places on earth. It started as a low moan, became an angry neck-shaking shriek and ended in a groan, like 75 foul drains disgorging into a great sewer. The end of the world for cameldom.

"Happy new year," we said, offering bags of sugar, rice and dried fruit to the camel herdsmen.

Sidi considered us. Yes, he said, it had been a very good year. The price of salt was high. The family had prospered. No-one had died. The desert was hotter now than in his father's day and there was less food for the camels. But he was happy that the new year was here and he hoped he could celebrate. Tonight, he said, stuffing an ancient metal pipe with the best Mauretanian tobacco, they would (God willing) be in Timbuktu. There would be music and dancing.

Even in Timbuktu, Mali, a byword for remoteness, isolation and mystery, the millennium is being celebrated. For the past three years, Ramadan (the Islamic month of fasting) and the Christian new year have coincided, merging the two most important times in both religions.

The millennium has not always been kind to the city. The Niger river has shifted 15 miles north, the sands dunes are at the gates and at least one of the mosques is being buried. There is more sand on the streets than on most British beaches, sand in the shops, in the food, in the bedrooms and in the hair.

The days when Timbuktu was a centre of African trade and Islamic learning are over and it is now one of the remotest places in one of the three poorest countries in the world. Most people are unemployed and the average wage is less than a dollar a day. There may be great pride in the tolerance of so many tribes living in the city, but there are still slaves, still the most dreadful persecutions.

But a sense of mystery remains. What, for example, has happened to the 150 Italian tourists who arrived on a charter flight on Thursday afternoon to celebrate the millennium? They have no rooms and are not expected to enjoy two nights with the mosquitoes in the main square.

Timbuktu has become a place of the European imagination, but the reality is sometimes too much. A party of French pensioners has all but drunk one hotel dry, and now the 75 US Peace Corps volunteers in Mali have floated in on a river boat . They were last seen being led by a tribesman towards the dunes.

"Are there showers and modern toilets in the desert?" asked an elderly French woman who had been told to live in a tent outside the city for the duration.

"I don't know," replied Omar, her camel-driving "hotelier" for the night. "It's possible, madam."

Timbuktu, bypassed for most of the past 500 years, cannot handle the invasion, but it is Christmas for the one travel agency, the few official guides, the children and many shopkeepers. Cigarettes were expected to run out and were increasing in price by the hour. A herbalist who normally deals in snake oil and potency cures was offering to cure la fièvre 2000. The largest hotel sent to the capital, Bamako, for Christmas decorations.

The price of a bottle of champagne last night was frightening, but one Englishman at least hoped to pay for his passage home by selling one to the mayor of a French town who had just arrived.

For others the millennium was a Christian feast of capitalism and consumerism carried on a westerly wind, and the only thing to do was to duck till it passed.

Mohammed Ali Cham, inspector general of the Arabic language in Mali and iman of a mosque in Bamako, has condemned the celebrations. He has spent the past month preaching against the influx of western consumerism and the influences which he believes may destroy a society where most people have no context in which to place such values.

"[The Malian state] cannot stop the millennium celebrations. We are being colonised by the Christians. If we try to stop them, the World Bank and IMF will cut the money and say we are not democratic. They will paint us as intolerant and call us terrorists," he said.

"The [Muslim] state has to sell its dignity for money. If you take their money, you get Christianity too. The west knows we are the poorest, so they send their Christian emissaries like Save the Children. And rather than colonise us with guns, they divert us now with television."

"This millennium is really nothing. It is of no consequence to us. It is like every other day and every other moment. It is like a breath of wind in the desert."

But there have been few other objections to the tourists and the celebrations in Timbuktu, where the visitors are considered heaven-sent, to be exploited like the salt from the Sahara.

One note of dissent has come from a group of radical students at the Muslim university who want to "clean up" the town's traditional tolerance of animism and other faiths.

For the young American couple and their children with the Baptist mission outside the town, the millennium gave them time to reflect that in more than 18 years spent helping the nomadic Tuareg learn to grow vegetables in the sands, their mission had yet to convert one person to Christianity. "We will pray tonight, go out into the desert and contemplate", said Peter Wing.

Outside Timbuktu, on the Niger, the communities of fishermen and boatmen were preparing to mark the new year last night with a simple meal of rice and yams.

As night fell, the great Boulkassim Tigampo 2000, a 30 metre, two storey riverboat, was loading up for the three day journey to Mopti. Aboard were displaced people from Senegal and Mauretania, others who had found no work in Timbuktu and were moving on to try their luck elsewhere, tradesmen, pregnant women, tribesmen and farmers. Under a canopy fashioned from a United Nations tarpaulin, they all said that the new year was important, but that they had no means to celebrate.

"Our grandparents would not have celebrated this time. But we are now in contact with people from all over. So we know that the world is greater now," said Omar Kontar, a village chief.

"These boats are like our life, this river is our road," said Mohammed, an illiterate ferryman. "People marry on board, they die, they are born. Tonight, the new year, we will tell stories and hope for better times."
fields.bodyText: We found Sidi Mohammed just a few hours before midnight. He, his sons, grandsons and 75-camel caravan were 15 days from the saltmines in the middle of the Sahara desert, and hours from Timbuktu. We were the first people they had seen in days and a welcome diversion from the monotony of sand and rock. But for the camels being reloaded with slabs of salt for the last leg of the 650-mile journey, our arrival in a Japanese 4-wheel drive was the last straw. A great roar filled one of the emptiest places on earth. It started as a low moan, became an angry neck-shaking shriek and ended in a groan, like 75 foul drains disgorging into a great sewer. The end of the world for cameldom. "Happy new year," we said, offering bags of sugar, rice and dried fruit to the camel herdsmen. Sidi considered us. Yes, he said, it had been a very good year. The price of salt was high. The family had prospered. No-one had died. The desert was hotter now than in his father's day and there was less food for the camels. But he was happy that the new year was here and he hoped he could celebrate. Tonight, he said, stuffing an ancient metal pipe with the best Mauretanian tobacco, they would (God willing) be in Timbuktu. There would be music and dancing. Even in Timbuktu, Mali, a byword for remoteness, isolation and mystery, the millennium is being celebrated. For the past three years, Ramadan (the Islamic month of fasting) and the Christian new year have coincided, merging the two most important times in both religions. The millennium has not always been kind to the city. The Niger river has shifted 15 miles north, the sands dunes are at the gates and at least one of the mosques is being buried. There is more sand on the streets than on most British beaches, sand in the shops, in the food, in the bedrooms and in the hair. The days when Timbuktu was a centre of African trade and Islamic learning are over and it is now one of the remotest places in one of the three poorest countries in the world. Most people are unemployed and the average wage is less than a dollar a day. There may be great pride in the tolerance of so many tribes living in the city, but there are still slaves, still the most dreadful persecutions. But a sense of mystery remains. What, for example, has happened to the 150 Italian tourists who arrived on a charter flight on Thursday afternoon to celebrate the millennium? They have no rooms and are not expected to enjoy two nights with the mosquitoes in the main square. Timbuktu has become a place of the European imagination, but the reality is sometimes too much. A party of French pensioners has all but drunk one hotel dry, and now the 75 US Peace Corps volunteers in Mali have floated in on a river boat . They were last seen being led by a tribesman towards the dunes. "Are there showers and modern toilets in the desert?" asked an elderly French woman who had been told to live in a tent outside the city for the duration. "I don't know," replied Omar, her camel-driving "hotelier" for the night. "It's possible, madam." Timbuktu, bypassed for most of the past 500 years, cannot handle the invasion, but it is Christmas for the one travel agency, the few official guides, the children and many shopkeepers. Cigarettes were expected to run out and were increasing in price by the hour. A herbalist who normally deals in snake oil and potency cures was offering to cure la fièvre 2000. The largest hotel sent to the capital, Bamako, for Christmas decorations. The price of a bottle of champagne last night was frightening, but one Englishman at least hoped to pay for his passage home by selling one to the mayor of a French town who had just arrived. For others the millennium was a Christian feast of capitalism and consumerism carried on a westerly wind, and the only thing to do was to duck till it passed. Mohammed Ali Cham, inspector general of the Arabic language in Mali and iman of a mosque in Bamako, has condemned the celebrations. He has spent the past month preaching against the influx of western consumerism and the influences which he believes may destroy a society where most people have no context in which to place such values. "[The Malian state] cannot stop the millennium celebrations. We are being colonised by the Christians. If we try to stop them, the World Bank and IMF will cut the money and say we are not democratic. They will paint us as intolerant and call us terrorists," he said. "The [Muslim] state has to sell its dignity for money. If you take their money, you get Christianity too. The west knows we are the poorest, so they send their Christian emissaries like Save the Children. And rather than colonise us with guns, they divert us now with television." "This millennium is really nothing. It is of no consequence to us. It is like every other day and every other moment. It is like a breath of wind in the desert." But there have been few other objections to the tourists and the celebrations in Timbuktu, where the visitors are considered heaven-sent, to be exploited like the salt from the Sahara. One note of dissent has come from a group of radical students at the Muslim university who want to "clean up" the town's traditional tolerance of animism and other faiths. For the young American couple and their children with the Baptist mission outside the town, the millennium gave them time to reflect that in more than 18 years spent helping the nomadic Tuareg learn to grow vegetables in the sands, their mission had yet to convert one person to Christianity. "We will pray tonight, go out into the desert and contemplate", said Peter Wing. Outside Timbuktu, on the Niger, the communities of fishermen and boatmen were preparing to mark the new year last night with a simple meal of rice and yams. As night fell, the great Boulkassim Tigampo 2000, a 30 metre, two storey riverboat, was loading up for the three day journey to Mopti. Aboard were displaced people from Senegal and Mauretania, others who had found no work in Timbuktu and were moving on to try their luck elsewhere, tradesmen, pregnant women, tribesmen and farmers. Tonight, the new year, we will tell stories and hope for better times."

webTitle: Global meltdown fears recede

fields.headline: Global meltdown fears recede
fields.standfirst: Few problems as computers change date
fields.trailText: Fears of a millennial meltdown caused by computers crashing at the turn of the new century appeared to be receding last night as the first countries to greet 2000 reported no major problems.
fields.body:
Fears of a millennial meltdown caused by computers crashing at the turn of the new century appeared to be receding last night as the first countries to greet 2000 reported no major problems.

In New Zealand, the first industrialised country to pass into the new millennium, aviation, telecommunications, electricity and water systems were all working as normal.

The Australian government also said no major problems had been reported as the country ticked over into 2000.

Japan appeared to enter the new millennium bug free. There were some mobile phone connection problems, but these were related to the usual year-end flood of calls.

The millennium bug was born in the 1970s and 80s, when many computers were programmed to read only the last two digits of a year. If the glitch is uncorrected, systems could misread 2000 as 1900, causing malfunctions or even entire systems to crash.

Fears had been raised about the safety of Russia's nuclear power plants, but staff at the Bilibinsk nuclear reactor, in Russia's far eastern Chukotka province, opposite Alaska, reported no problems as they ushered in the new year.

"In connection with the change of date, no shutdown in the work of the equipment was observed," the Rosenergoatom firm, which manages eight nuclear power plants in Russia said yesterday.

Cooperation between Russian and US military experts to ensure that the millennium bug did not trigger a nuclear disaster successfully underwent its first test yesterday. Military experts from both countries sat side by side at Peterson air force base in Colorado Springs, monitoring nuclear missile launch warning systems to avoid any accident.

"Everything is working smoothly. We're in contact with Moscow all the time," US air force Colonel Mike Therrien said.

In the US the federal aviation administration acknowledged that it had made a last-minute upgrade to some air traffic control computers. A glitch could have caused controllers' screens to show aircraft positions up to 10 seconds late if two related systems failed during the transition from 1999 to 2000.

But a spokesman played down the significance of the problem. "It is a very, very minor issue," he said.

webTitle: City bug fears recede

fields.headline: City bug fears recede
fields.trailText: The 60,000 City workers due at their desks this weekend to ensure the smooth running of the Square Mile through the Y2K bug danger period took heart last night as New Zealand, Australia and other financial centres in eastern time zones reported no major systems problems.
fields.body:
The 60,000 City workers due at their desks this weekend to ensure the smooth running of the Square Mile through the Y2K bug danger period took heart last night as New Zealand, Australia and other financial centres in eastern time zones reported no major systems problems.

Within an hour of the clock ticking over midnight to 2000 in New Zealand, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand said the country's banking systems had come through the date change without difficulty.

Reserve Bank deputy governor Rod Carr said reports from New Zealand banks showed automated teller machines, electronic fund transfer point of sale and credit card transactions were working well. The central bank had also been advised that inter-bank cheque clearing was also proceeding normally.

The good news from the other side of the globe came as thousands of City IT specialists were running final computer tests in London. Many of the banks' essential staff are receiving five star treatment. As well as receiving huge overtime payments - in many cases thousands of pounds for staying at their desks while the rest of the country celebrates - many are being put up in central London hotels and provided with transport.

At investment bank Merrill Lynch, which has spent some $520m over the past five years to ensure its not hit by bugs, some 500-600 staff are on duty and the US-based group has taken 200 hotel rooms in the capital to accommodate them. "We have also laid on minibuses and coaches to make it as easy as possible and we have full catering facilities in the office," a spokesman said. Haute cuisine menus had even been devised to ward off hunger.

He added: "They are running some 1,200 tests over the next few days to make sure everything runs smoothly on Tuesday when the market reopens. There will be a few bourses open across the world on Monday and that will be a useful dry run. Some top staff will be working and staying in hotels for the next five or six days."

A spokeswoman for Goldman Sachs, the investment bank renowned for its secrecy, was less forthcoming. "We have people available", she said. "About a thousand will be coming in over the next few days. But we are not saying much about our Y2K plans."

The UK's main high street banks were also toiling through last night to ensure that cash machines, cheque clearing and credit transfer systems would run properly.

Barclays had 750 people working through the crucial hours in regional centres all over the country. "We are not testing the systems," said a spokesman, "We have people on hand just in case anything does go wrong."

Lloyds TSB had 1,500 ready to take any remedial action required and NatWest has 1,000 staff working eight-hour shifts throughout this weekend in London, Birmingham and Bristol. "They are mainly IT people, said a spokeswoman. "Hopefully they will be just testing and checking, and not fixing anything."

The health of the London financial sector over the millennium weekend is being monitored jointly by the Bank of England - which is co-ordinating efforts from an operations centre called the Blue Room - and the financial services authority.

webTitle: Our challenge for 2000

fields.headline: Our challenge for 2000
fields.trailText: The Guardian deserves great credit for taking up the cause of debt cancellation for the poorest countries before it was fashionable. However, there is scant evidence of "campaigners' inability to appreciate the realities of international diplomacy" (In Jubilee's debt, December 30). This campaign has been grounded from the start in those very realities and our record shows it.
fields.body:
The Guardian deserves great credit for taking up the cause of debt cancellation for the poorest countries before it was fashionable. However, there is scant evidence of "campaigners' inability to appreciate the realities of international diplomacy" (In Jubilee's debt, December 30). This campaign has been grounded from the start in those very realities and our record shows it.

It was British Jubilee 2000 supporters who flooded the German finance ministry with postcards in 1997, helping to bring about a marked change in that government's policy. It was the British Jubilee 2000 Coalition, with our American colleagues, who worked the corridors of power in Wash ington to turn around the opposition of the US Congress in October. And we will focus in the same way on Japan, the new chair of G7, in the new year.

No campaigner in Britain imagines that Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have an easy time making the case for debt cancellation. If this were easy, it would have been done long ago. But now that the British have joined the Americans in pledging 100% debt cancellation, we can focus all our energies on persuading others to follow suit - and on turning promises into reality. That is our challenge in 2000.

Adrian Lovett
Jubilee 2000 Coalition
mail@jubliee2000uk.org

webTitle: The birth of a new age

fields.headline: The birth of a new age
fields.trailText: My year 2020 objectives for our first baby, due in March, are rather different from HW Hilton's (Letters, December 22). I would like her to have: Lived without cars, without complaint; had several hobbies, but no monomania; become fit through purposeful activity, not sport or climbing mountains; embarked on a path of enriching and interdisciplinary life-long learning; achieved contentment with her appearance and belongings; have an open, critical mind about religion; developed a global perspective of people's needs; committed herself to counter the effects of climate change.

I would like her to have: Lived without cars, without complaint; had several hobbies, but no monomania; become fit through purposeful activity, not sport or climbing mountains; embarked on a path of enriching and interdisciplinary life-long learning; achieved contentment with her appearance and belongings; have an open, critical mind about religion; developed a global perspective of people's needs; committed herself to counter the effects of climate change.

Bridget McKenzie
bribri@lineone.net

 My objective for my two sons is that at the age of 20 they should still feel the benefit of my unconditional love for them.

Lena Stadlen
London
GSTAD1@aol.com

 I would hope that my offspring at any age can avoid being trapped in a lift with the unctuous oaf described by HW Hilton. At age 20, one should be concentrating on the development of a wonderful palate and the provision of samples of fine food and drink for old dad!

Brian Littlewood
Ashton-under-Lyne, Lancs
cow.pie@talk21.com

 In the discussion about names for babies born in the opening days of 2000 (Letters, December 24), those children whose birthday is December 31 1999 have been forgotten. I would like to suggest a couple of Irish names to parents of boys born on the last day of the old century: Finn (de siècle) or, as the English sounding equivalent, Enda (da century).

Martyn Cornell
Twickenham, Middx

 What are we going to call the first decade of the new century? The "singles" - too redolent of unattached pleasure seekers? Or the "zeros" - but that's writing off the decade before its begun. Surely the millennium commission should get on the case straight away - before we're all typecast for posterity.

Bryn Jones
Bath
hssbj@bath.ac.uk

webTitle: Hopes for the millennium

fields.headline: Hopes for the millennium
fields.trailText: What I wish to see in the next millennium is a greater respect by individuals for the interests of others. How would you feel if you were in the other person's position? Would you feel your actions fair and justified? This approach is as relevant at an individual level as for companies and governments. The approach would reduce the risks of conflict and the power of dictators, and help reduce inequalities in the world. This practical recipe was stated about 2,000 years ago as "do unto others as you would they should do unto you". Wish best wishes for a new millennium that can be fair and happy for everyone.
fields.body:
What I wish to see in the next millennium is a greater respect by individuals for the interests of others. How would you feel if you were in the other person's position? Would you feel your actions fair and justified? This approach is as relevant at an individual level as for companies and governments. The approach would reduce the risks of conflict and the power of dictators, and help reduce inequalities in the world. This practical recipe was stated about 2,000 years ago as "do unto others as you would they should do unto you". Wish best wishes for a new millennium that can be fair and happy for everyone.

John Chubb
Cheltenham

 I'd like to think that the next 1,000 years would mark a turning point in our relationship with our collective home. That power and the amassing of material wealth, at the expense of natural wealth, would become a thing of the past. That we would look beyond our own short and futile lives. However, that is not going to happen. We have nothing to celebrate and nothing to look forward to. There is no future for the human race and we don't deserve one. Simply by living the lives we do, we each play an active part in the death of all that supports life on earth and the things which should make that life enjoyable. My hope is that when we go, we won't drag everything else down with us.

Alexander Fitch
London

 The past millennium has seen the human population multiplied sixfold and the number of continents known to western man double from three to six. Man has crossed and plumbed the oceans, conquered the air and despite mishaps at Mars, made his first faltering steps into the wider universe. My hope is that the next century will see a self-sustaining daughter civilisation established off the Earth, both as necessary life insurance against catastrophic climatic changes, but, more positively, as an essential first step to fulfilling the true potential of our restless species - the mental development of the cosmos. My hope for the new millennium is that we do not allow those who would reduce us to the animal kingdom or who would, out of misguided misanthropy, confine us to Earth, procure the abortion known as a static growth-limited "utopia".

Dr Michael Martin-Smith
Hull

 In 1941, Rabindranath Tagore, the Bengali poet, wrote a poem to his friend Satyajit Ray: "I have spent a fortune travelling to distant shores and looked at lofty mountains and boundless oceans, and yet I haven't found time to take a few steps from my house to look at a single dew drop on a single blade of grass." An aspiration for the world is to begin to harness our insatiable appetites for more and more of what is not needed and to slow down and take time to discover that single dew drop.

Judith Dell
London

 I hope the human race can evolve and realise that armed conflict never solved any of the world's problems.

David Reggiori
London

 When asked what I am doing "for the millennium", I respond I shall be spending most of it in my coffin.

Sue Hill
Milverton, Somerset

 Happy New Commercial Opportunity. When the new century really begins next year on January 1, 2001, will we go through this palaver again?

The Rev'd Tony Bel
Chesterfield
tonybell@glapwell.f9.co.uk

fields.headline: Date lines
fields.trailText: I have been reminded that December 25 is "Christ's birthday". However no one has been able to explain why Christians also claim New Year's Eve as "Christ's 2,000th birthday". Does He have two birthdays per year?
fields.body:

Rawtenstall, Rossendale

webTitle: Tories courted for jump to UKIP

fields.headline: Tories courted for jump to UKIP
fields.trailText: William Hague's troubles deepened last night when senior officials of the breakaway UK Independence party confirmed that they have been holding exploratory talks with Conservative party members - including MPs such as Teresa Gorman.
fields.body:
William Hague's troubles deepened last night when senior officials of the breakaway UK Independence party confirmed that they have been holding exploratory talks with Conservative party members - including MPs such as Teresa Gorman.

The MP for Billericay, whose bid to become Tory candidate for mayor of London was quickly crushed by the Hague leadership, was not available for comment yesterday.

Supporters in her constituency said they remain confident she will not break from her party.

But the UKIP, which has been engulfed in personality quarrels of its own since unexpectedly winning three seats in the European parliament elections last June, said it has held talks with a number of Conservatives who are becoming increasingly disenchanted with the Hague policy of "in Europe, not run by Europe".

Mr Hague has endured a Christmas buffeting from the Tory left since the defection to Labour of the MP for Witney, Shaun Woodward.

But criticisms of Mr Hague's drift to the right by Kenneth Clarke and others are offset by the leadership's concern to win back core voters who defected to the late Sir James Goldsmith's Referendum party in the 1997 general election and to the UKIP in the 1999 European elections.

Both did better than expected, despite the increasingly Eurosceptic tone adopted under Mr Hague, though both claim to be winning disaffected Labour voters in the north and Liberal Democrats in rural areas such as Devon and Cornwall.

Nigel Farage, one of UKIP's founding members, now an MEP for the south-east region, confirmed that Mrs Gorman is one of those MPs with whom the party has been talking.

But both he and Michael Holmes MEP, the UKIP leader, refused to divulge what had been discussed, though there were hints that the Billericay MP may have been exploring support for an independent run for London mayor.

Malcolm Buckley, chairman of her local party, acknowledged the rumours about Mrs Gorman, reinforced by the fact that the UKIP decided not to stand against her in 1997, but said he had no reason to think they were true. Nor would she stand against whoever is the official Conservative candidate for London mayor.

"Since the government wants to get people interested in local government again the ideal contest would be between Teresa and Ken Livingstone.

"From a Conservative point of view we would much prefer to see Livingstone as the Labour candidate. He would be a much more attractive proposition for us to attack," Mr Buckley said.

The UKIP has been riven with dissent since last October's annual conference when its entire national executive committee was urged to resign, but refused.

The NEC is at loggerheads with Mr Holmes, and efforts will be made to patch up the feud on January 22.

"Like the Green party in 1989 [when it did well in the Euro-elections] we are experiencing growing pains," said Mr Farage. "It has been a miserable couple of months."

webTitle: Castaways: 12 months' hard slog in the Hebrides

fields.headline: Castaways: 12 months' hard slog in the Hebrides
fields.trailText: The main condition in allowing the experiment was that, after a year on the island, nobody must get to like it so much that they want to stay there for life, writes John Ezard.
fields.body:
The main condition in allowing the experiment was that, after a year on the island, nobody must get to like it so much that they want to stay there for life, writes John Ezard.

But Western Isles council is quietly confident that this problem, at least, will not arise after 36 men, women and children land later this month on Taransay in the outer Hebrides. As part of what BBC Scotland yesterday called "a unique experiment", they will start to spend 12 months on a five-mile patch of land which has no trees. Between September and May, Taransay gets 100mph winds.

The cold-weather Robinson Crusoes must also decide on the rules under which their community will operate. Their safety valve will be a "confessional camera" where they can bellow out their frustrations, watched by television viewers.

Their travails will be filmed as Castaway 2000, a documentary by Lion Television.

Taransay, west of Harris and last occupied earlier this century, has recently been used as rough grazing for sheep and deer.

webTitle: Harrison stab charge man bailed to care unit

fields.headline: Harrison stab charge man bailed to care unit
fields.trailText: The man charged with attempting to murder the former Beatle George Harrison and his wife was yesterday bailed by magistrates to be detained in a psychiatric unit.
fields.body:
The man charged with attempting to murder the former Beatle George Harrison and his wife was yesterday bailed by magistrates to be detained in a psychiatric unit.

Michael Abram, 33, did not enter a plea to the two charges of attempted murder of Harrison, 56, and his wife Olivia, 51, at their home on the 34-acre Friar Park estate in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, early on Thursday morning.

Harrison was stabbed in the chest when he struggled with an intruder armed with a knife at his mansion. The ordeal ended when the intruder fell to the floor after being bludgeoned by Mrs Harrison with a lamp.

Yesterday doctors told the rock star, who was recovering in hospital, that he would have to stay in for at least one night as they tried to reinflate his right lung, which was damaged when he suffered a one-inch knife wound which narrowly missed a vital artery.

Abram, from Liverpool, appeared before Oxford magistrates with a black left eye and a bloodstained forehead. He was dressed in a police issue white boiler suit for the 45-minute hearing and was flanked in the dock by three policemen.

He spoke only to confirm his name and address and to thank the magistrate for setting bail which allowed him to receive treatment at the Scott clinic in St Helens on Merseyside.

Abram was remanded on bail for six weeks. The chairman of the bench, Tim Pocock, adjourning the hearing until February 11, said sending Abram to the clinic for assessment and treatment was a step that could not be delayed.

Mr Pocock told him: "This is an exceptional course of action, but we feel you need treatment immediately."

Robert Craig, general manager at Harefield hospital, said yesterday that Harrison was in good spirits, but added that the "reality" of the incident had hit home and both the star and his wife were now slightly shocked.

Mr Craig said that how well Harrison responded to treatment in the following 24 hours would be crucial.

"It is a question of waiting for the treatment to take hold until his lung reinflates.

"We hope that he will be able to go home in a couple of days, but that depends on the next 24 hours.

"It is a fairly painful condition that Mr Harrison is in, and he will remain on painkillers until such time as he doesn't need them any more." Mr Craig added: "He is in quite good spirits, but he is very tired."

Olivia Harrison, who received treatment for minor injuries, spent the night beside her husband in his private single room in the surgery unit of the hospital.

Harrison's son Dhani, who is home from university in the United States, has also been to visit his father.

Meanwhile at the star's luxury home, members of the Thames Valley police support team yesterday continued a fingertip search of the house and grounds.

webTitle: Charles and the Welsh nationalists

fields.headline: Charles and the Welsh nationalists
fields.standfirst: Minister feared prince had been 'influenced'
fields.trailText: Prince Charles alarmed ministers in the 1969 Labour government who feared he was being influenced by Welsh nationalists, files released today under the 30-year rule show.
fields.body:
Prince Charles alarmed ministers in the 1969 Labour government who feared he was being influenced by Welsh nationalists, files released today under the 30-year rule show.

They reveal that George Thomas, the Welsh secretary, was sufficiently anxious about the "political implications" of the prince's public statements that he expressed his concerns in a minute to Harold Wilson.

"I have no information about who his advisers are," Thomas told the prime minister in a handwritten note dated July 22 1969. "But a dangerous situation is developing."

Thomas continued: "In my presence in Cardiff he referred to the 'cultural and political awakening in Wales'. This is most useful for the nationalists.

"If the prince is writing his own speeches he may well be tempted to go further. The enthusiasm of youth is a marvellous spur, but it may lead to speeches that cause difficulty".

Thomas claimed that while the prince was studying at Aberystwyth university earlier in the year, he had been subjected to "concentrated attention by Welsh nationalists".

Thomas suggested a "discreet word to the Queen might help". Failing that, the prince's speeches, like the Queen's, would have to be screened by Whitehall.

Wilson acknowledged that Thomas's concerns were "a matter which was important". He agreed to get a Downing Street official to speak to the Queen's private secretary, Sir Michael Adeane, "in a low key".

Charles was invested as the Prince of Wales at Caernarvon Castle on July 1 that year.

A draft of the Queen's 1968 Christmas message written - unusually - by the Queen with the help of Prince Philip caused consternation in 10 Downing Street, the records released today show.

Officials told Wilson it contained "some odd phrases". They were referring to a passage in the draft where the Queen intended to say: "Britain is not the only commonwealth country contending with serious economic difficulties. Fortunately, there are others who are enjoying better times."

After consulting the foreign office, Downing Street approached Michael Adeane, the Queen's private secretary, and he ensured "the offending para has been deleted".

In October 1969, Adeane told Michael Walls, a member of Wilson's private office, that the Queen had decided to "break with the traditional Christmas message". Instead of broadcasting a message she would distribute it, to be read by others, becausethere had been "a great deal of royal film and television coverage this year".

Walls warned Wilson: "You are at risk, particularly in what may be a prelude to an election year" of appearing to "intervene to keep Her off the television so that you can hog it".

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Doubts on Concorde
fields.body:
Doubts on Concorde

The extent of the Wilson government's continuing misgivings about the Anglo-French Concorde project is revealed in the papers released today. Even after the maiden flight of Britain's 002 Concorde in April 1969, ministers were unconvinced of the scheme's merits.

Spy dilemma

The foreign office was engaged in sensitive negotiations with Moscow over a plan to exchange Peter and Helen Kroger, Russian spies, for Gerald Brooke, a British lecturer arrested for distributing "subversive" pamphlets in the Soviet Union.

The papers make it clear that the issue divided the cabinet. The Krogers were arrested in 1960 and sentenced to 20 years. Brooke was arrested in 1965 and sentenced to one year's jail and four years in a labour camp. The exchange was agreed in July 1969.

'Bar George'

Officials in the government were sent into a panic when it was suggested that ex-cabinet minister George Brown might be invited to official functions during the 1969 visit of US President Richard Nixon.

Harold Wilson and the foreign secretary, Michael Stewart, acted to discourage the Americans from inviting Brown, who had a reputation for drinking and erratic behaviour.

No joke

The government failed to see the funny side when the Tories produced spoof bank notes sending up the prime minister.

Bank of England officials warned Conservative central office that the £1 "Bank of Harold" notes breached the forgery act.

webTitle: Police meet over fate of alleged Nazi murderer

fields.headline: Police meet over fate of alleged Nazi murderer
fields.trailText: Police and home office officials met yesterday to decide the fate of an alleged Nazi mass murderer staying at a Latvian retirement home in the Leicestershire village of Catthorpe.
fields.body:
Police and home office officials met yesterday to decide the fate of an alleged Nazi mass murderer staying at a Latvian retirement home in the Leicestershire village of Catthorpe.

Konrad Kalejs, 86, was deported from both the United States and Canada for his alleged involvement in the slaughter of 30,000 people, mainly Jews, while commanding a Latvian squad working for the Third Reich.

Officers from Scotland Yard, Leicestershire police, and the immigration service met with home office officials to discuss what action, if any, should be taken against Kalejs. Jewish groups want him to be stand trial, either in Britain or Latvia. Scotland Yard is to seek information from Australia, where Kalejs lived after the war. He is believed to have entered Britain this summer on an Australian passport.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been briefed.

Since the war crimes act gave British courts jurisdiction over acts committed abroad by foreigners, only two have faced charges. After an £11m trial, Anthony Sawoniuk, 78, was jailed for life for murder. Szymon Serafinowicz, 85, was freed in 1997 after a ruling he was too weak to face trial.

webTitle: Worry that impersonator could launch nuclear attack

fields.headline: Worry that impersonator could launch nuclear attack
fields.standfirst: Gremlin fear over control of weapons
fields.trailText: The circumstances surrounding the most important decision a prime minister has to contemplate - the order to fire nuclear weapons - preoccupied officials close to Harold Wilson.
fields.body:
The circumstances surrounding the most important decision a prime minister has to contemplate - the order to fire nuclear weapons - preoccupied officials close to Harold Wilson.

Documents made available today reveal their concern about the possibility of someone imitating his voice.

They show the issue was first raised by Denis Healey, the defence secretary, in 1967 when he alerted the prime minister to the "need for Her Majesty's government to retain close political control of the release of these weapons".

He proposed a direct link between 10 Downing Street and the Polaris "firing headquarters" at Northwood, the navy's operational headquarters in north-west London.

"Under these arrangements," Healey noted, "the C in C at Northwood would not order the submarine commander to fire until specifically authorised by yourself to do so". Sir Burke Trend, the cabinet secretary, told Wilson that the order to fire was "a question of executive responsibility" and other ministers need not be troubled by it.

A closed circuit television link between Downing Street and Northwood was set up so that naval commanders could see as well as hear the prime minister. To ensure the system functioned properly in the event of a crisis it was retested twice a day.

It was "of crucial importance", a top secret note records, "to ensure that the arrangements for testing the Polaris control were such that those who tested it could in no way imitate the prime minister".

The note added: "One method was suggested (not recorded because it is so sensitive) by which the prime ministers could be imitated" - a reference, perhaps, to Mike Yarwood or John Bird, two satirists then at the peak of their powers.

Meanwhile, Healey's approach to the use of nuclear weapons provoked a storm of protests, the records show. Early in 1969, the defence secretary made a speech in which he suggested that in the event of a Soviet invasion of western Europe, Nato would have no alternative to firing off a salvo of tactical nuclear weapons as warning shots. "What in God's name has happened in the ministry of defence?" Lord Mountbatten, the former chief of defence staff, who was deeply sceptical about nuclear deterrent theory, thundered in a letter to the government's scientific adviser, Sir Solly Zuckerman.

He described Healey's remarks as "terrifying" and "pernicious nonsense". "Is there no one around, apart from you, who understands the diference between nuclear deterrence and fighting a war?", he wrote.

"I thought that we had got the intelligence people when we were in the ministry of defence to understand the facts of life," he added.

"But I suppose no one who understands is left. All I can hope is that Denis's political colleagues will not be taken in by his frightening conversion to such primitive reactionary thinking, the results of which, if accepted by men in real authority, could be catastrophic. For heaven's sake get to work and make sure that sanity prevails."

Zuckerman immediately wrote to Wilson, pointing to the prevailing US view that whichever side struck first, "both would be totally destroyed". Healey's strategy would lead to a "series of Hiroshimas", he warned.

webTitle: Revellers gather in capital to watch river of fire

fields.headline: Revellers gather in capital to watch river of fire
fields.standfirst: London: Millions gather for largest ever fireworks show
fields.trailText: Celebrations were under way well before nightfall in London as revellers jostled for the best positions to see in the new millennium.
fields.body:
Celebrations were under way well before nightfall in London as revellers jostled for the best positions to see in the new millennium.

As London's main river bridges were closed to traffic, crowds filled the roadways preparing to watch the "river of fire" spectacular. And despite the embarrassing cancellation of the inaugural public ride of the London Eye ferris wheel, people gathered for the official opening of the structure by the prime minister and a flypast by Concorde.

On the banks of the Thames and around central London, crowds queued up for funfair rides, clapped along to marching bands and danced to rock music. It appeared, however, that forecasts of 3m visitors were optimistic.

The Queen set out from Sandringham to light the London beacon - the biggest of a chain of similar flames being lit around the country - positioned on a barge floating on the Thames near Tower Bridge.

Sixteen more barges, each loaded with 3.75 tonnes of explosive, were moored along an five mile stretch of the river between Tower Bridge and Vauxhall, in preparation for the 20-minute firework show beginning on the stroke of midnight.

A computer on the shore was prepared to send out radio cues, triggering sequential detonations on each barge, from east to west, at an average time interval of 0.675 seconds. Each signal was primed to send hundreds of fireworks fanning into the air, giving the impression of an advancing river of fire dancing upstream at 650mph.

Once the river of fire was complete, more than 40,000 fireworks would be let off as part of a display that the organisers said was the biggest of its kind.

Elsewhere in central London, celebrations gathered pace. Yards from Buckingham Palace, the Mall was transformed into a funfair. For £100, you could be the first to bungee-jump into 2000 on a giant catapult outside Clarence House, the Queen Mother's London residence.

"If I was the Queen, I would want a rate rebate, having this outside my house," said Pamela Dearman, 66, from Berkeley, Gloucestershire.

But the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh spent their traditional Christmas and New Year holiday at Sandringham - travelling into London for the celebrations, and planning to return in the early hours.

It also emerged yesterday that health and safety officials would have banned the use of the millennium wheel if the attraction's operators had not cancelled the launch.

Two health and safety executive inspectors turned up at the British Airways London Eye site on the South Bank on Thursday, expecting to see certificates proving that the necessary safety tests had been carried out, the HSE said. Instead they were told that the inaugural ride had been cancelled. The decision was made public some hours later.

British Airways confirmed that a problem had been found with the clutch used to stabilise one of the 32 French-made capsules during tests on Thursday. The decision to cancel the ride was made by Allott and Lomax, the independent ride assessor, in the knowledge that the HSE was primed to issue a notice banning any passengers on the ride.

BA described the fault as a "minor hiccup". A spokesman was "quietly confident" that the planned public opening on February 1 would go ahead.

A disappointed 250 competition winners due to ride the wheel will be compensated with a "champagne party" and a pair of BA return flights to a destination of their choice.

The Queen set out from Sandringham to light the London beacon - the biggest of a chain of similar flames being lit around the country - positioned on a barge floating on the Thames near Tower Bridge. Sixteen more barges, each loaded with 3.75 tonnes of explosive, were moored along an five mile stretch of the river between Tower Bridge and Vauxhall, in preparation for the 20-minute firework show beginning on the stroke of midnight. A computer on the shore was prepared to send out radio cues, triggering sequential detonations on each barge, from east to west, at an average time interval of 0.675 seconds. Each signal was primed to send hundreds of fireworks fanning into the air, giving the impression of an advancing river of fire dancing upstream at 650mph. Once the river of fire was complete, more than 40,000 fireworks would be let off as part of a display that the organisers said was the biggest of its kind. Elsewhere in central London, celebrations gathered pace. Yards from Buckingham Palace, the Mall was transformed into a funfair. For £100, you could be the first to bungee-jump into 2000 on a giant catapult outside Clarence House, the Queen Mother's London residence. "If I was the Queen, I would want a rate rebate, having this outside my house," said Pamela Dearman, 66, from Berkeley, Gloucestershire. But the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh spent their traditional Christmas and New Year holiday at Sandringham - travelling into London for the celebrations, and planning to return in the early hours. It also emerged yesterday that health and safety officials would have banned the use of the millennium wheel if the attraction's operators had not cancelled the launch. Two health and safety executive inspectors turned up at the British Airways London Eye site on the South Bank on Thursday, expecting to see certificates proving that the necessary safety tests had been carried out, the HSE said. Instead they were told that the inaugural ride had been cancelled. The decision was made public some hours later. British Airways confirmed that a problem had been found with the clutch used to stabilise one of the 32 French-made capsules during tests on Thursday. The decision to cancel the ride was made by Allott and Lomax, the independent ride assessor, in the knowledge that the HSE was primed to issue a notice banning any passengers on the ride. BA described the fault as a "minor hiccup". A spokesman was "quietly confident" that the planned public opening on February 1 would go ahead. A disappointed 250 competition winners due to ride the wheel will be compensated with a "champagne party" and a pair of BA return flights to a destination of their choice.

webTitle: Railtrack website sabotaged

fields.headline: Railtrack website sabotaged
fields.standfirst: Hackers: Thousands misled over travel inquiries herey
fields.trailText: Semi-literate but effective hackers yesterday planted a fake millennium bug in Railtrack's website, disrupting it for 10 hours and blocking tens of thousands of travel inquiries and affecting plans for people planning to come into London for the evening.
fields.body:
Semi-literate but effective hackers yesterday planted a fake millennium bug in Railtrack's website, disrupting it for 10 hours and blocking tens of thousands of travel inquiries and affecting plans for people planning to come into London for the evening.

They intruded an announcement cancelling all trains for three days on what was due to be the site's busiest day of the year.

The message, which had a misspelling and was obscurely worded, blamed cancellations on the bug. It appeared at 1am on Railtrack's home page, which has a link to all rail timetables.

The company's information technology staff took until 11.30am to return things to normal. Railtrack phone inquiry lines were continuously engaged.

A spokeswoman said they believed the site had been vulnerable "because of a hitch in a piece of Microsoft software we have got".

The site - one of Britain's busiest - gets an average of 171,000 calls a day. Staff were expecting far heavier traffic than usual yesterday

The message ended with "greetings to all the sheep in Wales and all of the Railtrack directors". It added greetings to "HackUK, Rootworm, Illusions Team, Domz, Trionix, Slacker, Alkatraz, Dred". None of these nicknames is familiar in hacking circles. A specialist said yesterday: "They could be just blokes in a pub picking names out of a hat."

Last night one surfer who saw the message, Richard Yarnall, a Birmingham electronics engineer, said: "I was on a chat channel when somebody said, 'Have you heard all the trains have been cancelled?' I looked at the Railtrack website and spotted that something was not quite right with the message."

The Railtrack spokeswoman said: "This is a prank which is supposed to be amusing.

"Unfortunately, it affected hundreds and thousands of people who were trying to get into London for the millennium eve celebrations."

Timetables could still be reached while the message was on screen, she added.

"I have not heard of our website being hacked before. We shall be trying very hard to see that it does not happen again. We would like to reassure customers that trains are running as published."

webTitle: Blunders leave angry guests stranded

fields.headline: Blunders leave angry guests stranded
fields.trailText: The glittering dome opening came close to farce last night as thousands of guests were stranded outside a station in east London. More than 2,500 irate invitees, in dinner suits and evening gowns, queued in the cold for up to two hours outside Stratford station when it closed because a shortage of security scanning equipment made it impossible for organisers to cope with the numbers. Guests were furious that there was only one scanner available to deal with up to 8,000 guests.
fields.body:
The glittering dome opening came close to farce last night as thousands of guests were stranded outside a station in east London. More than 2,500 irate invitees, in dinner suits and evening gowns, queued in the cold for up to two hours outside Stratford station when it closed because a shortage of security scanning equipment made it impossible for organisers to cope with the numbers. Guests were furious that there was only one scanner available to deal with up to 8,000 guests.

After queuing up to an hour to get in, guests faced further delays to board special trains to the dome. The problems grew further when security equipment at Charlton station failed, forcing embarrassed officials to start ferrying quests to other already overcrowded stations, including Stratford.

A public address announcement at Stratford advised people to catch buses to board alternative tube service. At 9.30pm, many remained stuck on the platform - beneath a flashing sign saying, Welcome to Stratford, the Gateway to the New Millennium 2000, and were starting to make their way home.

The fiasco came after hundreds had spent up to seven hours queuing to collect passes that were meant to have been delivered by post.

Liam Kane, managing director of the New Millennium Experience Company, dismissed criticism, saying that the crush was being caused by people arriving earlier than expected.
