webTitle: Dream on...

fields.headline: Dream on...
fields.standfirst: New Year's Day needn't be about giving things up. Instead, why not make a millennial resolution to go to 10 places you've always dreamed of? Tom Bussmann ventures from the possible to the improbable
fields.trailText: The rainforest
fields.body:
The rainforest

I've flown the ocean in a silver plane/but haven't seen the jungle when it's wet with rain. The lyricist seemed quite insistent that said jungle, wet, was a desirable destination, so I suppose I will have to put it on my wish list, but I intend to take every known form of insect repellent and anti-snakebite serum. My clothing will be Gore-Tex down to, and including, my socks. In addition, I require that the jungle should be within easy walking distance (by which I mean as far as I would go on foot to post a letter) of five-star air-conditioned room service. All wildlife encountered must be either cute, colourful or easily frightened off by high-pitched screaming. Nor should any living creature, seen or unseen, have more than four legs or fewer than two.

America, the middle bit

Like millions of Brits, I've done the sides of the US. Now, as the days dwindle down to a precious few, it's time to land in the part that even Americans call Fly-Over Country. A lifetime wasted watching movies set in identical towns where teenagers are about to be drenched in pig's blood and subsequently slaughtered on prom night means I know what to expect. If the chosen location has a state university, I will surely come back with enough material for a snotty comic novel. If not, that'll be a first. Among must-see sights are those lockers in high schools, a bicycling paperboy throwing papers over picket fences, the court-house, the drive-in movie, and the Eagle Scout up the water tower with a telescopic rifle.

The UK

Oh the shame. The only bits I've seen are where I grew up (Cambridge), where we went on holiday (Hunstanton, year after year), where the RAF sent me (the Isle of Man, Norfolk, North Devon), and where my job took me. That last one covered quite a lot of the UK, mostly beautiful, as it had to be if you're making commercials. Now I'd quite like to go and have another look at the Lakes, the Highlands, Mull, the Llanberis Pass, the Cheddar Gorge and countless other cliché film locations pock-marked by tripods, but in my own time. Who knows? All that stuff probably looks quite nice without an umbrella and a baleful client dripping down your neck, asking you if there isn't some filter that makes it look sunny.

Museums

Oh the guilt. The art is out there. I know that. I don't even have to get on a plane and fly to the Prado or the Louvre or Moma. One bus route into town takes me past the Tate and the National Gallery. The other takes me past the V&A and the Royal Academy. Past being the operative word. People go in willingly, I know, I can see them from the top deck. Perhaps the curators could entice the likes of myself inside by hanging some of the art on the outside, on the railings. The oils and sculpture must be relatively waterproof, surely?

Egypt

This is like museums, only without air conditioning but with added mindless terrorism. Still, I feel duty-bound to tick the "pyramids along the Nile" off my to-do-before-I-die culture-list, and would prefer to get the whole trip done-and-dusted by chartered Concorde, helicopter, armed bodyguards and castrated camel. Shouldn't take more than an afternoon.

The Ritz Hotel, Paris

I think I can safely say that my chances of running into Tory ex-cabinet ministers, let alone their loyal wives, in this "beastly hotel" (copyright Mrs Hamilton) are nil. This alone makes it a big draw and, with luck, some passing Arab gun dealer might pick up my tab if I take the precaution of wearing a dark blue pin-stripe suit and Old Etonian tie. Must make a note not to use any of the in-house chauffeurs.

Cala di Volpe, Sardinia

There is expensive, there is hugely expensive and then there is the Cala di Volpe. This stately pleasure dome was built not by Kubla but by the other Khan, Aga. Many years ago, I was staying on Sardinia in a rented villa. Big mistake. The kids spent the day on the beach filling buckets with cigarette ends. Then we drove across the parched island to the Costa Smeralda and, after passing miles of livid green golf courses, found the name "Cala di Volpe" lettered on a rock. I wandered down the drive and tried to take it in - the tiny, perfect, private beaches, the vast yachts taking advantage of the deep-water mooring, the discreet architecture. Then the hotel doors opened and out walked a family. They glittered. They shone. One glance told me that if I sold every single item I possessed the total would not equal the cost of what they were wearing. So I'd like to go back to the Cala di Volpe, just once, and this time go inside, please.

Machu Picchu

I've always hankered to have a look at the temple of Machu Picchu ever since a travel agent friend told me of his efforts to bring this wonder of the ancient Incas to a wider public. Overcoming all obstacles, he led a party of American tourists here, first by narrow-gauge railway winding through mountain passes, then arriving in darkness at the monastery where they would spend the night. Next morning, he woke the group before dawn and shepherded them down through a gate in the garden wall. Then he lined them up along the precipitous path, so they would be perfectly positioned to see the sun rise over the valley and hit the cone-shaped mountain and the matching temple.

The sun duly did its stuff. There was a silence, broken by an American voice asking: "What are we waiting for?"

Hotel du Cap

This is the hotel, you may remember, that Madonna graced with her presence during the Cannes Film Festival. She also graced it with the presence of her bodyguards, who cleared the pool of other paying guests so that she might swim in it alone. My plan is to stay there the next time she pulls this stunt, then bottle the water. Takings should comfortably cover all expenses incurred on the foregoing fantasies.

And finally

An upgrade, please. To First, thank you very much, though Business will do at a pinch. Whoever said "To travel is better than to arrive," was not flying Economy.

The only bits I've seen are where I grew up (Cambridge), where we went on holiday (Hunstanton, year after year), where the RAF sent me (the Isle of Man, Norfolk, North Devon), and where my job took me. That last one covered quite a lot of the UK, mostly beautiful, as it had to be if you're making commercials. Now I'd quite like to go and have another look at the Lakes, the Highlands, Mull, the Llanberis Pass, the Cheddar Gorge and countless other cliché film locations pock-marked by tripods, but in my own time. Who knows? All that stuff probably looks quite nice without an umbrella and a baleful client dripping down your neck, asking you if there isn't some filter that makes it look sunny. Museums Oh the guilt. The art is out there. I know that. I don't even have to get on a plane and fly to the Prado or the Louvre or Moma. One bus route into town takes me past the Tate and the National Gallery. The other takes me past the V&A and the Royal Academy. Past being the operative word. People go in willingly, I know, I can see them from the top deck. Perhaps the curators could entice the likes of myself inside by hanging some of the art on the outside, on the railings. The oils and sculpture must be relatively waterproof, surely? Egypt This is like museums, only without air conditioning but with added mindless terrorism. Still, I feel duty-bound to tick the "pyramids along the Nile" off my to-do-before-I-die culture-list, and would prefer to get the whole trip done-and-dusted by chartered Concorde, helicopter, armed bodyguards and castrated camel. Shouldn't take more than an afternoon. The Ritz Hotel, Paris I think I can safely say that my chances of running into Tory ex-cabinet ministers, let alone their loyal wives, in this "beastly hotel" (copyright Mrs Hamilton) are nil. This alone makes it a big draw and, with luck, some passing Arab gun dealer might pick up my tab if I take the precaution of wearing a dark blue pin-stripe suit and Old Etonian tie. Must make a note not to use any of the in-house chauffeurs. Cala di Volpe, Sardinia There is expensive, there is hugely expensive and then there is the Cala di Volpe. This stately pleasure dome was built not by Kubla but by the other Khan, Aga. Many years ago, I was staying on Sardinia in a rented villa. Big mistake. The kids spent the day on the beach filling buckets with cigarette ends. Then we drove across the parched island to the Costa Smeralda and, after passing miles of livid green golf courses, found the name "Cala di Volpe" lettered on a rock. I wandered down the drive and tried to take it in - the tiny, perfect, private beaches, the vast yachts taking advantage of the deep-water mooring, the discreet architecture. Then the hotel doors opened and out walked a family. They glittered. They shone. One glance told me that if I sold every single item I possessed the total would not equal the cost of what they were wearing. So I'd like to go back to the Cala di Volpe, just once, and this time go inside, please. Machu Picchu I've always hankered to have a look at the temple of Machu Picchu ever since a travel agent friend told me of his efforts to bring this wonder of the ancient Incas to a wider public. Overcoming all obstacles, he led a party of American tourists here, first by narrow-gauge railway winding through mountain passes, then arriving in darkness at the monastery where they would spend the night. Next morning, he woke the group before dawn and shepherded them down through a gate in the garden wall. Then he lined them up along the precipitous path, so they would be perfectly positioned to see the sun rise over the valley and hit the cone-shaped mountain and the matching temple. The sun duly did its stuff. There was a silence, broken by an American voice asking: "What are we waiting for?" Hotel du Cap This is the hotel, you may remember, that Madonna graced with her presence during the Cannes Film Festival. She also graced it with the presence of her bodyguards, who cleared the pool of other paying guests so that she might swim in it alone. My plan is to stay there the next time she pulls this stunt, then bottle the water. Takings should comfortably cover all expenses incurred on the foregoing fantasies. And finally An upgrade, please. To First, thank you very much, though Business will do at a pinch. Whoever said "To travel is better than to arrive," was not flying Economy.

fields.standfirst: What's to do when the parties are over? Guardian critics on the year's hot tickets
fields.trailText: Pierre Boulez Boulez begins a series of concerts with the LSO at the Barbican to mark his 75th birthday, on January 27.
fields.body:
Pierre Boulez Boulez begins a series of concerts with the LSO at the Barbican to mark his 75th birthday, on January 27.

English National Opera (1)
Premiere of Mark-Anthony Turnage's The Silver Tassie. Libretto by Amanda Holden; conductor Paul Daniel (February 16).

CBSO
Final instalment, in March, of the Towards the Millennium series at the Royal Festival Hall and Symphony Hall, Birmingham. Conducted by Simon Rattle.

The Last Supper
Premiere of Harrison Birtwistle's "dramatic tableaux" at the Berlin Staatsoper on April 18. Libretto by Robin Blaser; director Martin Duncan, conductor Daniel Barenboim (April 18).

Songs and stories from Moby Dick
British premiere of Laurie Anderson's latest multi-media show at the Barbican Theatre, May 24.

St Magnus festival, Orkney
Peter Maxwell Davies premieres Mr Emmet Takes a Walk (text by David Pountney, June 16), Sailing in St Magnus No 4 (June 17) and Symphony No 7 (June 19).

Salzburg festival
Premiere of Kaija Saariaho's first opera, L'Amour de Loin. Libretto by Amin Maalouf, director Peter Sellars, conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen (August 16).

English National Opera (2)
ENO's nine-opera Italian season, overseen by Stefanos Lazaridis, begins with Manon Lescaut, (September 18), and The Coronation of Poppaea (September 19).

Glyndebourne touring opera
Season includes British premiere of Birtwistle's The Last Supper and new production of La Bohème, director David McVicar.

Thétre du Chatelet
Paris premiere of John Adams's Nativity, director Peter Sellars, conductor Kent Nagano (December 15).

webTitle: No 6 Next Tuesday

fields.headline: No 6 Next Tuesday
fields.trailText: "Sorry, our offices are closed until Tuesday January 4," muffled voices have been issuing bleakly from answering machines for the best part of two weeks now. "Let's get together after the fourth," we have all been saying to one another. And then there's: "We'll be able to pay first thing in January, as soon as everything's back to normal."
fields.body:
"Sorry, our offices are closed until Tuesday January 4," muffled voices have been issuing bleakly from answering machines for the best part of two weeks now. "Let's get together after the fourth," we have all been saying to one another. And then there's: "We'll be able to pay first thing in January, as soon as everything's back to normal."

Well, if you are reading this, it's a fair assumption that the world didn't end after all - and that the odd flapping noise you can hear outside is of a zillion chickens coming home to roost. Yes, after the longest and weirdest public holiday in history, normality will return on Tuesday. And we should all welcome it. No more excuses, no more cheques suspended in fiscal limbo, no more anxiety about North Korean missiles spontaneously launching an attack on Ashby-de-la-Zouch.

Not that the epic run of bank holidays hasn't been enjoyable in its own way. It's just that there are only so many videos you can watch during the endless, back-to-back Sundays, so many retrospectives of the last century you can absorb, so many discussions you can have in which everyone tries to out-do the other at expressing how little idea they have over whether a given day is a Saturday, a Monday or a Wednesday, and how little difference it makes anyway, because everything's been closed since the 20th century.

There is similarly a limit to the number of pointless walks around the block which can be taken or long-avoided tasks undertaken in the absence of anything else to do; you will know the syndrome by now - if it's New Year's Eve morning, it must be the time for putting all the videos in their proper jackets, getting up on a ladder and replacing all the dead lightbulbs in the hall and tidying the loft you haven't been in since 1985.

Normality, it must surely have struck even those of us who thrive on anomaly, isn't so bad after all. Stuff works, things are open, the trains and buses run and there are proper jobs to do when you get off them. There are no "specials" on TV, the news is on at the proper time and consists of more than bin ends of stories that wouldn't have seen the light of day in a "real" week. Most reassuringly of all, normality means there's no dread speculation on just what we would do if the central heating or the car broke down or if we found ourselves in need of a quick appendectomy.

Another thoroughly excellent thing about next Tuesday will be, of course, be that the word "millennium" should - oh, please let it be so - be heard several hundred times less per hour than has been the case for the past year. Even stories of doom at the Dome will begin to tail off after a while, as soon as we've got used to the fact that it's empty most of the time. There will be a brief flutter of interest in the pedants' millennium 364 days from now, but other than that, it looks like goodbye for ever to the M word.

The ultimate, exquisite, priceless benefit of next Tuesday, however; the towering, unassailable reason it must be regarded as a great day in our history, is that a terrible torment will have been removed from humankind.

OK, hunger, war and pestilence will still ravage the planet, but never again will we, or our children or their grandchildren's grandchildren have to concern themselves over what to do on millennium night. Whatever your solution was to that decade-long problem, you did it last night and need never give it a moment's thought again.

webTitle: Sir Leon Radzinowicz

fields.headline: Sir Leon Radzinowicz
fields.standfirst: The Polish emigré who first made criminology a respectable academic and political subject in his adopted country of Britain
fields.trailText: Leon Radzinowicz, who has died aged 93, was an exceptional man. This Cambridge professor, fellow of Trinity, fellow of the British Academy, member of the Athenaeum, and engine extraordinary of the development of British criminology, never conformed to the stereotype of the English academic, quite apart from the small matter of his Polish name.
fields.body:
Leon Radzinowicz, who has died aged 93, was an exceptional man. This Cambridge professor, fellow of Trinity, fellow of the British Academy, member of the Athenaeum, and engine extraordinary of the development of British criminology, never conformed to the stereotype of the English academic, quite apart from the small matter of his Polish name.

While he made no secret of his unbounded admiration for the institutions of his adopted country (he was naturalised in 1947), "Radzy", as he was known, remained the essential European. He could switch between English, French, Italian, German, Spanish and Polish as readily as from one television channel to another. His urbane manner was matched by a wry sense of humour, an often unexpected generosity and an excellent taste in wine.

He could be good company for lunch at the Athenaeum, dinner in Trinity or over tea and toasted teacakes at Brown's Hotel - he retained a strangely boyish affection for the atmosphere of that establishment.

He had what no one else did, the necessary combination of vision, tireless energy and Machiavellian wit to make criminology an intellectually and politically respectable discipline. But whatever he did, he did it with success and élan.

Unlike criminologists Hermann Mannheim and Max Grunhut, who prudently fled Germany soon after the rise of Hitler and arrived in Britain relatively penniless, surviving on the charity of academic communities, Radzinowicz had been a peripatetic European scholar.

In 1924, at the age of 18, he arrived at the University of Paris; in 1926, he moved to Geneva to take a law degree and, in 1927, he graduated with another from the University of Rome. In 1938, Radzy came to England to report on the English penal system for the Polish ministry of justice. This was the year of Munich, and the following year Hitler invaded Poland. Radzy was astute enough to see what was happening and took refuge in the law faculty at Cambridge; there he spent the rest of his academic life.

Criminology in England had, until the arrival of these emigrés, been a minority interest of the medical profession. It was seen as having little relevance to penal policy and less to forensic aspects of criminal justice. Judges treated it in like fashion.

Mannheim, at the London School of Economics, became the "father" of modern English criminology. Without his teaching in the 40s and 50s, the present generation of academic criminologists would not exist. But he was a proud man who never entirely abandoned the formalities of his youth, when he had been a Prussian officer and judge; he lacked the social skills to give the subject the public legitimacy crucial to its survival; he upset so many people that he was never to have the professorial accolade.

In 1957, the Conservative home secretary, RA Butler, approached London university about establishing an institute of criminology; Mannheim, though he had a record of empirical and policy-oriented research, was not even consulted. At a private lunch given by the vice-chancellor, the principal, Douglas Logan, dismissed Mannheim's claims in a single sentence, but praised Radzinowicz, whom he knew well as a fellow Fellow of Trinity. The lunch was attended by the under secretary of state at the home office and the secretary of the royal commission on capital punishment, on which Radzinowicz had served.

At the time, many in London, not least Mannheim, believed that the whole thing had been a stitch-up and the man with the needle was Logan. It will never be possible to know why the vice-chancellor did not acknowledge, let alone reply, to Butler's letter until prompted by the home secretary's private office. Did Radzy know what was going on behind the academic arras? It seems inconceivable that he did not, but the Old Fox, another of his nicknames, would have been far too wily to have left the least incriminating scent.

Mannheim wasted a disproportionate amount of energy in his retirement expressing his hatred of the "upstart Pole"; this degenerated into such an obsession that any former pupil who visited Cambridge was re-categorised as an "unperson". But by 1959 the institute was established in Cambridge. Radzinowicz became the first professor of criminology in Britain and some of Her Majesty's judges began to accept invitations to contribute to the institute's seminars.

Radzinowicz had already achieved much in wartime and postwar Cambridge and the institute was established on sound foundations. He had carved a niche in the law faculty and, by 1948, he had his fellowship at Trinity. By 1949, he was appointed a member of the Gowers commission on capital punishment. The first volume of his magnum opus, A History Of English Criminal Law Since 1750, appeared in 1948, and the last in 1986.

These five massive volumes stand as testimony to his prodigious industry. Not that they were the result of only one man's labour down the years. Radzy's enemies have ascribed to his various co-workers the greater part of particular volumes. For all that his mind ranged the horizons of the subject quick as a falcon's eye, his individual writings were probably not outstanding. It was the immediacy of his persona that was memorable; he was a master of the spoken word.

His membership of the Gowers commission stood him in good stead, for he made friends in the home office and in the shadows of the political establishment. Trinity and the Athenaeum came in handy for such things and lesser, and younger, mortals got the toasted teacakes. He was never short of money.

In 1966, there was a major scandal following the escape of the Soviet spy George Blake, who had just been sentenced to 42 years' imprisonment. The Labour home secretary, Roy Jenkins, appointed Earl Mountbatten to report. Radzy's seat on the advisory council on the penal system led to his becoming chairman of the sub-committee that considered Mountbatten's proposals for maximum security prisons in 1967-8. He came out in favour not of Mountbatten's idea of a concentration of high risk prisoners in one place but of the preferred home office option of dispersal.

Mountbatten was furious, which must have troubled Radzy, since he was totally sycophantic about royalty; the history of the dispersal policy has been the unmitigated failure its critics predicted. Perhaps, knowing the tide, he judged it better not to go against it. Yet, from his introduction to a book by Richard Sparks in 1971, he clearly saw what was happening in the English prison system and made few bones about it.

In 1986, he spoke at a reception in Lincoln's Inn to mark the publication of the final volume of his History (the Conservative home secretary was the principal guest) and his asides made little secret of contempt in which he held Thatcherite social policies and the mess of British society, never mind its prisons. By this time, he lived in Philadelphia.

His knighthood came in 1970, shortly before his retirement from the Wolfson chair. At last he could feel on equal terms with those senior civil servants whom he had assiduously cultivated down the years, although (not too secretly) his heart had been set on a peerage. He was not to be presented in their Lordships' house, but his retirement dinner was unforgettable.

For many years, Cambridge held regular conferences on criminology and these had become feudal gatherings at which fealty was paid to a liege lord; except that a number of young squires had begun to have their own show, what was to be the York deviancy symposium.

In the paranoid climate of British universities, Radzy was genuinely fearful of the activities of these leftist critics of orthodox criminology and the establishment. Unfortunately, quite a few of them were at his retirement dinner during a conference. Congratulatory messages were read out like wedding telegrams while Radzy, surrounded by the senior home civil service, surveyed the company like a headmaster seeking out absentees on speech day. As he rose to speak, some young squires made an ostentatious exit, but it was not his style to notice such things.

Brilliant as an academic entrepreneur, he was less apt at other things. He was not always good at human relations but there was, in his retirement, a mellowness about him. Some thought it stemmed from guilt, long overdue, for the appalling way in which he had treated junior colleagues.

Carel Weight's portrait of him as a young man conveyed through the eyes a fierce, almost vulpine, impression of a man who knew what he wanted and how to get it. He would have been at home in the courts of Renaissance Italy. It was not in his nature to be a tyrant, for he had too much humanity; he was just uncommonly ill-tempered, especially when he thought that he had been thwarted, when his behaviour degenerated to the level of any departmental bully. He despised weakness in others and respected those with the courage to stand up to his tantrums. Not all succeeded.

In old age, Radzy was forgiving, even to Mannheim, in a generous tribute in the Dictionary of National Biography; Mannheim would never have done the same for him. Those of us whom he described in his account of the events of 1957 as "still young, but gifted and enthusiastic... eager to leave a mark on the future development of the discipline" had a lot to put up with in the years of his ascendancy.

But like him or loathe him, we owe him an immense debt. Personally, I like to think of buying him tea and toast in the celestial version of Brown's Hotel.

His first two marriages ended in divorce. He is survived by his third wife Isolde and a son and daughter from his second marriage.

In old age, Radzy was forgiving, even to Mannheim, in a generous tribute in the Dictionary of National Biography; Mannheim would never have done the same for him. Those of us whom he described in his account of the events of 1957 as "still young, but gifted and enthusiastic... eager to leave a mark on the future development of the discipline" had a lot to put up with in the years of his ascendancy. But like him or loathe him, we owe him an immense debt. Personally, I like to think of buying him tea and toast in the celestial version of Brown's Hotel. His first two marriages ended in divorce. webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: World's oldest person dies
fields.body:
World's oldest person dies

The world's oldest person, Sarah Knauss, died yesterday at the age of 119 at a retirement home in Allentown, Pennsylvania.

Mrs Knauss, who was born in September 1880, died of natural causes just 33 hours before the beginning of the new century. Michael Ellison, New York.

Man charged with killing five

A Cuban immigrant hotel employee was charged with five counts of murder yesterday after a shooting rampage in Tampa, Florida, which four co-workers and a motorist were killed.

Silvio Izquierdo-Leyva, 36, was arrested after the shootings on Thursday at the Radisson Bay Harbour Hotel. His motives remain unclear. Reuters, Tampa

Man survives week lost in Alps

An American who became lost in the Swiss Alps survived for nearly a week in one of Europe's worst storms of the century, Swiss officials said yesterday.

The 23-year-old was found on the Breithorn, near Zermatt, on Thursday after going missing on Christmas Eve. He is being treated for hypothermia in a Bern hospital. AP, Zermatt

Executed PM's body 'found'

An undertaker has found what he believes could be the remains of the prime minister of Grenada, Maurice Bishop, and his cabinet, executed in 1983 in the coup that ended with US military intervention.

Clinton Bailey, whose funeral home has been accused of handling the leaders' bodies, said yesterday that he had found pouches believed to contain the men's burned remains in a local cemetery.

The 17 men charged with the killings claimed US soldiers removed the bodies. AP, St George's

webTitle: President begs forgiveness and bows out

fields.headline: President begs forgiveness and bows out
fields.trailText: Russia entered the new millennium last night braced for a new political era after President Boris Yeltsin announced his immediate resignation and turned over his sweeping powers to the popular prime minister, Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
Russia entered the new millennium last night braced for a new political era after President Boris Yeltsin announced his immediate resignation and turned over his sweeping powers to the popular prime minister, Vladimir Putin.

Eight years after becoming Russia's first ever democratically elected president - a mandate he used to combat and destroy Soviet communism as a political force - Mr Yeltsin went on national television to announce in dignified, if melancholy, terms that he was bowing out.

In the Kremlin, he handed the symbolic and concrete trappings of office to Mr Putin - the seals and chain of the Russian presidency, the briefcase containing the codes and controls for Russia's vast nuclear arsenal, and the pen he has used for the past eight years to sign laws and decrees into force.

Flanked by a Christmas tree for his brief television statement from the Kremlin, Mr Yeltsin, 68, a towering, boisterous and unpredictable presence on the international scene for the past decade, asked Russians' forgiveness for his failings.

He delivered an unequivocal endorsement of Mr Putin, whom he named as his preferred successor when he appointed him prime minister last August.

"I am stepping down early. I understand that I must do that and Russia must enter the new millennium with new politicians, new faces, new intelligent, strong, energetic people," said Mr Yeltsin. "We who have been in power for many years must go... To cling to power for another six months when the country has a strong person worthy of becoming president - why should I stand in his way? Why should I wait?"

The Kremlin machine, cock-a-hoop that the ailing leader had made one of the most politically astute moves of his celebrated career, promptly shifted into overdrive to prepare the Putin succession.

"Yeltsin once again proved that he's the right choice for Russia," crowed Boris Berezovsky, the media mogul and Kremlin insider who has been one of the most formidable manipulators of Russian politics throughout the Yeltsin era.

The president's decision, said Anatoli Chubais, another key Kremlin crony, was "a stroke of genius".

"It was the perfect decision, courageous and profound," he said.

Mr Yeltsin is the first Russian leader to be democratically elected, and his snap resignation has also made him the first to surrender power voluntarily, although it is not clear whether he jumped or was pushed.

There was nothing in his television appearance to suggest anger or forcible resignation. Rather he struck a dignified and melancholy tone, not bragging of his triumphs, but brooding on his failures.

"I want to beg forgiveness for your dreams that never came true," he told 143 million Russian citizens. "I also want to beg forgiveness for not having justified your hopes. And I beg your forgiveness for having failed to jump in one leap from the grey, stagnant totalitarian past to the clear, rich and civilised future," he said. "I am leaving. I've done what I could."

Mr Putin, assuming the sweeping powers of the Russian presidency quickly and smoothly, paid tribute to Mr Yeltsin by signing a decree giving him and his family immunity from prosecution.

For months, the Yeltsin family has been at the centre of corruption allegations. The Swiss construction firm, Mabetex, run by an Albanian bus-inessman, is said to have won lucrative contracts for refurbishing the Kremlin in return for providing, among other alleged bribes, credit cards to Mr Yeltsin and his two daughters.

Mr Putin, 46, riding a wave of unprecedented popularity for a Russian politician on the back of the Chechen war, disingenuously called on his government not to engage in campaigning for the presidency contest in March.

State-controlled television, however, showed the interior minister, Vladimir Rushailo, flanked by the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, declaring: "The successor has been named. It's Putin. We'll fulfil the president's decree."

The elderly centre-left figure and former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov, the extreme nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the Communists' leader Gennady Zyuganov, and the liberals' leader Grigory Yavlinsky, have all declared their intention to contest the presidency.

The official date for an election that had been scheduled to take place next June is to be set by the upper house or Federation Council on January 5.

But the presidential slate could be slimmed down after the impact of yesterday's drama. Mikhail Gorbachev, routed by Mr Yeltsin in 1991, declared his support for Mr Primakov and suggested that all forces on the centre-left should rally behind him.

webTitle: A man whose greatest lovewas power

fields.headline: A man whose greatest lovewas power
fields.standfirst: Flair and ambition were not enough to run a modern revolution
fields.trailText: Boris Yeltsin's unerring instinct for drama has served him well down the years, enabling him to seize the moment and his countrymen's imagination, facing down coup plotters from atop a Moscow tank or reading the riot act to Communist apparatchiks.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow and James Meek
fields.body:
Boris Yeltsin's unerring instinct for drama has served him well down the years, enabling him to seize the moment and his countrymen's imagination, facing down coup plotters from atop a Moscow tank or reading the riot act to Communist apparatchiks.

But yesterday he excelled himself. Seated beside a Christmas tree for what should have been an avuncular set-piece new year message to the nation, Mr Yeltsin did it again. He stunned Moscow, Russia, and the world by announcing he was throwing in the towel after eight years as Russia's first democratically elected president.

A millennium moment filled with magic and mystery.

The scourge of Soviet communism, the darling of the west, the tragi-comic figure who alternated between being a resolute saviour of democracy and a pitiable Kremlin clown departs the leadership of a huge country that is deeply immersed in an identity crisis, insecurity, instability, war, and confusion.

President Yeltsin can claim the credit for destroying Soviet communism, but he also has a lot to answer for. The promise of his early years in power yielded to mass disaffection with his remote and corrupt style of rule.

His economic incompetence, the failure to establish a more solid law-based political system, the cronyism and impetuosity of his increasingly wayward style of rule left Russians in the end contemptuous of the boss in the Kremlin - though not, it seems, of his anointed successor, Vladimir Putin, whom they appear to be embracing eagerly.

The outgoing president yesterday asked the nation for forgiveness for his failings, and in so doing, chalked up another first. Russians are not accustomed to such appeals from their authoritarian rulers.

Mr Yeltsin was marked out by an insatiable determination to take and hold the highest office in the land, and by an appetite for confrontation and change. His great gift was for the fight. In 1991, after becoming Russia's first elected president, he went on famously to defy the tanks of communist putschists bent on toppling the Soviet president, Mikhail Gorbachev.

But his talents were found wanting when it came to creative use of the sweeping powers he secured for himself in the constitution he established in 1993.

That was the watershed year for Mr Yeltsin's controversial reign and the moment many Russian analysts say he betrayed the hopes vested in him as a democrat and power became his raison d'etre. So he turned the Russian army's tanks on what was still a communist parliament and blasted it into dissolution.

Fond of sport, and vodka

"Power is his only love, his only passion. His drug is his attachment to power," says Vyacheslav Kostikov, a former presidential press secretary.

Whether against the 1991 putschists, against Mr Gorbachev, or against the Communists yet again in 1996, the tenacious will to win saw Mr Yeltsin to the top. But once in charge of a huge, complex domain embroiled in revolutionary change, his touch was less than sure.

The democracy he helped to build but also to distort is venal, fragile, unpredictable and boisterous. Perhaps it had to be like that. But maybe not.

Mr Yeltsin was a regular Soviet man, born poor, risen up the career ladder, fond of sport, fond of his family, fond of vodka, sentimental, anxious not to have fewer possessions than his peers, looking out for his friends, and with a world view shaped by the obsessions and omissions of Soviet popular culture.

An ordinary Russian who met the president wouldn't feel awkward about telling him a joke, complaining to him or recommending a folk cold cure. Even while hugely unpopular in the last two years of his reign, Mr Yeltsin never became a target of hate, more of pity and contempt.

If Mr Gorbachev was the midwife of Soviet then Russian democracy, Boris Yeltsin was its first big beneficiary. He will want to go down in the history books as the man who buried more than 70 years of Soviet communism.

It remains an open question how much the massive changes that followed, malign and benign, can be ascribed to Mr Yeltsin, how much is attributable to the radical steps Mr Gorbachev had already taken, and how much was the product of forces beyond anyone's control.

Russians now inhabit a country of 143m people; the USSR - which Mr Yeltsin was instrumental in breaking up to weaken the Soviet president's power - was almost double that.

Others got blame

Back in 1991 when Mr Yeltsin was elected as the Russian president who would see off the Communists, there were still a handful of political prisoners; now they are free, but the crowded, hungry, tuberculosis-ridden prison camps have not been so full of criminals - many convicted for the pettiest of crimes - since Khrushchev's time in the 50s and 60s.

In 1991, the Russian army of 3.2m was respected and feared in the west. The army Mr Yeltsin leaves his successor as commander-in-chief supposedly has 1.2m personnel and is widely disregarded.

During the Yeltsin years, crime soared, and murder became a common method of settling business disputes. The English word "killer", meaning hitman, has become part of Russia's everyday vocabulary. Without constraints, the marriage of corrupt bureaucrats, ruthless racketeers and parasitic businessmen was solemnised.

In 1991, the militarised, deformed Soviet economic giant was already disintegrating, and the embezzlers were already settling to feed on its mines, oil wells and smelters. Mr Yeltsin's rule has seen the Russian economy shrivel to a fraction of its former size, with millions unemployed or working without pay. Millions more were caught up in migrations from dying areas, or independent republics that no longer wanted ethnic Russians.

The system now corresponds to no traditional economic model, medieval in its reliance on payment in kind, primitive in its rapaciousness, modern in its cosmopolitan, opportunistic cross-border trade.

People's lives have changed greatly from the daily round of queuing, exchanging favours and sniffing round the black market. The number of households with cars and video recorders has soared.

Yet one of the saddest sights in Moscow in the week of Mr Yeltsin's resignation has been the search of ordinary, poor Muscovites for a Christmas tree, or rather a new year tree, that they can afford.

In the land of the Siberian fir where the forests stretch for thousands of miles, the Moscow market hawkers are trying to flog Danish and Norwegian trees for $100 a time, so most people forlornly settle for a few sprigs of pine or fir. Such are the new market freedoms.

The battle for democracy in Russia has been only partly won and the parliamentary election two weeks ago that paved the way for yesterday's installation of Vladimir Putin as presidential heir was seriously flawed.

The electoral process has forced many local governors to listen to their citizens' needs. But in other regions, particularly the ethnically based autonomous republics, elections have been a sham, strengthening local tyrants who abuse the trust of their ethnic kin and discriminate against the ethnic Russians.

But democracy is on the way to being taken for granted. So, now, is the right to travel freely: millions have, for the first time in the country's history, been able to see the outside world with their own eyes, beginning to heal the insularity that blighted the USSR.

Looking back over the Yeltsin years, it is hard to escape the conclusion that most of what is positive happened not because of Mr Yeltsin but in spite of him. Most of what is negative, however, happened either because he never bothered to engage in policy - as in the economic collapses that robbed Russians of their savings three times in a row - or because of decisions he took personally.

There is nothing to suggest the president ever thought deeply, let alone understood, basic market mechanisms. He confined himself to hiring, sacking and rehiring aides and ministers, casually hobbling policy initiatives if someone he liked lobbied him against them, and making ringing declarations about the economy which bore no relation to reality.

Whenever anything went disastrously wrong, he blamed the government he himself had appointed, or he simply disappeared.

Economic mayhem and corruption and the absence of the rule of law are the crucial failures of the Yeltsin years. Many of his actions suggest that he believed himself, as president, to be above the law.

It was Boris Yeltsin who ordered the KGB archives closed in 1992 to conceal the crimes of the communist years. It was Boris Yeltsin who illegally dissolved parliament in 1993 and tried to dissolve it again in 1996.

It was Boris Yeltsin who protected scores of powerful friends from criminal investigation. In the twilight years of the presidency he and his immediate family became the subjects of Swiss corruption allegations involving an Albanian businessman alleged to have provided the president and his influential daughter Tatiana with western credit cards in return for lucrative contracts.

It was Boris Yeltsin who ordered the military campaign, not once but twice, to bring the breakaway republic of Chechnya into line, and then lied and lied again about what was taking place there.

The Yeltsin family cruised into office like lottery winners, with their first obligations to themselves, their next to their friends, associates and hangers-on, and their last, absent-mindedly, to the outer circle, the people.

It was all chance

One of the Yeltsins' first moves was to strip the furniture and kitchen fittings out of Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev's flat and move it to their own dacha.

Besides drinking, hunting and lounging in the sauna with his buddies, Mr Yeltsin had a childlike love of mischief and gadgets. He would pinch female aides. He used to play the spoons, using the bald heads of anyone nearby. He threw his press secretary, Mr Kostikov, off a riverboat on the Volga.

Apart from the nuclear "button", he was given another button, for when he fell ill and needed to get help. He began summoning doctors all the time, just for fun. A few months after the 1991 coup attempt, with Russia in chaos, Mr Yeltsin was off playing tennis four or five times a week.

"Experts work out entire theories, analyse mythical chains of Kremlin relationships, to logically explain this or that staff appointment," wrote his former bodyguard Alexander Korzhakov in his memoirs. "But there was and is no theory ... since 1991 people casually tumbled into positions of power and, with equal ease, tumbled out. And it wasn't even the personal preferences of Mr Yeltsin ... It was all a matter of chance."

1955 Graduates as construction engineer.

1961 Joins Communist party, becoming Sverdlovsk regional boss in 1976 and deputy of USSR supreme soviet.

1986 Joins Gorbachev's politburo. Shows populist skills by refusing party limousines and using underground. Begins anti-Gorbachev campaign.

1987 Sacked by Gorbachev, falls into depression and has heart attack. Later apologises for criticism of party.

1990 Elected to Russian parliament; becomes chairman and quits party.

1991 Russian parliament declares Russian sovereignty. Yeltsin wins presidential election easily. Defeats attempted coup by hardline communists in August. In December declares Soviet Union defunct. Soviet flag lowered from Kremlin on December 25.

1992 Government abolishes price controls and begins privatisation. Inflation skyrockets. Yeltsin regularly "disappears" to country dachas, fuelling rumours about his health and heavy drinking.

1993 Illegally dissolves parliament and calls election and referendum on new constitution to transfer most of parliament's powers to president. Parliament impeaches Yeltsin. He bombs parliament into submission and arrests its main leaders. Hundreds killed. In December parliamentary elections anti-Yeltsin candidates win majority of seats.

1994 Fails to disembark at Shannon airport for meeting with Irish prime minis ter. Bodyguard later says Yeltsin was drunk. Orders troops into Chechnya after separatists declare independence, starting 21-month war that kills about 100,000 and ends in humiliation for Russian army.

1995 Twice hospitalised with heart problems. Pro-Yeltsin parties suffer in parliamentary elections.

1996 Popularity plummets as economy sinks. Rediscovers populist skills in election campaign, travelling across country and dancing at rock concert in Moscow. Assisted by financial and media power of the oligarchs he reverses opinion polls but later suffers heart attacks. Has quintuple bypass operation.

1997 Health remains poor. Stock market booms but real economy fails to grow.

1998 Sacks long-serving prime minister Viktor Chernomyrdin. Appoints Sergei Kiriyenko, 35, but sacks him five months later and appoints Chernomyrdin acting prime minster as oil price fall sparks stock market crash. Rouble devalued and government defaults on foreign debt. IMF refuses bailout. Yevgeny Primakov appinted prime minster after parliament refuses to accept Chernomyrdin. Yeltsin becomes increasingly isolated.

1999 After more health problems, emerges in May to sack Primakov. Appoints Sergei Stepashin as premier. Survives impeachment vote over Chechnya. In August sacks Stepashin, and appoints Vladimir Putin as new prime minister. Clashes in Dagestan and bombings in Russian cities provoke new Chechen war, boosting Putin's popularity.

Dec 31 Quits, names Putin president.

webTitle: Jubilation as freed hostages return home

fields.headline: Jubilation as freed hostages return home
fields.standfirst:
India faces accusations of climbdown as it trades three jailed militants for lives of airline passengers
More about the Indian Airlines hijacking
fields.trailText: Some beaming and waving their arms over their heads, others moving in a slow shuffle, the 155 mostly Indian passengers who had been held hostage on a jet for a week arrived home at the international airport in New Delhi.
fields.body:
Some beaming and waving their arms over their heads, others moving in a slow shuffle, the 155 mostly Indian passengers who had been held hostage on a jet for a week arrived home at the international airport in New Delhi.

They were greeted by relatives amid tumultuous scenes, in which one mother fainted and children rushed forward to present them with bouquets of flowers, after flying in from the southern Afghan city of Kandahar at 9pm last night.

The prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, was also at the airport to greet them. His government arranged the hostages' freedom by releasing from prison three men convicted of terrorism-related charges in connection with Kashmir, the Himalayan region claimed by both India and Pakistan.

The hostages stank and were ashen-faced but appeared unharmed after their ordeal, which began on Christmas Eve when a flight from Katmandu was hijacked by five armed men. The plane then touched down in Amritsar, Lahore in Pakistan and Dubai before landing in Kandahar. "I'm on top of the world," said Viten Menon, as his family members cheered.

For others the emotions were mixed. "Eight days in a fucking plane - how do you think I feel?" one middle-aged man snapped. "This government has let us down. They are a bunch of jokers."

Most of the hostages said they had been treated fairly well despite difficult conditions on the Indian Airlines jet. But it emerged that not all of them had known of the killing of one of their number, Rippan Katyal, a 25-year-old bridegroom whose throat was slit after he disobeyed orders not to look at the hijackers.

According to one woman, their captors were nervous and brutal in the first days of their captivity.

"If anyone raised their heads they would start kicking us but towards the end they were nice," Kanika Narthani said. "Then when the deal suddenly crashed they said they would begin killing us. But something just happened all of a sudden and within a split second they were very happy.

"The conditions [on the plane] were inhuman beyond words."

Utpal Brar, whose brother S Brar was taken off the plane briefly on Thursday to be treated in a Kandahar hospital for a stomach ailment, said: "We are feeling very great that all the hostages are coming home before the millennium starts. It has been a very painful experience these last eight days."

But it has been even more painful for the Indian government, as their concession to the hijackers will inevitably been seen as a humiliating surrender to the militants.

In announcing the deal, India's national security adviser, Brajesh Mishra, tried to deflect criticism. "It is the best one could achieve," he said.

In the deal, brokered by the Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, the three militants were flown into Kandahar and the hijackers were then permitted to leave with them for an undisclosed destination.

The first inkling of a breakthrough came at 2am Indian time when Mushtaq Ahmed Zargar, the sole Indian among the trio of freed militants, was transferred from Srinagar prison into army custody.

Zargar, the Kashmiri who founded the al-Ummar Mojahedin organisation, was flown south to Jammu to join the real prize of this exchange, Maulana Mohammed Massoud Azhar, the Pakistani-born preacher who is a secretary general of the Harkat-ul- Mojahedin.

From Delhi's Tihar jail, they brought Syed Abdul Ahmed Sheikh, a former student of the London School of Economics who was arrested in October 1994 after kidnapping three western tourists and holding them hostage in an abandoned home.

After the militants were brought to Afghanistan, the hijackers, faces shrouded in the balaclavas they have worn throughout the crisis, descended the steps of the Airbus, and handed over their pistols to guards of the ruling Taliban militia.

Within minutes, they and the three militants were whisked out of sight in Taliban pick-up trucks. Their identities and their destination remains a mystery. The Taliban has set a 10-hour deadline for the hijackers and the freed militants to leave Afghanistan.

"If they do not leave Afghanistan, we will force them," the Taliban foreign minister, Abdul Wakil Muttawakil, told a news conference yesterday.

Despite India's apparent climbdown, Mr Singh remained upbeat. He said yesterday: "There is no bowing to terrorism" and added the release of the prisoners had been purely in order to protect the lives of the hostages.

"I came here in a purely humanitarian capacity," he said.

In his new year address to the country yesterday, Mr Vajpayee vowed to spare no effort in battling "diabolical and evil" terrorism.

"India shall not spare any effort to thwart the phenomenon of terrorism itself," he said in his first speech since the hostage drama came to an end.

"As you are aware, the hijackers had demanded the release of 36 terrorists. We were able to substantially scale down their demand."

Mr Vajpayee said that in dealing with the hijackers New Delhi had been guided only by concern for the safety of the passengers and the crew, and the long-term, overall interests of the country.

"Surely the time has come for the world to confront this evil, to act in concert and crush it," he said. "India shall join hands across nations to rid the world of this crime against humanity."

"Let this be our first resolution for the new century."

webTitle: 'My main job has been done; Russia must enter the new millennium with new faces'

fields.headline: 'My main job has been done; Russia must enter the new millennium with new faces'
fields.trailText: Following are extracts from Boris Yeltsin's televised resignation statement.
fields.body:
Following are extracts from Boris Yeltsin's televised resignation statement.

Dear friends, today I am addressing you for the last time as Russian president. On the last day of the century, I am retiring.

Many times I have heard it said: Yeltsin will try to hold on to power, he won't hand it over. That is lies.

I always said I would not take a single step away from the constitution, that the duma elections should take place within the constitutional timescale. This has happened. And likewise, I would have liked the presidential elections to have taken place on schedule in June 2000.

That was very important for Russia - we were creating a vital precedent of a civilised, voluntary handover of power from one president to another, newly elected one. And yet, I have taken a different decision. I am standing down earlier than scheduled.

Russia must enter the new millennium with new politicians, new faces, intelligent, strong and energetic people. Those of us who have been in power for many years must go.

I have done the main job of my life. Russia will never return to the past. I must not stand in the way of the natural progress of history.

Why hold on to power for another six months when the country has a strong person, fit to be president. Why should I stand in his way? This is not me.

Today, on this incredibly important day for me, I want to ask you for forgiveness, because many of our hopes have not come true, because what we thought would be easy turned out to be painfully difficult. I ask you to forgive me for not fulfilling some hopes of those people who believed that we would be able to jump from the totalitarian past into a bright, rich and civilised future in one go.

I myself believed this. But it could not be done in one fell swoop. In some respects I was too naive. Some problems were too complex. We struggled on through mistakes and failures. Many people experienced upheavals in their lives. But I want you to know that I never said this would be easy.

Today it is important for me to tell you I also experienced the pain which each of you experienced. I experienced it in my heart, with sleepless nights, agonising over what needed to be done to ensure people lived more easily and better. I did not have any objective more important than that.

I am leaving. I have done everything I could. I am not leaving because of my health, but because of all the problems taken together. A new generation is taking my place, the generation of those who can do more and do it better.

In accordance with the constitution, I have signed a decree entrusting the duties of president to prime minister Vladimir Putin.

For the next three months - again in accordance with the constitution - he will be head of state. Presidential elections will be held in three months' time. I have no doubt what choice you will make at the end of March 2000.

webTitle: Leaders pay their tributes to key figure in the demolition of communism

fields.headline: Leaders pay their tributes to key figure in the demolition of communism
fields.standfirst: World Eyes are already fixed on heir
fields.trailText: Most foreign governments were caught by surprise and their leaders - or their writers of speeches and soundbites - scrambled to put together some thoughts.
fields.body:
Most foreign governments were caught by surprise and their leaders - or their writers of speeches and soundbites - scrambled to put together some thoughts.

Many praised President Yeltsin for leading Russia away from communism but also expressed hope that a new leader might improve the Kremlin's strained relations with the west.

"Boris Yeltsin has played a crucial role in the history of Russia," Tony Blair said in a short statement put out by Downing Street.

"He has steered his country through a most difficult and painful transition from communism to democracy ... We now look forward to the presidential elections when the Russian people will decide on Boris Yeltsin's successor and take a further step towards embedding the democratic process."

From the White House in Washington, President Clinton said: "I liked him because he was always forthright with me." He added: "He always did exactly what he said he would do. And he was willing to take chances to try to improve our relationship."

After a brief pause, Mr Clinton said: "I liked him because he deplored communism."

Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany praised Mr Yeltsin for leading Russia toward democracy.

But, he said in a tougher vein, he now "expects that the war in Chechnya and the suffering of the people will come to a speedy end, and will clear away the growing sense of crisis that has burdened Russia's relations with us and with the world."

The French President, Jacques Chirac, wrote a farewell letter to Mr Yeltsin, and another congratulating his heir, Vladimir Putin.

The comments of a number of world leaders or their ministers gave little hint that they might see Mr Putin as a front man for continued rule by the Yeltsin circle.

One of the most fulsome was the Japanese prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, who was quoted as saying that Mr Putin struck him as "a fearless and aggress-ive leader".

Portugal and Spain also expressed hopes that the acting president would improve handling of foreign affairs.

"It is to be hoped that the new person in charge of the presidency demonstrates greater agility in foreign affairs and is able to listen to and interpret the voice of the international community in problems like Chechnya which require more constructive attitudes by Russia," said a statement from the foreign ministry in Lisbon, which took over the six-month rotating presidency of the European Union at midnight.

The foreign minister of Norway, Knut Vollebaek - who is chairman of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development - said that while the war in Chechnya had clouded the last months of his presidency, Mr Yeltsin deserved praise as Russia's first popularly elected president.

Finland, which held the EU presidency until last night, also paid tribute to Mr Yeltsin's historically significant role in Russia, as did the leaders of the former Soviet republics of Georgia, Armenia and Ukraine. Along with Poland and Austria, they praised the departing leader for opening up his country to democracy.

In South Africa, a spokesman for the department of foreign affairs said that Mr Yeltsin's democratic legacy was "indicative of the progress that humanity is making".

As for the dramatic way in which the resignation was sprung on the Russian people and the world, many said that was vintage Yeltsin.

webTitle: Still to come: the second coming

fields.headline: Still to come: the second coming
fields.standfirst: Jerusalem: No Messiah but no apocalypse either in cradle of Christianity
fields.trailText: He didn't turn up. Billions of people were born, loved, prayed, suffered, fought and died. Empires rose and fell, fortunes were won and lost, cities were built and destroyed over centuries, all in the half-expectation that one day, in this dusty cluster of flatroofed houses and squat pines on a hill overlooking Jerusalem, Jesus would come back and tell them whether it had been worth it.
fields.byline: James Meek  on the Mount of Olives, Jerusalem
fields.body:
He didn't turn up. Billions of people were born, loved, prayed, suffered, fought and died. Empires rose and fell, fortunes were won and lost, cities were built and destroyed over centuries, all in the half-expectation that one day, in this dusty cluster of flatroofed houses and squat pines on a hill overlooking Jerusalem, Jesus would come back and tell them whether it had been worth it.

Last night, as the clock of the years reached 2000 since he was born, the Mount of Olives was warm, still and thick with police.

There was no Messiah.

There was no splitting of the mount, as foretold in the book of Zechariah. There were no heavenly trumpets, no new famines, pestilences or earthquakes as Jesus was quoted as promising in Matthew. There was no blood-red moon, no bottomless pit, no red dragon as foretold in Revelation. There was no beast, apart from a phlegmatic camel giving rides to tourists.

There was no sign either of the Christian apocalypse cults of whom a thousand devilries had been feared: they would throw themselves off steeples, they would set themselves alight, they would run amok with weapons, they would blow up the sealed Golden Gate through the walls of the old city of Jerusalem, they would hurl pigs' heads into the sacred precincts of Islam's Dome of the Rock, they would go wild in Megiddo, site of the biblical Armageddon.

The scale of things not happening was so great that it was easy to forget the real millennium marvel in the cityscape spread out below the mount - that, 2000 years on from the birth of the child who was to challenge the religion of the Jews here, and was later to be challenged by the rise of Islam, these three faiths have survived into the age of genetic codebreaking and artificial intelligence, and are still, mistrustfully, reluctantly, sharing Jerusalem.

The clash of calendars yesterday was fateful. The Christians' millennium eve coincided with the Jewish sabbath, when observant Jews are forbidden to work, drive, cook or use electricity. Worse, it coincided with the last Friday of Ramadan, when an estimated 400,000 Muslims flood into the old city to pray at the Al-Aqsa mosque, virtually back to back with the Jewish holy of holies, the Wailing Wall.

And then there was the Y2K bug. The authorities won Sabbath exemptions to deploy an extra 12,000 troops, police, volunteers and border guards in case of trouble.

Temple Mount was - and will remain throughout 2000 and beyond - the feared flashpoint. The Dome of the Rock, the third holiest shrine in Islam, and Al-Aqsa lie there, but it is also sacred to Jews as the site of their long-destroyed temple and presumed resting place of the Ark of the Covenant. Some fundamentalist Christians believe that Christ will not return until the dome, Jerusalem's best-known landmark, is demolished and the Jewish temple rebuilt.

Web surfers watching Messiahcam yesterday, a live internet camera set up by the Hereford-based evangelical group Daystar International to watch the Golden Gate for the Messiah's return, would not have seen Jesus, but would have seen thousands of Muslims surging across Temple Mount to pray. For Muslims yesterday was not 1999, but 1420.

"The Muslims also believe the Messiah is coming back," said Christine Darg, who heads Daystar in Hereford. "Their interpretation is different, but it's interesting they have him in their theology."

Jews (current year: 5760 - an ahead-of-the-curve rabbi has organised a Y6K party for tonight) also believe in a Messiah. That's why what lies between the Mount of Olives and the old city ramparts is the world's most exclusive Jewish cemetery. Robert Maxwell lies there, waiting for the Messiah to come down the mount and lead him and the others through the Golden Gate.

Was anyone really expecting Jesus? Israel has already deported a couple of dozen who allegedly were, although there was never any evidence that they planned to hasten his coming with violence. The latest victim of Israeli anxiety was an American born-again Christian called Bobby Bible, uplifted from the Mount of Olives Hotel on Thursday. He had hoped to be lifted up to heaven yesterday but now appears set to be lifted by Boeing to the States.

The idea that Christ will return is a basic tenet of Christianity, and the early 21st century is seen by many as a likely time. But not today. Maybe not tomorrow, either. If Christians have learned anything, it is to swallow disappointment and not to get hung up on precision.

"I do believe that we are in these days when it's very possible for the Lord to return, but what's so sad is people saying he's going to return on new year's eve," said Mrs Darg. "Then of course it doesn't happen. They've created a credibility problem."

In the old city, as Israeli soldiers screened the invisible boundary between the Jewish quarter and the thick flow of Muslims heading for Al-Aqsa, the Christian quarter was quiet. It means the 2000th birthday of Jesus," said Father Micallef, a Maltese Franciscan friar working in the Church of the Holy Sephulchre, supposed site of Christ's crucifixion. The church was almost empty. "But it doesn't mean it's the end of time or anything like that. He will come again, but let's stick to what he said himself: nobody knows when."

Empires rose and fell, fortunes were won and lost, cities were built and destroyed over centuries, all in the half-expectation that one day, in this dusty cluster of flatroofed houses and squat pines on a hill overlooking Jerusalem, Jesus would come back and tell them whether it had been worth it. There was no splitting of the mount, as foretold in the book of Zechariah. There were no heavenly trumpets, no new famines, pestilences or earthquakes as Jesus was quoted as promising in Matthew. webTitle: End of the Yeltsin era

fields.headline: End of the Yeltsin era
fields.trailText: Boris Yeltsin stunned Russia and the world by using his traditional new year message to announce his resignation and hand his sweeping powers, including the nuclear suitcase, to prime minister Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
Boris Yeltsin stunned Russia and the world by using his traditional new year message to announce his resignation and hand his sweeping powers, including the nuclear suitcase, to prime minister Vladimir Putin.

Looking grim and melancholy, Mr Yeltsin used his address to apologise to the nation. He said: "I want to beg forgiveness for your dreams that never came true."

But he gave a ringing endorsement of Mr Putin, 46, who is now in pole position for the presidential elections on March 26. He said: "To cling to power for another six months when the country has a strong person worthy of becoming president - why should I stand in his way?"

In the Kremlin, he handed the trappings of office to Mr Putin - the seals and chain of the Russian presidency and the case containing the codes for Russia's nuclear arsenal.

In return, Mr Putin's first move as acting president was to sign a decree granting Mr Yeltsin, who has been besieged by allegations of corruption, immunity from prosecution.

In Washington, President Bill Clinton paid tribute to Mr Yeltsin for dismantling the communist system and putting a democratic structure in place.

"I liked him because he was always forthright with me," Mr Clinton said. "He was willing to take chances to try to improve our relationship."

The resignation came less than two weeks after an unexpectedly good performance by pro-Putin centrist parties in parliamentary elections.

Mr Putin's strong handling of the war in Chechnya and no-nonsense manner has appealed to many Russians, who want strong leadership to tackle the nation's enormous economic, political and social problems.

Mr Putin said there would be no change in government policies, including foreign relations. But he said efforts to strengthen the weakened military would continue.

webTitle: Airline hostages freed

fields.headline: Airline hostages freed
fields.trailText: The first of 155 hostages freed from a hijacked Indian Airlines plane landed to tumultuous scenes at New Delhi airport last night after a week-long ordeal that spanned five countries and cost a new groom his life.
fields.body:
The first of 155 hostages freed from a hijacked Indian Airlines plane landed to tumultuous scenes at New Delhi airport last night after a week-long ordeal that spanned five countries and cost a new groom his life.

The passengers looked weary as children rushed forward with flowers and the mother of one hostage fainted. One man stooped down and kissed the ground.

Waiting relatives threw bouquets into the air and garlanded some of the passengers as they arrived from the southern Afghanistan city of Kandahar where their plane had been held. Some of the hostages had to be supported to walk, but still waved to the crowd.

All passengers and crew walked to freedom earlier after India agreed to the hijackers' demands to free three Kashmiri militants from jail and allow them to walk away, an act that caused a sizeable dent in national pride.

The masked hijackers, who slit the throat of a newly married man last weekend, left the plane and drove into Kandahar in a deal overseen by Indian foreign minister Jaswant Singh. They had commandeered the Indian Airlines plane on Christmas Eve en route from Nepal to New Delhi.

Their destination last night was a mystery but the closest country with ties to Kashmir is Pakistan. However, a spokesman for Pakistan's military government said in Islamabad last night that he doubted the hijackers were on their way to his country. Afghanistan's Taliban movement said it would force the hijackers and freed militants to leave Afghanistan if they did not heed a 10-hour deadline to quit.

webTitle: Boris Yeltsin's masterstroke - to boldly go

fields.headline: Boris Yeltsin's masterstroke - to boldly go
fields.standfirst: Putin's contrived TV image as a war leader is the key to this ploy
fields.trailText: The bold gesture was always the hallmark of Boris Yeltsin's career, and in the manner of his leaving Russia's presidency he has struck it once again. His sudden retirement confounds the diplomatic wisdom. Most western embassies in Moscow had been arguing that Yeltsin would serve out his time to the last minute.
fields.body:
The bold gesture was always the hallmark of Boris Yeltsin's career, and in the manner of his leaving Russia's presidency he has struck it once again. His sudden retirement confounds the diplomatic wisdom. Most western embassies in Moscow had been arguing that Yeltsin would serve out his time to the last minute.

Partly to flatter him, and partly to forestall any temptation to cancel the democratic process, they regularly argued that his great and final achievement would be to serve out his time until the elections of summer 2000 and hand power peacefully to a successor on the constitutionally appointed day.

But there was always another option - the "abrupt resignation" theory. When I first reported it last September, the date which Kremlin insiders were hinting at was November 7.

They linked it mischievously to the anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. The aim, then as now, was the same. It would give Prime Minister Vladimir Putin three months to serve as acting president and build up an image as a powerful incumbent.

It would require an early presidential election and give opposition candidates little time to get organised.

In those September days Putin was still an almost unknown figure who had only just been plucked out of obscurity as Russia's domestic spy chief. So Yeltsin's closest advisers, the men known as the "family", delayed the abrupt resignation while they developed a new card, war in Chechnya.

It was a gamble of enormous proportions, a typical Yeltsin masterstroke, though this time it has to be assumed he was no longer the lone or leading player. His frequent collapses in recent weeks show how much he now relies on a team of cronies to help him.

Building on their tight control of television news and the Russian military's apparent success in the northern Caucasus, Yeltsin and his allies managed to launch Putin into orbit as a tough-talking war leader. Last month's Duma elections showed he could be a powerful vote-winner, able to defeat every faction except the communists.

Now they have clearly decided to exploit the momentum, secure in the knowledge that in any head-to-head contest between Putin and the communist candidate, the Kremlin's man will again have the advantage of television bias and be sure to win.

Acting president Putin may not even have to issue an amnesty from criminal sanctions for Yeltsin and his family. Once in power in the Kremlin, Putin will be able to ensure that the prosecutors never take up any charges of corruption against Yeltsin. The man who has so often seemed to be nose-diving towards disaster will be safe again, and this time for ever.

Y eltsin's career has been marked by seven symbolic moments. His dramatic resignation from the Soviet Communist party as he walked out of its Congress in July 1990 fatally wounded its already shaky authority. In the glare of publicity Yeltsin was throwing down the gauntlet and announcing that Mikhail Gorbachev's hopes of reforming the party were over.

Six months later, as hardliners in the army, the KGB and the party leadership mounted mini-coups in Latvia and Lithuania to try to block the Baltic republic's drive for independence, Yeltsin called on Russian troops to mutiny and flew to the region to show his solidarity with the Baltic leaders.

In August 1991, when the by now desperate hardliners launched a larger coup in Moscow itself, it was Yeltsin's resistance which turned the tide.

These were moments of great radicalism. Yet, perhaps more than with any other contemporary world politician, Yeltsin's actions were a mixture of personal ambition and historic destiny. His primary motive was always his determination to remove Gorbachev. If that meant destroying the Communist party and the Soviet Union, so be it. The driving energy was power rather than principle.

The big prize followed naturally when in December 1991 Yeltsin conspired with the leaders of Ukraine and Belarus to pronounce the Soviet Union dead. Gorbachev had no choice but to resign, and Yeltsin was supreme master of the Kremlin.

Yet, once he was in command, his failings soon became apparent. By temperament, instinct, and experience Yeltsin was a destroyer, not a builder. He was a master tactician, but a miserable strategist. He failed the two biggest tests of a democrat, the ability to compromise with opponents and the need to take responsibility for decisions.

The three symbolic moments of his time in office were proof of that. In September 1993 after months of resistance to his economic shock therapy when the same MPs who had made him executive president now called for a slowdown in privatisation, the maintenance of some form of regulation of the market, and protection of the welfare system, Yeltsin broke the constitution and suspended parliament.

Ten days later he ordered tanks to shell them out of the building. In August 1998 when his young prime minister's market mismanagement led to the rouble's collapse and a default on Russia's debts, Yeltsin failed to take the blame. He simply disappeared.

Now, finally, in his choice of early resignation the burly bruiser has shown his spots again. His retirement is not an actual violation of the constitution but it is a way of using it creatively for narrow personal advantage.

It leaves two ironies. Yeltsin has gone peacefully, but not in peace. It took a cynically conceived and brutally conducted war to create the platform for him to feel safe enough to go. And he is not the first Russian in history to hand power in calmness and dignity to a successor, since Gorbachev already did that in December 1991.

Historians will long debate which of the two men did most to change Russia over the past 15 years. Politically, the big strides towards a multi-party system and the democratic freedoms came under Gorbachev. Yeltsin prodded and provoked to make them faster, but Gorbachev was the one who did the lion's share.

Economically, it was Yeltsin who made the biggest changes. But the sorry part of Yeltsin's legacy is that so many Russians feel he took the fast and corruptly low road to the market instead of finding the gradualism and sensitivity which Russia in this now dead century has, sadly, never had.
