webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Shropshire
fields.trailText: What a spot to find yourself in on the shortest day of the year, high on the southern side of Hodre Hill overlooking the narrow valley of the River Redlake. Up here above the hamlet of Chapel Lawn is the ancient hanging oak wood called Bryneddin Wood. Near its top grows the   solitary Bryneddin Pine - a Scots pine planted soon after the dawning of the 20th century - which stands out conspicuously when seen from the opposite hillside below the iron age hill fort of Caer Caradoc (1,321ft).
fields.body:
What a spot to find yourself in on the shortest day of the year, high on the southern side of Hodre Hill overlooking the narrow valley of the River Redlake. Up here above the hamlet of Chapel Lawn is the ancient hanging oak wood called Bryneddin Wood. Near its top grows the solitary Bryneddin Pine - a Scots pine planted soon after the dawning of the 20th century - which stands out conspicuously when seen from the opposite hillside below the iron age hill fort of Caer Caradoc (1,321ft).

On clear winter afternoons the lowering sun casts the shadow of Caer Caradoc across the southern flank of Hodre Hill. And on the shortest day of the year the tip of this Caer Caradoc shadow just manages to touch the foot of the Bryneddin Pine. In that delightful informative arboriculturist's bible, The Trees of Shropshire (Airlife, 1986), Andrew Morton calls it an "inspired piece of planting" and points out that why this tree came to be there will probably remain a mystery.

We came up the slantwise "rack" (track used for access and hauling out the felled trees that villagers had the right to) that has reverted to a narrow path through the oaks and soon found our pine at the very eastern end of the wood. Here was a winter view to vie with the best in the Welsh Marches, of crumpled hills and the silent valley of the little Redlake in the last light of midwinter day.

Caer Caradoc (the shadow-caster) stood half a mile distant across the gloomy dale, its gently convex summit ringed by the prehistoric earthwork. A curl of silver smoke rose from a riverside cottage but we saw no other sign of human activity. As we peered down the valley, to the south-east, a small flock of rooks crossed towards Bucknell Hill, heading home after a short day's foraging in the turned red soil of some lonely field near Offa's Dyke.

Then we were feeling our way down in the velvet dark by the lane at Pentre Hodre and so down to Bryncalled. An orange light flickered in a cottage window, a tawny owl called from the depths of Bull Wood across the river, then everything settled down for the longest night of the year.

webTitle: Y2K force outstrips single currency operation

fields.headline: Y2K force outstrips single currency operation
fields.trailText: The Corporation of London, the City's local authority, said the 60,000 workers in the financial district over the holiday would be more than double the number who worked last new year when the European single currency was introduced, writes Jill Treanor .
fields.body:
The Corporation of London, the City's local authority, said the 60,000 workers in the financial district over the holiday would be more than double the number who worked last new year when the European single currency was introduced, writes Jill Treanor .

While the euro conversion was a good dry run, Paul Eskriett, security and contingency planning adviser at the corporation, said it failed to reach the magnitude faced by computer experts this year as every firm is affected by the millennium bug.

The celebrations at the Millennium Dome and along the river on the edge of the City meant the corporation could not ease parking restrictions to make it easier for essential staff to get to work.

Firms had required staff to go into the office rather than be put on standby be cause of the travel problems. Healthy bonus payments meant that there was no shortage of volunteers to work through the holiday.

In case of problems in the distribution of cash, the Bank of England has stashed an additional £7bn in secret locations around the country to ensure that hole-in-the-wall cash machines do not run out.

The Bank has the ability to release £50bn of cash into circulation over the holiday period, the equivalent of £1,000 for every man, woman and child and nearly double the amount in the system last Christmas.

Fears that shoppers would stockpile cash have so far proved unfounded. Consumers have been using debit cards rather than cash. Only £1m of the £7bn cash pile - equivalent to 20p per person - has been withdrawn so far.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: HSBC clinches Republic deal
fields.body:
HSBC clinches Republic deal

HSBC yesterday completed the long-awaited purchase of Republic National Bank of New York and Safra Republic Holdings for £6.15bn. The deal has been held up for months while the bank sought regulatory approval in the US, Europe and Japan.

The deal looked to be on the rocks last month when Edmund Safra, the founder of Republic, was killed in his Monaco home. A spokesman said the US bank would "fit with HSBC's businesses".

The deal doubles HSBC's private banking business to 55,000 clients with $120bn funds under management. It will also have the third-largest branch network in New York State.

Red Christmas for e-commerce

Retailers offering online sales suffered £75m of operating losses at Christmas despite estimated internet sales of over £200m, according to a report by consultancy E-Insight. Online discounting, heavy marketing costs, and inefficient order processing made for a costly e-Christmas, especially for conventional retailers dabbling with internet trading, E-Insight said.

The analysis shows that the earnings models of start-up e-commerce ventures in the UK and US led to estimated losses of 35%-45% of internet sales in 1999 with established high street players suffering further losses.

webTitle: Now we are getting down to business

fields.headline: Now we are getting down to business
fields.standfirst: Ugly, exciting new era has dawned
fields.trailText: The evidence is splattered all over our daily lives. In Bradford, Margaret, forty-ish and until three months ago deputy manager at a local Laura Ashley, is now deep into Vocalis plc, £3,000 flying on the promise of a breakthrough in speech recognition technology.
fields.body:
The evidence is splattered all over our daily lives. In Bradford, Margaret, forty-ish and until three months ago deputy manager at a local Laura Ashley, is now deep into Vocalis plc, £3,000 flying on the promise of a breakthrough in speech recognition technology.

In London's West End, at a drinkery called Soho House, the queue for the lone trap in the gents is five deep on a Wednesday night, and the jittery looks on the faces of these five late-twentysomethings has nothing to do with nature's call. They are consuming, conspicuously.

Three or four miles east, down a twist of stairs off Worship Street, three men are standing at a bar guffawing. Not one is under 50 and all three are drunk. Two describe themselves as stockbrokers, the other is a corporate financier, and until last autumn all three thought they were past it, washed-up on the fringes of the great City of London. Now they're havin' it off.

This is some of the evidence of change in the world of business and finance, and it's none too pretty. But then watching this country's economy, the British way of doing business, being tipped on its side was never going to be that easy on the eye.

Commentators noticed the change as it began to grip this country a little over a year ago. We'd seen the same thing in the US and found it fascinating. We thought Britain would follow, but in a restrained, British way. When the reality proved to be decidedly un-British our initial reaction was to try to soften it with traditional metaphors. Bubbles, slumps, calls for regulation, images of 1929, the dangers of leverage, and so on.

The warnings were, and will continue to be, relevant. But in truth we've been looking for glitches and cracks and scams when we should have been spending our time grappling with something much bigger, something much more intense. There has been a seismic shift in the way that business operates, in the way that wealth is created and in the way it is destroyed. And we thought it was just a story about technology.

The change now is about individuals taking control of their working lives and realising, crucially, that their industry and creativity has a real worth which can be applied in a tangible way. High-falutin' stuff, perhaps. But just look around your own office, or turn on the TV/radio, or even boot up that bloody machine.

Michael Lewis, in his new book on the life of Netscape founder Jim Clark, identifies this as a byproduct of the search for the New New Thing. He chronicles how a bunch of software engineers woke up one day and set about ransacking the boardrooms of corporate America.

It's not just about money, although that is important. And it's not ephemeral, like the world of Liars' Poker, Mr Lewis's portrait of 80s market decadence. This time his subject matter is shifting the business horizon and then keeping it in motion - for all we know, for ever. It is a good book. Do read it. So in Britain we are watching decades of corporate nonsense being put to the torch. The white-gloved service in the directors' dining room at Marks & Spencer's Baker Street HQ has gone. The head of the Financial Times' Lex column has just said sod it, I'm off. A couple of e-sloanes have just put a thousand travel bucket shops out of business.

This is not about futurology, or gadgets, or a vision thing, although the technology has had something to do with it. Nick Scheele, the head of Ford Europe, talked in a casual way a couple of months ago about how the application of technology to his company's supply chain would free about £140bn within a few years. That's billions, not millions, and there were signs of angst on Mr Scheele's face as he discussed the figures - perhaps because the only destiny he could see for all this money was the customers. Cars just got cheaper.

But what about Margaret, the five blokes in the queue at Soho House and the three older City guys slapping each other's backs? It is difficult to impose maturity, whatever the age of the subject, as any parent will tell you. Britain's financial regulators espouse a rule that says they are not there to protect a fool from losing his or her money but simply to protect a reasonable man or woman from being made to look a fool.

As for defining the fool in all of this, the regulators are looking as dumb-struck as the rest of us. Betting your month's salary on a share when you are not sure the company exists is stupid. Snorting cocaine is costly and dangerous. As for the alleged professionals of the City, ripping off an investment client is plain criminal.

The markets will crash. It might be really big, seismic stuff. But for now there is such a surge of adrenaline, a sense of empowerment, that warning about the dangers of travelling too fast sounds dull, a croak from the past.

So for now let's just say bye-bye to the Old Old Thing and see what happens next.

webTitle: Rachel Anderson The only female Fifa-registered agent

fields.headline: Rachel Anderson The only female Fifa-registered agent
fields.body: I hope the powers- that-be will limit the amount of foreign players in English clubs' squads. They already do it surreptitiously in Europe and I think the current situation is making our national team sub-standard. I also worry about the survival of some of our league clubs - I believe within five or 10 years we'll lose 20% of them. There's so much hype and nonsense in the game, and meanwhile most clubs can't even make ends meet. For example, we'll probably end up with only one team in Sheffield. Oh, and I'd really like England to become a nation that embraces success rather than always knocking it.

webTitle: Ron Atkinson

fields.headline: Ron Atkinson
fields.trailText: I hope the new millennium's as good as the last one; I've enjoyed it. I hope we get the World Cup in 2006 and win it. In fact I'd like to see England get back to winning a few more things: football, cricket and so on. Football-wise I'd like to see fans starting to appreciate good players like Beckham, Owen and Kewell and laying off them a little bit. Otherwise I don't have any great fears. You know, you keep reading about various disasters like the recent one in Venezuela and you think, is it just coincidence or are a lot of these things coming together at the same time? But I suppose, as the world gets older, then things like that will happen.

webTitle: They used to play on astroturf and terrestrial television

fields.headline: They used to play on astroturf and terrestrial television
fields.trailText: In football it is unwise to presume too much. The end of the 20th century finds the game in a state of rude global health but the shape of its future as a mass spectator sport in the 21st is hard to predict.
fields.body:
In football it is unwise to presume too much. The end of the 20th century finds the game in a state of rude global health but the shape of its future as a mass spectator sport in the 21st is hard to predict.

Football worldwide has never been so popular. More countries than ever before officially play the game as members of Fifa. Satellite television has created millions of new fans. Manchester United's triumph in the European Cup final last May was, quite literally, cheered to the ends of the earth.

There would appear to be no tangible reason why this happy state of affairs should not continue for a long while yet. Fresh fields are about to open up in Asia, which in two years' time will stage its first World Cup. How long will China remain a sleeping giant?

Africa, already a rich source of talent, is bound to provide an increasing number of gifted players for European clubs. South Africa appears increasingly likely to win the Fifa vote for hosting the next World Cup but only provided it can begin to get to grips with the country's crime wave.

In those areas where football has been established much longer, optimism needs to tread more warily. South America continues to produce some of the world's greatest players but for the past three decades economic factors have dictated that virtually all of them will end up earning hard currency in western Europe.

This seems to be the footballing equivalent of cutting down the rainforests. Should the flow of South American talent ever slow to a trickle the effect on global football would be alarming. Brazil and Argentina remain as precious to the future of the game as any European nation.

Association football has been around for a mere 137 years, a relatively short time in millennium terms, yet still manages to behave as if it had a divine right to exist for ever more. That is a lot to take for granted.

The appeal of the sport has always been its simplicity and continuity. Football is not a stop-start game. In theory there should be no reason to halt play other than for goals, assuming there are any, and half-time.

The laws have survived the past 100 years largely unaltered. The only radical change came in 1925 when the number of opponents required to keep an attacker onside was reduced from three to two.

At present the interpretation of the offside law, which has almost always been the biggest bone of contention between referees and players, is about right. Goals can quite properly be allowed if attackers, while in offside positions, are obviously not interfering with play. This, after all, is the original spirit in which the law was framed.

No more tinkering with the way the game is played should be necessary. Fifa has surely gone as far as it can in restricting methods of tackling without ruling out tackling altogether, as was seriously proposed at one point. Fortunately this wheeze, like the nonsense about enlarging the goals, came to nothing.

However, the 21st century may soon see drastic developments in the way matches are controlled. Refereeing controversies have become endemic because the ways television can expose and analyse decisions are becoming increasingly sophisticated.

An already strong temptation to make TV the referee's friend rather than his enemy may prove impossible to resist. A fourth official studying incidents on closed-circuit television and giving his decision through an ear-piece may eventually become as much a part of football as cricket, although spectators might quickly tire of the disruptions to matches this would cause.

Either way television, or rather television money, remains central to football's future as an entertainment. In England the hard bargaining over the next TV contract is about to begin in earnest with a figure of £1bn already common parlance.

The 2002 and 2006 World Cups will not be completely available to terrestrial viewers and Fifa's insistence that in each country every match played by the national team, along with the opening match, semi-finals, third-place game and final, must not go to pay-TV cannot hide the fact that under such a system one of the greatest matches ever played, the 1986 quarter-final between France and Brazil, would in Britain only have been seen live on Sky.

The Premier League's breaking of the BBC-ITV cartel released extra TV millions into the English game and helped, with the Football Trust, to underwrite the cost of building some of the world's safest and most comfortable stadiums. It also attracted the sort of foreign player who previously would never have dreamed of passing up the fortunes being made in continental Europe in order to take a wage cut for the dubious pleasure of being kicked from behind in England.

The new century urgently needs to witness genuine attempts by the clubs to restore an acceptable balance between overseas imports and home-grown products at present in danger of being squeezed out by short-term solutions from abroad. Inflated domestic transfer fees used to be the reason quoted for buying foreign. Now, post-Bosman, the greater problem concerns salaries that continue on an ever-upward spiral.

Far less fuss was made about Roy Keane's recent £50,000-a-week contract at Manchester United than on the day in 1961 when Johnny Haynes became the first footballer to earn a weekly wage of £100. Yet the amount United have had to pay to keep Keane at home, combined with the even greater sums he could still earn in Italy or Spain, will surely usher in the 21st century against a cacophonous background of players' agents trying to obtain proportionately increased deals for their own stars.

For the moment, talk of wage-capping is just that but a showdown with the Professional Footballers' Association cannot be far off. At the beginning of the 60s the £20-a-week ceiling was abolished. Now most clubs would regard a limit of £20,000-a-week as a not unreasonable basis for negotiation even though this would risk losing the best English talents abroad, not to mention a sudden outbreak of homesickness among the Premier League's foreign legion .

Football should be entering the new century aware of its limitations. There has to be a limit to what players can earn and the extra amounts spectators can be charged in order to finance higher wage bills.

Television coverage may not be at saturation point because most of the live stuff is exclusive to Sky's relatively small audience but how much more can viewers be asked to cough up - and is digital pay-per-view going to be that popular anyway?

The worst prospect for football in the new century would be a global satellite TV cartel telling clubs that if they wanted a better deal they had better sound out the Martians. By that time, no doubt, Dan Dare will be in charge of the England team for the Inter-World Cup on Venus, where there has never been a shortage of left-headed midfield players.

webTitle: Nicolas Anelka

fields.headline: Nicolas Anelka
fields.trailText: The first thing I really want to do in the year 2000 is help Real Madrid become world club champions in Brazil. I couldn't take part in the World Cup in France and this is a good opportunity to make amends. It will be a complicated thing to achieve but I don't see why it shouldn't be possible. We have a good enough team, after all - we don't need to sign anybody else. Basically, I want to forget all the bad things that have happened in 1999. I have been working hard during the holidays and have begun to feel part of the Real Madrid team. For people to see the real Anelka I need a lot of time playing on the field and a manager who trusts me.

webTitle: David Mellor

fields.headline: David Mellor
fields.trailText: I hope that England produces a decent football team, for Euro 2000 and beyond, and that we win the right to host the 2006 World Cup. The leading Premiership clubs also have to reconcile whether they want to be European champions or domestic league champions. You can't go on competing in two leagues at the same time. Obviously football is becoming a bigger and bigger money game but I hope its progress around the world is not ruined by the ever more powerful influence of television.

webTitle: Gérard Houllier

fields.headline: Gérard Houllier
fields.trailText: I hope football remains a game and does not move any closer to becoming a business operation. In humanitarian terms, I would like to see a breakthrough in the search for a cure for cancer, a disease which claimed my father. It would also be comforting to think we could, in some way, alleviate the suffering of children on a global scale. At Liverpool we often invite ill and underprivileged children into our training ground; I believe it helps us all to keep things in perspective. My great fear has always been the continuance, if not the further spreading of, warfare. War is our greatest evil, and with so many conflicts raging in so many parts of the world, we should all be concerned.

webTitle: The greatest teams of the century

fields.headline: The greatest teams of the century
fields.trailText: So what's in a hundred years? At first glance the background against which football was being played at the beginning of the 20th century bears a marked similarity to the circumstances in which it is entering the 21st.
fields.body:
So what's in a hundred years? At first glance the background against which football was being played at the beginning of the 20th century bears a marked similarity to the circumstances in which it is entering the 21st.

Victoria reigned then as does another now, the latter enthroned alongside David Beckham in 1999's nattiest nuptials. Englishmen are again engaged in conflict in South Africa, albeit with rather less bloodshed than Spion Kop.

Certain aspects of the game have changed out of all recognition. Spectators have never watched in such safety and comfort although for most of the past 100 years they have watched it in acute discomfort with safety a secondary factor. That it took the Hillsborough tragedy of 1989, some 87 years after the Ibrox disaster, to bring the game to its senses will always be the sport's biggest disgrace.

As to the way football is played, it would surely be an exaggeration to say it is unrecognisable from that seen 100 years ago. Tactics have changed, certainly. There has been an increasing emphasis on defence. Football is now essentially a counter-attacking exercise.

Yet the basics of accurate passing, sound technique, broad vision, concentration and, above all, good imagination have not changed. The increased pace has produced a breed of footballer who for sheer athleticism would leave the players of the past standing but the levels of skill have not improved to the same degree.

Bob Crompton, Blackburn's right-back, was the outstanding figure of the English game before the first world war with Charles Buchan one of its most profound exponents for a time thereafter. Dixie Dean, Clem Stephenson and George Camsell were among those who dominated the inter-war years and the reign of Stanley Matthews will never be equalled.

Selecting an all-time England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland team from the 20th century will only ever be a starting point for endless argument. Those who declare now that Beckham or Ryan Giggs are the greatest British players ever never saw George Best in his prime.

The likes of John Charles, Danny Blanchflower, Jim Baxter, Peter Doherty and Wilf Mannion belong to another age, as did Hughie Gallacher, Alex James and Alex Jackson before them. Choosing one Englishman who could be most relied upon to score a goal or two and it could only be Jimmy Greaves. One goalkeeper and Gordon Banks would just edge out Frank Swift.

There can surely be little argument about Best being the century's outstanding footballer produced by the home countries. Blanchflower, Baxter, Duncan Edwards, Greaves, Matthews, Tom Finney, Bobby Charlton, Johnny Haynes and, yes, Paul Gascoigne would lead the pursuing pack.

Yet football is a team game after all and there have been few better forward lines than Hibernian's Famous Five of the early 50s - Gordon Smith, Bobby Johnstone, Lawrie Reilly, Eddie Turnbull and Willie Ormond. And the forwards who helped Derby win the 1946 FA Cup - Raich Carter, Jack Stamps, Peter Doherty and Dally Duncan - were easily the best in England at that time.

Go overseas and there is a jostling throng of famous names. In the 30s the leading sides were Italy and Austria. Giuseppe Meazza, who played for both Milan and Internazionale, was for a time the world's leading player.

The Superga air crash of 1949, which wiped out a Torino team including eight internationals, delayed Italy's re-emergence post-war but Ernst Ocwirk led another distinguished Austrian side until first the Hungarians and then the Brazilians took over. Ferenc Puskas would get into most people's World XI and, as for Brazil, where do you begin?

There has never been a greater footballer than Pele although two Argentines, Alfredo di Stefano and Diego Maradona, run him close. But what about Didi, Vava, Tostao, Garrincha, Rivelino and Zico, along with Romario, Rivaldo and Ronaldo now?

Johan Cruyff remains the best footballer produced in Europe over the past three decades with Johan Neeskens, Wim van Hanegem, Marco van Basten and Dennis Bergkamp a strong Dutch supporting cast. Fritz Walter, Uwe Seeler, Franz Beckenbauer, Gerd Müller, Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, Lothar Matthäus and Jürgen Klinsmann reflect the success of Germany. France should have won more, given men like Raymond Kopa and Just Fontaine, Michel Platini and Jean Tigana.

Bobby Moore has to appear in a 20th-century England defence but so, arguably, does Neil Franklin. Best is worth more than a mention in an Irish-Welsh XI and players of the quality of Liam Brady and Johnny Giles appeared for the Republic as does one of the world's best, Roy Keane, now.

Scotland: Bill Brown; Eric Caldow, George Young, Martin Buchan, Danny McGrain; Jimmy Johnstone, Jim Baxter, Dave Mackay, Alan Morton; Denis Law, Kenny Dalglish. Subs: Jim Leighton, Tommy Gemmell, Billy Bremner, Hughie Gallacher, Lawrie Reilly, Billy Steel.

webTitle: Scholes misses Brazil for surgery

fields.headline: Scholes misses Brazil for surgery
fields.trailText: Manchester United last night said that Paul Scholes will miss the World Club Championship in Brazil, though the club allayed fears that he might not be ready for England's build-up to the Euro 2000 finals.
fields.body:
Manchester United last night said that Paul Scholes will miss the World Club Championship in Brazil, though the club allayed fears that he might not be ready for England's build-up to the Euro 2000 finals.

The United midfielder was originally named in the squad for the tournament beginning next week but, after discussions yesterday, will stay at home for surgery for a hernia problem.

United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson confirmed: "He won't be going to Brazil. He is going to see a specialist in the next few days and hopefully everything will be sorted out while we are away."

Scholes had been playing with the problem for some time and was always likely to require surgery before the end of the season. But a longer delay before an operation might have put his involvement in Kevin Keegan's preparations for the European Championship in doubt.

Scholes, who aggravated the injury in Tuesday's draw at Sunderland, should now be back in action in four to six weeks. That should free him to be available for England's Wembley meeting with Argentina on February 23.

United now await a decision by tournament organisers as to whether they can name a replacement in the squad for Brazil.

Real Madrid, potential final opponents for United in Brazil, saw their striker Fernando Morientes limp out of training yesterday with a thigh injury that rules him out of their first match.

Nicolas Anelka, who scored his first goal for Real in a charity match on Thursday, is expected to take the place of Morientes against Al Nassr of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.

The French striker's first Real goal after his £23m move from Arsenal last August was front-page news in the Spanish sports press, with one newspaper joking: "Anelka scores - millennium bug takes effect".

Tottenham have agreed to pay £1.2m for Matthew Etherington and Simon Davies, two of Peterborough United's rising stars, after concluding a deal which bypassed the Third Division club's manager Barry Fry.

Previous Spurs inquiries about the midfielders were rebuffed by Fry, who values them at around £1.5m each. But this time he was powerless to intervene as David Pleat, the Spurs director of football, negotiated directly with Peterborough's chairman Peter Boizot.

"Pleat wanted to see my chairman because he couldn't do a deal with me," Fry said yesterday. "I wasn't prepared to sell the players for the figures he talked about."

Spurs will pay £500,000 for the 18-year-old Etherington, a left-sided England under-20 international who could be the long-term successor to David Ginola. Davies, 20, a Wales under-21 player, will cost £700,000. Both trained with United at Ferguson's request last summer.

There is little doubt Fry would have refused to sanction the transfers, which will be completed next week subject to personal terms being agreed. He said he had rejected better offers and had talked of getting £6m in the future. But he refused to castigate Boizot, who saved Peterborough in 1997 after his own bungled attempt to buy the club.

"I told him it's the wrong time to sell them," Fry said. "The players ain't playing well at the moment and we're not doing well. You sell them when they are doing well.

"But I've got no qualms. If he wants to take the money he can take the money whenever he wants. He owns 99.97% of the club and he's put £4.5m in already."

 David Beckham was selected alongside Barcelona's Rivaldo, who beat him to the European footballer of the year award, in a world media dream team yesterday.

Dream Team (3-4-3): Khan (Bayern Munich); Thuram (Parma), Stam (Man Utd), Carlos (Real Madrid); Beckham (Man Utd), Luis Figo (Barcelona), Veron (Lazio), Rivaldo (Barcelona); Batistuta (Fiorentina), Shevchenko (Milan), Vieri (Internazionale).

webTitle: Hussain cries out for firepower

fields.headline: Hussain cries out for firepower
fields.trailText: In two Test matches now England have earned the respect of their opponents. As Nasser Hussain says, the team are near the bottom of a ladder but are beginning to make the climb.
fields.body:
In two Test matches now England have earned the respect of their opponents. As Nasser Hussain says, the team are near the bottom of a ladder but are beginning to make the climb.

That they have been competitive in this series is mostly down to the influence of Hussain and the new coach Duncan Fletcher, who unobtrusively prefers to leave the power base to his captain.

Hussain has responded superbly. He is a man of standards, a tough competitor and a shrewd leader already, although he would willingly say he is not the finished article. But he has tactical nous, the capacity to make tough decisions (Darren Gough, for example, was miffed at Port Elizabeth when Chris Silverwood was given a new ball ahead of him in the second innings but he came back stronger) and clearly has a thriving relationship with Fletcher, whom he had not met before the end of last season. The players have responded by lifting their efforts to a level no watcher of England over the past decade can remember.

Now the show moves on and as yet they have achieved nothing. They are still 1-0 down in the series and to win it they need to take the match which begins here tomorrow and the final Test at Centurion.

Gary Kirsten, asked after his marathon innings in Durban about the pitch at Newlands, reckoned that, unless grass was left on it, it would be similar to Durban but with spin later. In other words, whatever side the South Africans choose - and they have got three out of three wrong so far - they will be backing their bowlers on a flat pitch ahead of England's.

It is probably in England's interests to play on a pitch that has a bit of sap to it and take their chances against Shaun Pollock, Allan Donald and company.

The new ball was crucial at Durban and, with Gough out of sorts, Silverwood willing but lacking class, Alan Mullally out through injury since the first Test and Alex Tudor unable to reveal the talent he showed a year ago, Andy Caddick is the only bowler who looks like taking wickets with it.

Gough is a worry as he is the only bowler in the England side who can reverse-swing the old ball to effect. In the past two games he has charged in, pitched the ball up in an attempt to find the movement, gained none and been clattered for his pains. When Hussain says the ball did not reverse, he means Gough was not managing it.

The same applies to the spin of Phil Tufnell. Perhaps the most telling deliveries of the last day were those bowled by Mark Butcher, a dabbler with offbreaks who found turn and bounce because he put a few revs on the ball. The ball with which he bowled Lance Klusener was a cracker. Yet Tufnell got through 45 overs without making any impact.

There is a theory about Tufnell that, when there is no pressure on him to take wickets, as in the first innings at Port Elizabeth, he relaxes and gets results. But when he is expected to bowl a side out, he cannot hack it.

Hussain recognises that bowling sides out a second time on unhelpful pitches is a problem. England may have missed a trick in not bringing the young Lancashire leg-spinner Chris Schofield with them rather than Graeme Swann, who is wondering why he is here.

For the next Test England will have Michael Vaughan back to replace Darren Maddy - and Mullally as an alternative to Silverwood.

But, if the pitch looks as if it might take spin, there is a case for Swann's inclusion, in an initial squad at least. That would perk him up no end: his work in the nets has given him a criss-cross tan and he would like to top it up.

webTitle: Shocked Shoaib is banned for throwing

fields.headline: Shocked Shoaib is banned for throwing
fields.trailText: Shoaib Akhtar, the fastest bowler in the world, passed a distressed Millennium Eve in a Perth hotel room after being banned from international cricket for a month because of an illegal bowling action.
fields.body:
Shoaib Akhtar, the fastest bowler in the world, passed a distressed Millennium Eve in a Perth hotel room after being banned from international cricket for a month because of an illegal bowling action.

Shoaib will return to Pakistan within the next few days to remodel an action now officially viewed as flawed, amid doubts whether his ferocious bowling style, seen most markedly during last summer's World Cup, can ever be repeated. It would be a terrible loss if the Rawalpindi Express now became more laughing stock than rolling stock.

"I'm totally shocked," Shoaib said. "They won't give me a definite word as to what is wrong with me. They've just told me to remodel my action."

The misgivings of the International Cricket Council's illegal deliveries panel primarily concern the apparent occasional "chucking" of Shoaib's bouncer. The nine-man panel detected a slight straightening of the arm after studying video evidence and reached their conclusions after a teleconference lasting more than one hour.

Shoaib had reflected during the Test series against Australia late last year, when learning that a video of his action had been sent to the ICC: "They are saying my action has changed since I had a shoulder injury earlier this year, but I think that is wrong."

Waqar Younis flies to Perth today as a replacement for Shoaib and will join the Pakistan squad preparing for a one-day series against Australia and India. He may receive a frosty reception from Wasim Akram, as Waqar has recently accused his captain of freezing him out of the side.

The Pakistan Cricket Board remains in a disturbing state of flux, administrators being replaced almost monthly, but indications are that it will comply with ICC instructions.

Shafqat Rana, the PCB secretary, said: "We have been asked to work on Shoaib's action. The ICC is the supreme authority. We can't go against them. They must have acted in the best way they could."

Australian umpires, at the forefront of a heightened campaign against illegal bowling actions, will feel that their reservations about Shoaib, which hardened during the recent Test series, have now been entirely vindicated.

Certainly the ICC has cause for satisfaction that its procedure regarding suspect actions is no longer so obviously flawed. Once umpires' reservations were formally raised, Shoaib's action was automatically examined in the most sympathetic manner available: that of video evidence.

That compares favourably with the witchhunt against the Sri Lankan spinner, Muttiah Muralitharan, in Australia a year ago. Murali endured a whispering campaign before being called during a match, erroneously as video evidence proved, in an atmosphere that stunk of premeditation.

It is also an advance from the leave-alone approach of much of the past 30 years when several prominent fast bowlers, notably the late Sylvester Clarke, were persistently rumoured as possessing illegal actions without a proper investigation ever being undertaken.

Nottinghamshire, who had achieved a coup by signing Shoaib for next season, face an anxious wait as they monitor a rehabilitation programme which, under recent ICC guidelines, becomes the responsibility of the Pakistan board.

Pakistan's team manager, Brigadier Mohammad Nasir, said: "The objections were not serious. Shoaib has to remove minor things. He'll be all right. He's a fighter and I have full faith that he will be able to overcome these objections raised against him. I don't see his career ending."

Wasim, Shoaib's new-ball partner, reflected the prevailing view in Pakistan that there is nothing to remedy. "I have played more cricket than anyone else in the world and I think that his action is fine, more than fine," he said. "The poor guy. I can't imagine what he is feeling. My heart goes out to him."

It is a technological aid that the ICC should consider officially utilising.

The ICC will study further video evidence in a month and, if it is satisfied, this could enable Shoaib to return in a home Test series against Sri Lanka.

webTitle: Diary: Gasmen came, dad died, Mary still plays harpsichord

fields.headline: Diary: Gasmen came, dad died, Mary still plays harpsichord
fields.trailText: Thanks so much for the tidal wave of circular Christmas letters. As I read them I began to feel like a voyeur, peering in unseen at the windows of these happy, active, wonderfully worthwhile families with their talented children, their ceaseless charity work, musical skills which would make the von Trapps envious, yachting holidays, 100-mile hikes, professional successes and loveable pets.
fields.body:
Thanks so much for the tidal wave of circular Christmas letters. As I read them I began to feel like a voyeur, peering in unseen at the windows of these happy, active, wonderfully worthwhile families with their talented children, their ceaseless charity work, musical skills which would make the von Trapps envious, yachting holidays, 100-mile hikes, professional successes and loveable pets.

At times there is a darker side. Some families clearly lead lives of such stupefying dullness that the tiniest incident has to be dragooned into the annual newsletter, as in this one from Lancashire: "The gas men finally came on January 11. They had been supposed to come at the beginning of December", or from Hampshire: "During this period and the ensuing months we converted the cesspit into a septic tank."

At Portsmouth college they have an annual competition for the best, genuine examples of the genre. Annette Foster writes: "Points are awarded for the inspirational: ('Tamara ran her best time in the Boston Marathon with a podiatric orthotic'); the aspirational: ('Sadly, Dad died in June. We now have a six-person dining table with drop-in leaf'); and work ethic gone mad: ('One weekend Jim travelled to meetings in China and Korea, crossed seven time zones and was at a 7am breakfast meeting in the Washington office on Monday.')

"For US correspondents a bonus is given for the most frequent use of the words 'challenging', 'exciting' and 'rewarding'; for English entries, the same for most pretentious children's names - a trio called Barnaby, Mungo and Buffy will be hard to beat."

Ginny Sykes sent an email from her daugher Jessica, who was peering over an old lady's shoulder on the tube and spotted this: "Despite her boundless work with the sickle-cell charity, Mary seems to still find time for the harpsichord."

It's a pretty sound rule that anyone called The Jones Tribe or Those Pettigrews Again! will have dreary lives. This from The Smith Clan of Wiltshire: "Nigel had a very special birthday this year, and was given a new golf bag . . . well, chaos still reigns in the Smith household!"

A musical family from the Isle of Man delight their friends every year with four pages of A4 paper, at least 2,000 words long, lavishly illustrated with photos, and I have to admit they look terribly nice people. As it is, nobody could possible need to know everything about them: "In March, Kati gained distinction for grade 4 theory and is currently awaiting the result of grade 5 flugelhorn."

Children's names remain a special problem. One feels that a short apologia should be attached, for example, "I know Chauncey is a really stupid name, but it was my father's, and he died two days before the baby was born" would serve. But nobody ever does, as in this example (surname and address cut off by sender): "The children are all thriving. Jack is doing wonderfully well at prep school, India continues to excel at ballet, and Tara is riding, both passing exams and winning competitions with flying colours. Xanthe is eccentric and charming and keeps me smiling [oh, dear, that's a euphemism for something, I fear], Kinvara talks incessantly and is a guinea-a-minute! [another euphemism, perhaps]. There is never a dull moment, specially since I dispensed with the nanny in February!"

I wish I had space to describe the 1,500-word newsletter almost entirely devoted to the world's most disastrous yachting holiday. ("At this point we were towed into harbour and our passports confiscated," gives you a flavour.) And I enjoyed the philosophical one from Leicester ("Life must be lived in the context of history," they tell their friends), received annually by Dave Sang in Bognor: "I think it is intended for the previous occupants who moved 10 years ago. Their confidence that it is still worth sending after a decade has passed without them receiving a reply is rather touching."

But, as we connoisseurs of such letters know well, not at all surprising.

The disparity between media coverage of sport and actual public interest has been fascinatingly displayed during the current Test series against South Africa. Acres of space are devoted to the games, an anguished national debate was held when Talk Radio nicked the rights from the BBC, and we are genuinely supposed to be depressed because England failed to force home their advantage in the third Test.

But there's no one there. The stands are virtually empty. The tiny sprinkling of people are half England supporters anyway. They get bigger crowds at Hartlepool FC. If nobody there gives two hoots, why should we care at all?

Seasons In The Sun by Terry Jacks was probably the worst number one of 1974, and until a week ago, Cliff Richard's Millennium Prayer was the worst of 1999. Now he has been toppled by Westlife's version of the Terry Jacks song, a record so empty and so bland that it bestows on the original a raw, Lawrentian emotional intensity. You can't even call it sentimental; it's just nothing. It tells us all we need to know about pop at the end of the century: John Lennon is dead, George Harrison is in hospital, and Westlife are top of the charts.

I've been watching my Ali G tape over Christmas. In case you don't know, he's the Voice of Youth from Channel 4's 11 O'Clock Show. Though a white Cambridge graduate, he dresses like a black gangsta, in yellow wraparound shades, baggy trousers and trainers the size of military pontoons (see below). His speciality is interviewing real people who live in their own intellectually closed world, and asking them questions which leave them reeling with disbelief and us rocking with laughter. To Tony Benn: "Isn't havin' a strike just the same as callin' a sickie?"

He asked a feminist lecturer: "Would you feel safe if a woman was flyin' your plane?" and later "Do you think it's right that the women should be tryin' feminism just once, when they be drunk at a party?"

Ali G in Northern Ireland was superb, since so many people there are firmly stuck in their own narrow groove. To a militant unionist: "Are you Irish?" "No, I am British!" "So, are you on holiday?" and "Why you be always dissin' the RAC? Why you be dissin' a breakdown service?" I suppose that most of his victims are so vague about modern youth and so anxious not to appear racist, that they take this seriously, and evidently don't even notice that Ali G is actually as pale-skinned as a blancmange. And yet, and yet . . . I suppose Mr Cohen, who plays Ali G, would argue that he was satirising not black people, but white kids who want to pin black culture on to themselves as a fashion accessory. But I'm faintly reminded of Al Jolson and the Black and White Minstrels - all white men and women amusing us with the humorous, colourful, eyeball-rolling ways of black people. But perhaps I'm taking the whole thing much too seriously.

webTitle: Weaving a spell

fields.headline: Weaving a spell
fields.trailText:
Stravinsky/Sellars
Netherlands Opera, Amsterdam
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Stravinsky/Sellars
Netherlands Opera, Amsterdam
Rating: ****

If the Glyndebourne production of Handel's oratorio Theodora unforgettably demonstrated Peter Sellars' ability to create a spell-binding theatrical experience out of a work that was never intended for the stage, his Stravinsky project for Netherlands Opera poses an even greater challenge.

None of the six works on biblical themes that Stravinsky composed in the last decade of his life has a true dramatic component, though one of them, The Flood, was originally written for television. But in the Amsterdam Muziektheater Sellars has woven it into a fascinating sequence of images, seamless and coherent, in which man's relationship with God is probed and ultimately celebrated.

As the evening unfolds the focus changes, from the Old Testament depictions of myth to the New Testament assertion of belief. Paradoxically the staging gains in power and impact as the subject matter becomes less concerned with story-telling, and the choreography has a freer rein.

The whole enterprise is contained with George Tsypin's monumental set. The wood-floored stage area is left bare for the intricate deployments of Sellars' interpretation, with singers, dancers and actors combined in ever-changing conformations.

Sometimes the focus is intimate - in Abraham and Isaac dancers and actors enact the story in a tightly circumscribed area right downstage while the solo baritone delivers the text - but as the focus shifts from individuals to communities the action becomes all-embracing. Threni is compelling, with the singers (the Theatre of Voices and the Netherlands Opera Chorus) mingled with the dance troupe (choreographed by Donald Byrd) and developing an extraordinary abstract ritual of grief, making full use of the hand signing that has become a trademark of Sellars's direction of religious subject matter.

The whole experience is unclassifiable: not conventionally operatic in any sense, and not likely to be repeated elsewhere, but still worthwhile when a director with Sellars' vision is behind it.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: New York ends millennium with record-breaking figures

fields.headline: New York ends millennium with record-breaking figures
fields.trailText: US stock markets celebrated the last day of the millennium by doing what they have done best all year - breaking records.
fields.body:
US stock markets celebrated the last day of the millennium by doing what they have done best all year - breaking records.

The Nasdaq composite index topped the best performing year in history for any US stock market by ending up 32.12 at 4068.99 when it closed at lunchtime in New York. The technology-driven index had breached the 4,000 mark for the first time in its 28-year history earlier this week after a year in which it had broken more than 60 records. It rose about 85% in 1999.

Private investors and last minute bargain-hunters ignored fears of a computer meltdown to buy yet more shares of companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

The Dow Jones closed up 44.26 at a record 11497.12. Reports that the Y2K bug had failed to affect other financial centres around the world helped push US shares higher in the last few hours of trading in the 20th century.

The traditional seasonal lull between Christmas and the new year seemed to make little difference as the markets shrugged off the surprise resignation of Boris Yeltsin, the Russian president.

The Dow Jones has risen about 25% this year and from just 65.73 on the very last trading day of 1899. Technology companies dominated the top 10 performers in the US this year.

Qualcomm, the mobile phone technology group, was 1999's best performing company, according to Standard and Poors, with a share price increase of about 1,656%.

Some of the world's biggest companies were among the best performers. Microsoft, the world's largest software company, became the most highly valued group this year, confirming Bill Gates, its founder and chairman, as the world's richest man. The gains came in spite of a landmark anti-trust lawsuit and fears over what the millennium bug would do to the world's software.

Dell, the computer group, was the best performer of the decade with an increase of more than 91,000%. Party poopers have pointed out that some of the most successful stock market performers such as Amazon.com are also the most indebted or loss-making in America.

Stock market bears, who have spent much of the 1990s being wrong, have predicted a fallout of internet stocks early in the new year.

webTitle: Revelations unravelled

fields.headline: Revelations unravelled
fields.trailText:
The Apocalypse
British Museum, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Apocalypse
British Museum, London
Rating: ****

Wandering among the glass cabinets in the British Museum's department of prints and drawings, you find yourself poring over interpretations of the Book of Revelation and seeing the same images of ruin down the centuries: St John of Patmos eating the book, the angel who opens the Seventh Seal and pours a "fiery incense" on the earth, causing earthquakes, floods and massacres, the Four Horsemen - the Conqueror, War, Famine and, behind them, Death on a Pale Horse.

Exhibiting all this stuff on the millennium's eve is great fun, but makes for a mad, occulted labyrinth of an exhibition. To enjoy it you have to become a fanatic, scrutinising scores of prints for signs of the end. The British Museum has the best collection of prints in the world. Here there is a clumsy, populist gesture in adding a papier mache tableau of the Mexican Day of the Dead and a few film stills to what should really be a more lucid unveiling.

None the less, it is weirdly addictive. You can glut on catastrophe and horror. Here are the Four Horsemen in Albrecht Durer's engravings published in 1498, riding across the earth with fierce determination, crushing peasants and burghers. Durer's hard, firm line makes his Horsemen terrifyingly mechanical.

Many saw the Apocalypse as a consummation devoutly to be wished. There is a drawing of Britain's destruction by Jonathan Martin, brother of the Victorian apocalyptic painter John Martin. Jonathan tried to make his vision come true by setting fire to Yorkminster - and ended up in Bedlam. For the dispossessed, the apocalypse was not just the end but a beginning - when the new Jerusalem appears. William Blake's hand-coloured prints for his book Jerusalem are juxtaposed with two millennarian prophets from the turn of the 19th century, Richard Brothers and Joanna Southcott.

Brothers, self-styled "Prince of the Hebrews and Nephew of the Almighty", created an architectural blueprint for the New Jerusalem. Sixty-five year old Southcott said she would give birth to Shiloh, whose coming would mark the beginning of Revelation. She died childless.

The apocalypse dissolves in art after the first world war; the 20th century unveiled things that make the Book of Revelation seem almost cosy.

 British Museum, Great Russell Street, London, WC1 (020 7636 1555) until April 24

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.body:
Black Sabbath
NEC, Birmingham
Rating: ****

On Christ's 2,000th birthday these old devils are finally announcing their retirement. Billed as the Last Supper, this is allegedly Black Sabbath's final bow. Lest we forget, this is the band whose singer Ozzy Osbourne will be remembered for biting the head off a bat onstage; who collectively drank more than four Ollie Reeds; who single-handedly inspired almost every scene in Spinal Tap (pioneering the use of the rock drummer in combustion) and whose guitarist Tony Iommi wore a moustache that would invite prosecution in many civilised countries. But really, Sabbath should be re membered for some of the truly seminal hard rock of the 20th century. And it is this - not the bats - of which they seek to remind us.

The gig is like a Nuremburg rally soundtracked by hell's house band. But what is most remarkable is not the 11,000 voices chanting things such as "The war machine is burning", an unexpected glimmer of rock's forgotten insurrection, but just how strangely primal Sabbath sound. Any other ageing rock band would rely on technology or additional key board players to embellish their creaking limbs. Sabbath don't. It is just the four of them, in a (very large) room, plugging fabulously into whatever unholy adolescent rage once gave birth to classics such as Electric Funeral.

The master of ceremonies is, of course, Osbourne. Sober for many years, Ozzy either has enough demon drink left inside him from the bad days or gets some kind of weird high from inducing pandemonium. At one point, he yells "Go crazy!" upon which the crowd start hurling seat cushions into the air, which continues for most of the set. It is almost, well, demonic.

But Ozzy solo is not a patch on Oz with Sabbath and the band underline just how much he needs them. Tony Iommi - moustache proudly untrimmed - is surely one of the most underrated rock guitarists of all time. Geezer Butler - long-haired at almost 50 - never once stops headbanging, while Bill Ward proves that not even a heart attack has stopped him remaining the pulse beat of the band. They slip, effortlessly from rock to black funk, and my only gripe is the absence of their overlooked gentler side and that Ozzy asks me to put my hands up around 45 times too often.

At the end, things get very emotional. Ozzy hugs the band and they return with a rendition of Paranoid that can presumably be heard in China. Is this the end of Sabbath? I'd guess possibly not. But whatever happens, the world will be a quieter place without them.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
